title: Most money you can earn without paying a dime in tax
content:encoded:
Every year, around February or March, I start dreading checking the mail. I dread it because itâ€™s that special time of the year. Itâ€™s the time you have to gather all those illegible slips you received from your employer and enter them in to some half baked software online. As you go through the process, the dollar amount you owe/receive will swing wildly making you break into a sweaty mess. All of this is coupled with a stack of indecipherable rules handed down to you from some government entity responsible for the tax collection.

The entire mess with all the pre-tax and post-tax deductions, itemization, credits, and exemptions makes it incomprehensible if all you want to do is â€œpay your fair shareâ€. Additionally, once a tax break is given, itâ€™s very hard to take it back. Thus; we end up with 80,000 pages of IRS lawyerÂ talk.

Wouldnâ€™t it be great if at least you could take advantage of all theseÂ rules?

Thatâ€™s why, Iâ€™m going to explore here the following question: What is the maximum amount you can earn without paying any federalÂ tax?

To keep this manageable, I will make a few assumptions. First, youâ€™re filing as a married couple. This is purely out of convenience for me since thatâ€™s how I file. If you are filing as a single person, most of the time you can just divide the number in half. Additionally, there is a pile of rules Iâ€™ll ignore for convenience. They either donâ€™t apply to the vast majority of people or are insignificant for the bottom line. Also, I will ignore Medicaid and Social security taxes. Finally, I will ignore any possible employer contributions or matches into your retirement accounts.

Letâ€™s start by defining a fewÂ terms.

Pre-tax (or traditional)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA type of deduction for which you donâ€™t have to pay taxÂ upfront.

Post-tax (or roth)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA type of deduction for which you do pay taxÂ upfront.

401(k)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA retirement plan sponsored by yourÂ employer

IRAâ€Šâ€”â€ŠA retirement plan that you pay for yourself.

Standard deductionâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAn amount every tax filer gets to deduct from their income to find their taxableÂ income.

Capital gainsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe tax applied on an investment

Everything beyond will assume a pre-tax or traditional deduction. Roth deductions are for suckers. We will explore thatÂ next.

Now that we got the jargon out of the way, letâ€™s see how we can apply it. We can start with the easiest. The standard deduction. It is $24,000 for a couple for the year 2018. If your family unit is bringing $24,000 per year, the standard deduction would bring your taxable income down to $0. In turn, your taxes would be $0. Fantastic.

Next, you can contribute to a traditional IRA. The limits for traditional IRAs is $5500 per person or $11,000 per couple. Remember that a traditional IRA is a pre-tax deduction. Thus; you can earn an additional $11,000 per couple and pay $0 tax. We are now up toÂ $35,000.

Similarly to IRA, you can also contribute to a traditional 401(k) program with your employer (if the employer is offering it). Each person has an IRS mandated limit of $18,500. Since youâ€™re filing as a couple that gives you a total of $37,000 to deduct. Adding it to the above gives us a total of $72,000 tax freeÂ dollars.

Thereâ€™s one more easy pre-tax deduction left. The health savings account (HSA). This is a great choice for individuals with low medical expenses. Some highly respectable online individuals even describe it as the ultimate savings account. For 2018, the limit for a couple is $6,900. Adding that in to our total gives us $78,900 tax freeÂ dollars.

In many cases, 401(k)â€™s and HSAâ€™s come with a few more advantages. First, many employers are willing to match at least a part of your contributions. That usually amounts to a few thousand tax free dollars. Additionally, if you are 50 or older, 401(k)â€™s allow you to sock away another $6000 per individual. Thatâ€™s another potential $12,000 to put away depending on yourÂ age.

Alright, we got all the obvious things out of the way. If you are not maximizing these, what are you waitingÂ for?

Now letâ€™s talk about the more esoteric options. First, thereâ€™s the 457(b). Thatâ€™s a special program for government workers. If you are a teacher or a nurse or some other government worker you can usually participate in this plan. 457(b) plan has an interesting feature. Unlike other employer sponsored retirement plans, this option has a separate limit. That means you can contribute to both 401(k) and 457(b). Both also have the same limits. Therefore; if a couple works for the government, thatâ€™s an additional $37,000 that can be deducted. That would give you $115,900 tax free dollars if my math isÂ correct.

Of course this is not the Soviet Union. We donâ€™t all work for the government. However, there is one other interesting way to reduce your taxes. If you went through my list of terms above, you may remember â€œcapital gainsâ€; the tax applied on investments. The great thing about this tax is that under certain conditions, when your investment â€œqualifiesâ€, this tax can be 0 percent. You heard that right. Youâ€™ll pay nothing. The requirements are also relatively moderate. The main requirement is that your investment must be held for at least aÂ year.

Once your investment is â€œqualifiedâ€, as long as you manage to keep your total taxable income to under $77,200, youâ€™ll actually owe nothing to the government. Taxable is bolded on purpose. Remember that through the power of IRAâ€™s, 401(k)â€™s and HSAâ€™s we were able to earn $78,900 tax free. Thatâ€™s because, for the purpose of taxation, youâ€™ve earned $0. Now, if you were to earn an additional $77,200 from capital gains, that would still be taxed at 0 percent due to capital gains taxes.Â Amazing!

So whatâ€™s the bottomÂ line?

As a couple with a decent job, you can earn $78,900 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

As a couple working for the state or federal government, you can earn $115,900 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

As a couple working for the government and amassing an impressive portfolio, you can earn an astonishing $193,100 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

As a couple above 50, working for the government and amassing an impressive portfolio, you can earn $205,100 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

Thereâ€™s a huge array of further deductions and credits you can look into to reduce your taxes further. If you prefer, you can think of it as increasing your taxable income while keeping your tax obligation at zero. For example, the child tax credit can give you up toÂ $2000.

However, most of us are not working for the government and do not have a portfolio that can generate $80,000 in capital gains year after year. Yet we can still reduce are taxable income by almost $79,000. To put that in perspective, the median income of a married household in 2016 was roughly $87,000; a little more then you canÂ deduct.

Iâ€™m a strong proponent of saving hard and saving fast. Thatâ€™s why, I encourage everyone to participate in any government money give away that is available to them within the legal boundaries. Retirement savings programs are â€œuse it or loseâ€ it programs. Make sure you useÂ it.

title: Elaborating more on Bitcoin value
content:encoded:
Friends have been asking me for weeks about what I thought of this promising new investment opportunity. I promised them a blog post was coming and delivered it. Since then, Iâ€™ve done some more reading about the concept and would like to clarify a fewÂ stances.

Before I do any clarification, I just want to say that I think the idea is actually very interesting. It is modeled after gold and assumes certain positions on the economy and prosperity. The libertarian in me definitely likes where this isÂ going.

One error that I made when reading about Bitcoin was the assumption that all transactions are completely anonymous. I was under the impression that you can transfer money between two consenting adults and the government cannot politely place their noses in your business and ask for a cut. However, thatâ€™s not theÂ case.

Either way, the idea of modeling it like gold is very intriguing. Every so often, when a conversation turns to money, someone looking to sound smart will state some sort of an opinion about how todayâ€™s money is â€œfiat currencyâ€ backed by nothing but thin air and promises. In the good old days, we had the gold standard so each dollar was worth something.

As the video above points out around the 50 second mark, the gold standard does not mean that money is backed by anything either. Gold is just a convenient way of figuring out who owns what and who owes who. It is like a ledger where we write down all the transactions.

Gold isnâ€™t valuable because we make jewellery out of it. Itâ€™s the other wayÂ around.

As it turns out, good forms of money (such as gold) have 5 properties.

  1. Scarcityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGold is pretty hard toÂ find
  2. Fungiabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAny gram of gold is equallyÂ valuable
  3. Divisibilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠYou can subdivide gold into smaller pieces to pay for cheaperÂ things.
  4. Durabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGold is a noble metal. Does not react under most extreme weather conditions.
  5. Transferabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠExchanging gold coins is reasonably easy and been done for thousands ofÂ years.

Bitcoin meets all of the criteria above and some would argue exceeds these criteria relatively to gold. Does it mean itâ€™s time to remortgage your house and go all in on Bitcoin mining like your Uber driver told you? Not quite. Thereâ€™s 4 big problems that I see with the current state of crypto-currencies.

Itâ€™s not an investment. The view that Bitcoin is an investment seems to be the most dangerous to me although itâ€™s a widely held belief. To be fair, itâ€™s hard to argue with results. If you held Bitcoin from 2010 to today youâ€™d be a Zillionaire. Naturally, the typical precautions apply. â€œPast performance do not guarantee future resultsâ€.

However, Iâ€™m mostly referring to the word â€œinvestmentâ€. I donâ€™t think it should be used in this case. The reason is that an investment implies some sort of return due to added value. For example, you invest in stocks because you get to own a company that presumably adds value over time. Added value leads to bigger profits. Bigger profits lead to dividends and as a share holder you have a claim on those dividends. Similarly, we invest in real estate because we count on the rental income. We provide the valuable service of shelter and to thank us, the renter hands usÂ dollars.

Where is the value being added when you store your dollars in the form of Bitcoin? Thereâ€™s none actually. Itâ€™s just a commodity like gold. You may argue that itâ€™s a store of value. You can make an argument that itâ€™s a hedge against inflation (assuming it ever stabilizes in price). But thereâ€™s definitely no added value there so itâ€™s not an investment.

And it isnâ€™t just semantics. Something that is not an investment but you still risk money on to make more money sounds a lot like a gamble. I think that if everyone treated it like a gamble, the results wouldnâ€™t be nearly as exciting. The pundits on TV would have to quiet down and the small talk at dinner will have to shift back to real estate (because thatâ€™s what we did before Bitcoin).

Investors have no clue how it works. We were having a social gathering the other day. Once we were done talking about Trump for the night, the conversation obviously shifted to Bitcoin. Two of my friends wanted to know what I thought of the idea and if they should invest in it. We started talking about some fundamentals of money and investing when it dawned on me; I was standing next to two world class software engineers neither of whom understood how crypto-currencies worked. Neither did I. However, they were ready to put down thousands of dollars into this â€œinvestmentâ€.

A week later I am chatting with another friend over coffee when he pulls out his phone to show me his portfolio. He has huge gains. Over 80% in just a month. Turns out he invested in 20 different crypto-currencies. However, when I asked him what percentage of the tech he understood, he admitted that it was roughly 0.5%. I appreciate the honesty but worried of the implications.

To be fair, this is anecdotal but I have a feeling itâ€™s much more wide spread than many realize. Personally, I would never dream of investing in a company without ever knowing at least what they do and looking at some financial ratios. However, in this case, at least in some limited examples, it seems like the default approach is to buy now and figure it outÂ later.

Itâ€™s actually not that useful. This reason is most up for debate but I think itâ€™s also going to be the most influential. For a currency to be of any use, it must be widely accepted. Bitcoin isnâ€™t quite there yet. Some would argue that itâ€™s just a matter of time until itâ€™s adopted. However, Iâ€™m wondering why? Why would anyone actually useÂ it?

I see one use case for me. I would like to be able to transfer money internationally without paying a middle man. Some people may like to buy guns and blow on the black market. Outside of that, Iâ€™m not really sure why it would be adopted. It makes moving money marginally better but adds a lot of barriers that need to be overcome.

What Iâ€™m really saying, is that beyond the hyper paranoid consumer and the mafia Don, thereâ€™s very little added value to Bitcoin as a currency. Therefore; I must wonder why it would gain any traction as a currency versus more established ones like the USD. Iâ€™m thinking about your average consumer. The ones that make up 95% of the population.

It can easily be competed out of business. So thereâ€™s Bitcoin. Thereâ€™s also Litecoin, Ethereum and Ripple. Three weeks ago, I introduced SuckerCoin. In fact, as of this writing, thereâ€™s thousands of different crypto-currencies you can trade. Crypto-currencies are built on public ideas and open source technologies. Thereâ€™s very little competitive advantage any one currency has that another cannot justÂ adopt.

Bitcoin does have the advantage that is the first and best known. However, that could easily be erased over time as others gain (or Bitcoin loses). One option companies use to maintain their competitive advantage is to lobby the government for regulations and licensing to keep competitors out. I have a hard time imagining the Bitcoin lobby passing that through congressÂ though.

The result is that anyone can start their own crypto-currency. Some of them have even real advantages. For example, Bitcoin has a limitation on how many transactions it can process in a 10 minute block. That is addressed in other currencies. Some currencies donâ€™t even bother with that. They just jump on the hype train. After all, a rising tied lifts allÂ boats.

If Bitcoin, or any other crypto-currency has any chance of staying around for the long term, it must be the currency that is accepted everywhere. But with thousands of currencies, how would anyone make the right choice? Of course, you could imagine a world where everyone accepts all crypto-currencies. However, in that case, the whole scarcity idea (property #1) becomesÂ â€¦ questionable.

Conclusion

I think that Bitcoin is a really cool idea. Getting central planning out of our money supply is a goal worth pursuing. Bitcoin should be thought of as version 1.0 of that idea. But just like all good software, we need to keep iterating overÂ it.

Block-chain (the general idea behind all crypto-currencies) is great. Iâ€™m sure it will be widely adopted. Maybe even for our own financial system. Maybe by our governments. Who knows? However, Iâ€™m going to stick to the tried and true. Iâ€™m keeping my money in a well diversified passively managed index fund and I recommend you do the same. More on thatÂ later.

title: What to insure
content:encoded:
This is highly inspired by an article from Mr. Money Mustache titled Insurance: A Tax on the stupid and I found it to be quite influential for my way of thinking about insurance. The premise of the article is simple. Insure only the things you cannot afford to lose. Pay up for the rest because in the long run youâ€™ll saveÂ money.

This makes perfect sense as well. Take any insurance company as an example. It exists for the sole purpose of making money. It does this by paying out less then it brings in. That means, the risk that itâ€™s covering must cost less in the long run then what it charges for it in premiums. I think no one would argue against thisÂ idea.

Humans have two major flaws when it comes to losses. The first is that we seem to feel twice the amount of pain for a loss then an equivalent gain. Putting this in dollars is the easiest way. Youâ€™d feel twice as much pain for losing $100 then the pleasure of gaining $100. This is completely irrational but thatâ€™s just the way the mind works. It is called loss aversion.

The second flaw is that we are really bad at estimating probabilities. Especially when these events are extremely unlikely. Thatâ€™s why we have irrational fears about dying in a plane crash but arenâ€™t worried what so ever about heart disease. Yet the former kills a tiny fraction of theÂ latter.

So given these two flaws of human behaviour, we can now see why insurance becomes a bad deal. An insurance company knows roughly how likely houses are to burn down or your electronics getting damaged. With a large enough pool of people, they can calculate the risk reasonably well and then distribute it over many premium payers. In fact, since we over estimate the likelihood and the pain of loss, they can charge us significantly more forÂ it.

The other issue I have with insurance is that people seem to insure absolutely everything of any moderate value. For example, people buy extended warranty on their TVâ€™s and phones. They buy extended coverage on their cars. They insurance their pets. Etc. So whatâ€™s theÂ problem?

The problem is that itâ€™s generally a big waste ofÂ money.

Not only are you making money for the insurance companies but also itâ€™s extremely silly to insure something you could afford to repurchase without thinking twice about it. If someone dents my car and I felt the need to fix it, I could pretty easily afford to do it and never think about it again. I wouldnâ€™t bother going to the insurance company forÂ it.

So the general rule of thumb is very simple. Buy insurance only if you cannot afford the replacement or the bills to fix it. For example, if my house burned down and I needed to rebuild it, I could not afford it. Thus; I insure my house. On the other hand, my deductible for my insurance is set to the maximum because I can afford to pay for it out ofÂ pocket.

And if you stop to think about the purpose of insurance, youâ€™ll realize that is there to cover you in case of a catastrophic events. It is not there to save you $20. Dropping your flat screen TV on the floor is not a catastrophic event so buying extended insurance is plain dumb. Unless of course it is in which case buying a flat screen TV is plainÂ dumb.

Thereâ€™s one other situation that you can justify buying insurance for. It is very specific and youâ€™re unlikely to run into but I feel I should mention it anyway. It is the time when you have some additional information that the insurance company doesnâ€™t that significantly increases your risk. For example, letâ€™s say youâ€™re extremely shitty driver but youâ€™re getting a great quote from GEICO. If you have a really good reason to believe that the insurance company is underestimating their risk significantly, go ahead and insure. But Thatâ€™s unlikely to be true and the gain is probably not very significant.

title: Correction. Holding ESPPâ€™s is worse than I thought
content:encoded:
Correction. Holding ESPPs is worse than IÂ thought

This doesnâ€™t happen veryÂ often.

I was correctedâ€Šâ€”â€Šon Twitter of all places. Turns out, my advice to you about selling ESPPs was spot on but my reasoning was wrong. I am here humbled in front of you and I stand corrected. Thank you Tom Larson for setting me straight.

Tax treatment for ESPPs is more complicated than I initially thought. My whole argument was centered around the idea that keeping the ESPP shares to pay long term capital gains tax was misguided because the savings are minuscule. The math is certainly impeccable. The tax treatment on the other hand isÂ wrong.

Turns out, any discount given to you by your employer, is always taxed as regular incomeâ€Šâ€”â€Šregardless of how long you kept it for. Thatâ€™s a bummer forÂ Aaron.

It gets even nastier. My buddy Bob pointed another provision in the tax code. But first, a few definitions:

  1. Offering period: the period of time the participant is locked in to a particular stock purchase plan; typically this is 12Â months.
  2. Purchase period: the frequency in which you purchase stock within your offering period; typically this is 6 months (meaning thereâ€™s two purchase periods in a typical offeringÂ period).

Great, now that weâ€™re up to speed, letâ€™s pretend your company stock doubled between the beginning of the offering period and the purchase date 6 months later. Hereâ€™s the kicker: to get a long term capital gains rate on the gain beyond the company discount, you must meet two criteria.

  1. Hold the shares for 12 months from the purchase dateÂ AND
  2. Hold the shares for 24 months from the beginning of the offeringÂ period.

That means, half the time you must hold your company stock for a full 18 months before you get to enjoy the lower taxÂ rate.

To summarize for the skimmers: any discount given to you by the employer is always taxed as regular income. Any gain beyond that may be taxed as long term capital gains but the shares must be held for 24 months after offering periodÂ starts.

If the stock price went down between the offering date and the purchase date, the decisions becomes a complete no-brainer. Sell immediately. There is no advantages to beÂ gained.

If the stock is up and youâ€™re thinking of holding on to save a couple of bucks, considerÂ these:

  1. Would you buy the stock today at the currentÂ price?
  2. Are you willing to hold on for up to 18 months to save around 10% of yourÂ gains?

If itâ€™s a resounding yes to both questions, go ahead and wait. If any of them is a no, sell immediately; then go ahead and open up a betterment account.

title: Will purchasing a home help or hurt financial independence?
content:encoded:
A few approaches to a complicated question.

When I first discovered financial independence (FI or Effai), life was simple. I could plug in a few numbers into an online calculator and get a rough idea of when I could â€œretireâ€. After all, the principal is very simple. Mark your expenses on a graph. It should be a horizontal line with a slight upward slope to account for inflation. Plot your expected passive income each year. It should be a line with a steeper upward slope. Once those two lines intersect, congratulations, you are financially independent.

Figuring out your expenses is simple. Take your income. Subtract your savings. Whatever is left is your expenses.

How about your passive income? Thatâ€™s easy as well. Take your net worthâ€Šâ€”â€Šall money you have invested. Apply the 4% rule (I have yet to write about it. You can Google it for now. In short, you can consider 4% of your net worth as passive income for the year).Â Done.

Thatâ€™s all fine and dandy while you are living in your momâ€™s basement like I did. At some point though, you are likely to get your own place that comes with a mortgage and its own set of responsibilities. Thatâ€™s when things get tricky. The fundamental idea doesnâ€™t change. You still need to wait for the expenses curve to intersect with the passive income curve. The complexity is identifying those expenses.

While building Effai.me I had to think long and hard about it because I just bought my own house. I was trying to see what kind of an effect it would have on my Effai date. After combing through the interwebs and researching through the available literature, the answer wasâ€¦ it depends. It depends on what you want to do. Turns out, you have threeÂ choices.

Sell your house. Assuming the price of the house increases over time, you may find yourself at a point where selling your house could net you a big pile of money. That could significantly shorten your time to Effai. Once you sell it, the passive income you could generate would skyrocket.

How would you know if this is a good option for you? Itâ€™s a little more involved. You have to know severalÂ things.

  1. Your mortgageÂ payments
  2. Your home maintenance cost
  3. Your propertyÂ tax

The sum of the three above is your housing cost. In addition, youâ€™d need to know your new rental costs. Thatâ€™s just one moreÂ number.

  1. The cost to rent something equivalent.

When you sell, you bring your housing cost down to zero but introduce a new expenseâ€Šâ€”â€Šrental costs. The two expenses are likely in the same ballpark and mostly cancel each other out. Selling your house and renting is usually your fastest way toÂ Effai.

Of course, most people wouldnâ€™t dream of ever going back to renting. After all, theyâ€™ve â€œleft college years agoâ€. In that case, you are left with two otherÂ options.

Pay off your mortgage. In a way, this is a mirror image of selling your house. Instead of putting money to work for you, you decide to reduce your expenses. This strategy will eliminate your monthly mortgage payment (Yay!!). However, you are still left with the maintenance bill and the always increasing property taxÂ (Boo).

This could be a great strategy if you donâ€™t have much debt left on your mortgage. A simple rule of thumb isÂ this:

If the mortgage payoff amount cannot generate more passive income than your monthly mortgage payments, go ahead and pay off your mortgage.

Donâ€™t (or never) pay off your mortgage. You probably saw this one coming. If the rule above does not hold, this is for you. You are likely to find yourself in this situation if you bought the house recently and you still have a large amount of debt left. In that case, it may be cheaper for you to just keep your expenses as they areâ€Šâ€”â€Šmortgage payments includedâ€Šâ€”â€Šand have your money passively pay for those expenses. This is a temporary solution since at some point youâ€™ll have so little debt left you may want to pay it off. However, in the interest of retiring as early as possible this is definitely a possibility.

Youâ€™ll be glad to know that Effai.me runs all three of these scenarios for you. It is very biased towards retiring early. I hope the above made sense. Donâ€™t hesitate to reach out if you need some clarifications.

title: Why do we leave retirement to the end?
content:encoded:
I love spreading early retirement propaganda. It is honestly one of my favorite past time activities. On the surface, it is a very simple concept. Save a bunch of money. Keep going until you supplement your living expenses. Conversation over, right? Wrong. Turns out, thereâ€™s a lot more toÂ it.

I ended up having an interesting discussion recently with my colleagues Troy and Nina over beer (all good conversations involve beer). The question we deliberated wasÂ this:

Why do we leave retirement to theÂ end?

If youâ€™re in the traditional mindset of retiring at 65, this might seem like an odd question. How else would you have it? On the other hand, If youâ€™ve discovered the wonderful world of financial independence, itâ€™s a perfectly fair question. Why do we leave it to theÂ end?

The end can certainly be very long. You can stay retired for 60 years. But it still comes after continuous chunk ofÂ work.

So whatâ€™s the alternative? One option is to take 6 months off right now. Do your thing. Then come back and work someÂ more.

This actually has a great benefit. You get to discover what itâ€™s like to be financially independent without having to wait for years for your savings to accumulate. Itâ€™s like shopping at Costco without membership. Fantastic!

The first time I heard about this concept was back around 2011 when I read Tim Ferrissâ€™s 4 hour work week. In the book he talks about having mini retirements throughout your working life. I thought the idea was profound. It definitely changed the way I viewed retirement.

The 4-Hour Workweek: Escape 9-5, Live Anywhere, and Join the New Rich

Except thereâ€™s a problem. Lunches arenâ€™t free. In this case, itâ€™s your TTF (Time To Financial independence). If you are taking time off work to travel and â€œfind yourselfâ€, youâ€™re not earning any money. If youâ€™re doing it for 6 months, you just set yourself back by 6Â months.

It gets worse. Since you are unable to perform photosynthesis, you also end up spending money. Your TTF moves back by an additional number of months it would take you to save what youâ€™ve just spent. It can be summarized asÂ follows:

Your TTF moves forward by the amount you save and moves back by the amount youÂ earn.

You save less than 100% of what you earn. Hence, it will take you longer to make up the hole in your savings than the time you tookÂ off.

Thereâ€™s a second downside to the concept of mini-retirements. People seeking financial independence (effai seekers) tend to fall in one of two (or both)Â camps.

  • You are looking for freedomâ€Šâ€”â€Šexpressed as autonomy from the work schedules.
  • You are looking for securityâ€Šâ€”â€Šexpressed as autonomy from the businessÂ cycle.

Mini-retirements address the freedom part at the expense of securityÂ part.

Imagine youâ€™re a technology worker in 1999. You decide youâ€™re burned out. Youâ€™d like to take 6 months off and travel to Thailand. Great! except when you come back, thereâ€™s no job waiting for you. Itâ€™s likely you wonâ€™t have another one for a while. Once you do get one, itâ€™s going to be half theÂ salary.

None of this means you canâ€™t be financially independent but recessions and economic downturns are things most people want to avoid. One such way is financial independence.

Does this mean my professional opinion is that mini-retirements are a bad idea? Absolutely not.

You could mitigate the downsides by taking less time off. 3 months might suffice to find who you really are. The damage to your TTF is eased and your employer might even agree to keep your position open for you. Just be aware of the risks. I have been always too scared to take the timeÂ off.

title: A penny saved is a penny earned. Not really.
content:encoded:
Is there really a difference between spending less and earning more? Of course there is. In one scenario you get to drive a brand new SUV to work with shiny new rims and an obnoxiously loud exhaust pipe, and the other youâ€™re poâ€™. I donâ€™t think I need to explain which one is which. No one would disputeÂ this.

However ğŸ˜ƒ, there is one important assumption we made. The assumption is that being poâ€™ (thatâ€™s short for â€œpoorâ€ if someone is unclear) is bad and driving an SUV is good. In other words, we are talking about a basic, familiar consumer lifestyle. That is probably a fine assumption. Nonetheless, what if youâ€™re an effai seeker? Apparently itâ€™s all the rage with millennials. Youâ€™d have to reconsider those assumptions.

The reason for this is very simple. If you are seeking effai, your goal isnâ€™t to burn through as many resources as possible during your lifetime. Your goal is to get a minimum amount of resources you needâ€Šâ€”â€Šand as early as possible. Thatâ€™s quite a different form of consumption.

So what gets you there sooner? By being â€œpoorâ€ you end up spending lessÂ money.

Spending less money means you require less money to liveÂ on.

Requiring less money to live on means you can save it up faster. Thatâ€™s pretty simpleÂ math.

With this in mind, we can now return to the original question: Is a penny saved, as good as a penny earned? The answer to that is absolutely not. Itâ€™s farÂ better.

Letâ€™s take Hank and Lenny as an example (I have debated this with my friend Hank many times although I am somewhat misrepresenting his stance). For convenience, letâ€™s also assume they have roughly the same standard of living costing $60k annually (or $5k monthly). They also save the same $3k per month. At that rate, and with some reasonable assumptions, it would take them about 16 years to reach effai (you can check for yourself here). If they started at 20 and keeping life circumstances constant, theyâ€™d reach effai atÂ 36.

Turns out though, that Hank is also a very hard worker and got promoted recently. He also got a nice pay bump to go along with a fancier title and is now able to save an extra $1k a month. In other words, he is socking away $4k monthly instead of $3k. That brings his Time To eFfai (TTF ğŸ˜ƒ) down to 13.7 years from 16â€Šâ€”â€Ša savings of 2.3 years. NotÂ bad!

Lenny on the other hand is a cheapskate. Instead of making more money, Lenny decided to cut his expenses by $1k (Letâ€™s ignore the how for the sake of this article). What does that mean for Lenny? Since Lenny cut his expenses, he now lives on $4k a month instead of $5k. That puts effai 13 years away. Thatâ€™s an additional 0.7 years sooner thanÂ Hank.

Additionally, since Lenny cut his expenses, by $1k without changing anything else, he just freed up $1k to put towards savings. Lenny is now able to also save $4k per month just like Hank. This makes effai only 11 years awayâ€Šâ€”â€Ša full 5 years earlier then originally anticipated.

In short, each penny you save, from an effai view, actually has two roles. First, itâ€™s a penny you donâ€™t have to produce with your passive income anymore. Second, itâ€™s a penny you can redirect towards savingsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIncreasing significantly your savingsÂ rate.

So, no, a penny saved is not a penny earned, itâ€™sÂ two!

There is actually one other way to look at all of this. I find this to be far more impressive to think about than 11 years versus 13.7 years. Consider instead how much less money you actually need. For example, letâ€™s go back to Lenny. He went from spending $5k to $4k and increased his savings from $3k toÂ $4k.

Now take the 4% rule. Oh? Youâ€™re not familiar with it? I realize that I havenâ€™t written about it yet. Iâ€™ll summarize it super quickly for the sake of thisÂ article:

You can passively earn a dollar a month forever by intelligently investing $300.

Now take the 4% rule. By cutting $1k a month from what Lenny spends, Lenny does not need to intelligently invest $300k. In other words, Lenny just saved himself from savingÂ $300k.

This gets a tiny bit better actually. You should never think of your retirement number in todayâ€™s dollars. You always have to take inflation into account. The $300k we just saved for Lenny is in todayâ€™s dollars. Since Lenny is retiring in 11 yearsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand with an inflation rate of 2%, Lenny shaved off a whopping $373k off his retirement number. Cha-ching.

title: Why itâ€™s good to be rich
content:encoded:
A little while back my wife discovered a small lump on my catâ€™s stomach. We werenâ€™t sure what it was. So what do we do? We Google it of course. Now weâ€™re really scared. Itâ€™s the last thing you want to read about. It could be the big C. Based on my catâ€™s age, and the description online it is also somewhatÂ likely.

We go ahead and yelp the closest good vet in the neighborhood and schedule a prompt appointment for the next day. I took the kitty in and sat there anxiously as the vet inspected her carefully. Eventually she informed me she doesnâ€™t really know what it is exactly and weâ€™ll need to do a biopsy. Greatâ€¦Â :-s

One thing she did recommend is to do an x-ray to make sure that if it is cancer, it didnâ€™t spread to the lungs. If it did, there wasnâ€™t much to treat there. Also, she was missing a couple of shots that the city enforced by law. I obliged and we went ahead with the procedure and theÂ shots.

I sat through and waited patiently for the results to come back. Luckily, there was no sign of cancer in the lungs. A big relief to say the least. As I get ready to walk out Iâ€™m also reminded that I have to pay. They hand me a bill and ask me to go to the front desk and settle it. I open it to see the total damage. Itâ€™s well over $700. Thatâ€™s just for today. The biopsy estimate is anotherÂ $500.

Now donâ€™t get me wrong. Iâ€™ll gladly pay that and much more as long as my kitty is healthy. But not everyone is able to pay $1200 and keep the lights on. For some people, thatâ€™s a very significant amount of money. Some people may need to choose between paying the vet bill andÂ rent.

My first hint regarding the cost of treatment should have been all the posters advertising financing options. I remember looking at them and then chuckling in my mind about the absurd idea of financing bills in general. How irresponsible!

Before you start explaining to me the free market I just want to say this isnâ€™t some cry baby, socialist plea to nationalize veterinarian treatment. I picked the best vet in the area and agreed to all the pricing ahead of time. But there was one huge thing that dawned on me that day. Something that I never truly understood until thatÂ day.

The reason why money is great is not because of all the consumables you can obtain but because of the security it offersÂ you.

I swiped my credit card and walked out of that vet high as a kite thinking only about the fact that my cat didnâ€™t have cancer that metastasized. Thatâ€™s all I cared about. The $1200 I just paid will be paid off the next day and Iâ€™ll never worry about it again. Thatâ€™s a very privileged but little appreciated place to beÂ in.

I guess I understood this idea subconsciously. After all, the entire idea of being FI (financially independent) is financial security. You save enough money to be â€œemployer independentâ€. Itâ€™s something Iâ€™ve been working towards for nearly a decade. But never in my life did I understand how important it is until thatÂ day.

A lot of people concentrate on the idea of not working. At least not the traditional way for some big corporation in a soul sucking cubicle job. I admit that this idea is very attractive but itâ€™s the cherry at the top. The real benefit of FI is the security that comes with it. Itâ€™s the knowledge that no matter what, your bills will be taken careÂ of.

You are recession proof for life. You are interest rates, stock market, bond market, and job market independent. On top of it all, life tends to throw curve balls. Those curves could in many cases improve your state. It could be a raise, a move to a different city or country or a new more lucrative job offer. Occasionally it could also be a broken transmission. Either way, you got it covered and you can sleep at night just fine. Great feeling in myÂ mind.

title: Surprising unintended consequences of Airbnb hosting
content:encoded:
Weâ€™ve been hosting on Airbnb for a full week now. However, my perfectionist wife has been setting up the room for a month prior to that. The possibility of someone giving us a three star rating is just too much to bear. Thankfully, weâ€™ve been getting only five star ratings soÂ far.

To ensure the five star rating keeps coming, weâ€™ve had to go through each corner of the basement and clear it out, rearrange the furniture and fix any outstanding nagging maintenance issues. As a result, weâ€™ve taken several trunk-loads of stuff straight to Goodwillâ€Šâ€”â€Šmostly random junk that was packed away in the basement, forgotten about and collecting dust.

The basement was also the place where our TV lived. We do not have another one upstairs. It is also the place where I kept my clothes. My wife graciously allowed me to keep my stuff in the basement while she took over the bedroom closet. It incorporated my own private bathroom as well. Weâ€™ve never had to worry where to keep my shaving paraphernalia versus her hair products.

Since weâ€™ve started renting the basement, things had to change. Weâ€™ve shifted from having 1600 square feet to 900. My clothes moved upstairs. Weâ€™ve had to isolate a small corner in the closet for me. The bathrooms were unified (it is going through a clean up process as I am writing this). Thereâ€™s also no more television.

Essentially, weâ€™ve forced ourselves into adopting a certain level of minimalism.

Minimalism was never the intention when considering Airbnb. Instead, I was always thinking about our TTF (time to financial independence). Thatâ€™s because Airbnb is the classic example of passivish income (I made that up). Your existing asset (the house) is doing most of the heavy lifting. You just need to remember to pay the bills. The more you automate, the more passive itÂ becomes.

One glance around here and youâ€™ll know right away that I am a huge fan of minimalism and intentional living. Thatâ€™s why it came to me as a very unexpected yet pleasant surprise when I realized I am forced to downsize substantially.

Before you jump to conclusions, this is not some personality disorder or twisted reasoning. I am not actively trying to induce self-harm. This is a very conscious decision. Ponder this idea of happiness through subtraction for example to see where Iâ€™m coming from. If youâ€™re still not convinced, thatâ€™s fine. Iâ€™ll have a lot more to say about minimalism in theÂ future.

In the mean time, for anyone thinking about their TTF, you should know there are some unintended consequences to Airbnb that go well beyond the money; intentional minimalism happens to be one ofÂ them.

In other words, we are talking about a basic, familiar consumer lifestyle. That is probably a fine assumption. Nonetheless, what if youâ€™re an effai seeker? Apparently itâ€™s all the rage with millennials. Youâ€™d have to reconsider those assumptions.

The reason for this is very simple. If you are seeking effai, your goal isnâ€™t to burn through as many resources as possible during your lifetime. Your goal is to get a minimum amount of resources you needâ€Šâ€”â€Šand as early as possible. Thatâ€™s quite a different form of consumption.

So what gets you there sooner? By being â€œpoorâ€ you end up spending lessÂ money.

Spending less money means you require less money to liveÂ on.

Requiring less money to live on means you can save it up faster. Thatâ€™s pretty simpleÂ math.

With this in mind, we can now return to the original question: Is a penny saved, as good as a penny earned? The answer to that is absolutely not. Itâ€™s farÂ better.

Letâ€™s take Hank and Lenny as an example (I have debated this with my friend Hank many times although I am somewhat misrepresenting his stance). For convenience, letâ€™s also assume they have roughly the same standard of living costing $60k annually (or $5k monthly). They also save the same $3k per month. At that rate, and with some reasonable assumptions, it would take them about 16 years to reach effai (you can check for yourself here). If they started at 20 and keeping life circumstances constant, theyâ€™d reach effai atÂ 36.

Turns out though, that Hank is also a very hard worker and got promoted recently. He also got a nice pay bump to go along with a fancier title and is now able to save an extra $1k a month. In other words, he is socking away $4k monthly instead of $3k. That brings his Time To eFfai (TTF ğŸ˜ƒ) down to 13.7 years from 16â€Šâ€”â€Ša savings of 2.3 years. NotÂ bad!

Lenny on the other hand is a cheapskate. Instead of making more money, Lenny decided to cut his expenses by $1k (Letâ€™s ignore the how for the sake of this article). What does that mean for Lenny? Since Lenny cut his expenses, he now lives on $4k a month instead of $5k. That puts effai 13 years away. Thatâ€™s an additional 0.7 years sooner thanÂ Hank.

Additionally, since Lenny cut his expenses, by $1k without changing anything else, he just freed up $1k to put towards savings. Lenny is now able to also save $4k per month just like Hank. This makes effai only 11 years awayâ€Šâ€”â€Ša full 5 years earlier then originally anticipated.

In short, each penny you save, from an effai view, actually has two roles. First, itâ€™s a penny you donâ€™t have to produce with your passive income anymore. Second, itâ€™s a penny you can redirect towards savingsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIncreasing significantly your savingsÂ rate.

So, no, a penny saved is not a penny earned, itâ€™sÂ two!

There is actually one other way to look at all of this. I find this to be far more impressive to think about than 11 years versus 13.7 years. Consider instead how much less money you actually need. For example, letâ€™s go back to Lenny. He went from spending $5k to $4k and increased his savings from $3k toÂ $4k.

Now take the 4% rule. Oh? Youâ€™re not familiar with it? I realize that I havenâ€™t written about it yet. Iâ€™ll summarize it super quickly for the sake of thisÂ article:

You can passively earn a dollar a month forever by intelligently investing $300.

Now take the 4% rule. By cutting $1k a month from what Lenny spends, Lenny does not need to intelligently invest $300k. In other words, Lenny just saved himself from savingÂ $300k.

This gets a tiny bit better actually. You should never think of your retirement number in todayâ€™s dollars. You always have to take inflation into account. The $300k we just saved for Lenny is in todayâ€™s dollars. Since Lenny is retiring in 11 yearsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand with an inflation rate of 2%, Lenny shaved off a whopping $373k off his retirement number. Cha-ching.

A penny saved is a penny earned. Not really. was originally published in Effai.me on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: HSA: a friend on the road to financial freedom
content:encoded:
Minimizing your tax burden further through healthy living and flexible accounting

For this weekâ€™s post, I decided to step back from our discussions on happiness and talk about something actually importantâ€Šâ€”â€ŠsavingÂ money.

A few weeks back I wrote the wildly popular article â€œMost money you can earn without paying a dime in taxâ€. We talked about all the different programs Uncle Sam offers to reduce our tax bill at the end of the year. Thereâ€™s the traditional ones we hear about all the time like 401kâ€™s and IRA. Thereâ€™s a mention of a few less common ones as well. I encourage you to read it if you havenâ€™tÂ yet.

However, one of the most controversial options I mentioned was the Health Savings Accountâ€Šâ€”â€Šalso known as the HSA. Turns out, some people are not aware of all the super powers of the HSA and in turn ended up paying unnecessary taxes to the government. Thus; Iâ€™ve decided to break it down for you in a digestible way.

First, letâ€™s talk about what HSA is used for. HSA is a savings account (I bet you didnâ€™t see that coming) that allows you to save money for medical purposes. Each dollar that you set aside in an HSA is tax free. The money in the account can be invested in the stock market and grow tax free. Once you have a medical expense, the money can be withdrawn from the account, once again, tax free. You get the idea. One caveat is that HSA is only available for high deductible healthÂ plans.

Of course, the government cannot allow you to put every single penny you earn towards medical expenses. There is a limit of $3,450 per person or $6,900 for a couple per year. Thatâ€™s 2018Â numbers.

Hereâ€™s a quick example of how it would work. Assume your household income for 2018 is $100,000. If you were to max out your HSA for you and your spouse, the government would tax you on $93,100 instead of the entire $100,000. Thatâ€™s a free, ~$1500 you donâ€™t have to pay inÂ taxes!

Aside from federal income tax, thereâ€™s a few other taxes snuck into your pay stub. Two of them are social security and medicareâ€Šâ€”â€Šaffectionately known as FICA. Together they add up to 7.65% of your income. Turns out, unlike all other retirement accounts available to you, HSA is the only one that is exempt from paying FICA taxes too. Thatâ€™s another ~$500 in your deepÂ pockets.

Thatâ€™s just the beginning though. Once youâ€™ve set aside the money in your HSA, the most powerful force in the universe takes overâ€Šâ€”â€Šcompound interest. Thatâ€™s because each dollar youâ€™ve set aside can be invested and grow tax free. Naturally, as a FI (financial independence) pursuer, youâ€™d invest it in a diversified index fund of stocks*. Over time, the growth alone could dominate any further contributions.

Letâ€™s also address the elephant in the room. What do you do if you donâ€™t need to spend all this money on health care? What if youâ€™re healthy? Once again, youâ€™re in luck. Aside from being healthy, once you hit 65, all the money saved up in your HSA can be used for anything penalty free. You heard that right; anything. Taxation is also simple. It is treated like regular income. In essence, your HSA becomes a traditional IRA. One exception is if HSA is used for medical purposes. In that case, withdrawals are still taxÂ free.

This beast of Roth and Traditional IRA blended and fused together sounds like a great deal, doesnâ€™t it? Should you then go ahead and switch your health plan at work to a high deductible plan as soon as possible? Probably.

However, there is one notable exception. If you tend to have high medical bills throughout the year, it doesnâ€™t make much sense to switch to a higher deductible health plan. You could be better off forgoing the tax savings and letting the employer subsidize your health costsÂ instead.

Also, keep in mind that some generous employers contribute to your HSA as well. It does count against your overall limit but free money is freeÂ money.

Finally, thereâ€™s always going to be a subset of people who are terrified of exposing themselves to a little bit more risk through the high deductible health plan. I suggest that you read my article addressing insurance in general appropriately named â€œwhat to insureâ€. To summarize it in one sentence, Iâ€™d say, donâ€™t worry about it if you can affordÂ it.

*I need to write something an article, or more likely a series about stock investing for the FIÂ pursuer.

HSA: a friend on the road to financial freedom was originally published in Effai.me on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: The real reason economic progress hasnâ€™t lowered work hours more
content:encoded:
Assume for a moment that youâ€™re running a small business manufacturing pins and exporting it to the rest of the world. If you are working the standard North American schedule, it would translate to 40 hours a week or 8 hours a day. Now imagine that through some innovation on your part, you are now able to produce the same number of pins at half the time. To satisfy the same demand you can now work only 4 hours a day and enjoy an additional 4 hours of leisure. Straightforward math soÂ far.

Letâ€™s take this a step further. This time, youâ€™ve automated the process further and you can now produce the same number of pins at a quarter of the previous time. By the same math, now you can work an hour a day and enjoy 7 hours of additional leisure. This is essentially the reality for our productivity curve between 1950â€™s and today. We are far more productive today by every measure. However, the number of hours we work hasnâ€™tÂ budged.

The above was a prediction by a famous economist, John Maynard Keynes, in 1930. The video is a lecture by a professor in Economics trying to answer why this prediction did not materialize. The lecture is very insightful and brings up many interesting statistics about work, prosperity and well being broken down by gender, age and race. However, his main reason as to why the number of hours we work hasnâ€™t decreased despite much progress in productivity is our love for work andÂ money.

Although he presents good evidence to support his case, I believe there are a couple of other reasons we are working the same 40 hour weeks as we did in the 50â€™s that he overlooked. I would also argue that these reasons are equally important if not moreÂ so.

The system isnâ€™t conductive to less hours. Letâ€™s go back to our pin maker from before. If the pin maker decided to lay back and enjoy the additional 7 hours of leisure, what do you think would happen? All of her competitors would eventually figure out the same new, faster method of production and flood the market with pins since they can now produce moreâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach trying to wrestle away market share. In turn, that would push prices down and our (lazy) pin maker would quickly go out of business. This is the basis of capitalism.

We can thank our high standard of living to this phenomena. It brought us many innovations by aligning incentives and pushed billions of people out of poverty all around the world. It does this by rewarding work and innovation but penalizing complacency.

However, there are certainly few employers out there that have toyed with the idea of lowering work hours. For example, back in 2016, Amazon considered introducing a 30 hour work week for some of their employees.

If we have employers that are open to this idea, why donâ€™t the employees rise up and demand lower work hours? Do we love money this much? I think thereâ€™s another more subtle reason that is driving it beyondÂ greed.

Most people havenâ€™t discovered their purpose. If you ever needed to describe your purpose in life, could you? Not the purpose of life, thatâ€™s also beyond the scope of this article. Your purpose in life is what youâ€™d like to achieve or do. If you canâ€™t, thatâ€™s okay. Few peopleÂ can.

Once you free up those 7 hours of leisure time, you must have a way to fill them up with some leisure activities. If you donâ€™t have a purpose, itâ€™s hard to come up with things to do unless traveling the world for 40 years sounds like a good idea to you; and thereâ€™s certainly people who thinkÂ so.

Iâ€™ve encountered this a lot when I talk to people about financial independence (FI or effai ğŸ˜ƒ). The question of what I would do with all that free time immediately comes up. This question sometimes stems from curiosity and other times to ridicule the idea (read this article for my thoughts on this behaviour). Iâ€™ve spoken to countless people about FI but only a handful ever considered what they would do if they had moreÂ time.

Thatâ€™s why a job is usually the de facto source of purpose and the main occupier of time for most people. Once itâ€™s taken away, people may feel lost. Thatâ€™s also why early retirees seem to dieÂ earlier.

Of course, I wouldnâ€™t even be considering FI if I believed dying early was an inevitable fact and no amount of salad eating could save me. Nor would I ever recommend it to anyone else. I believe that anyone who is working towards FI the traditional wayâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat is, by saving hardâ€Šâ€”â€Šmust at some point consider their purpose. Otherwise they could not maintain the motivation to save so much for 15 plus years. Thatâ€™s a tiny minority of peopleÂ though.

Hence the result. Still working 100% of the time while creating 800% the product instead of working 1/8th of the time while producing 100% of theÂ product.

title: Most money you can earn without paying a dime in tax
content:encoded:
Every year, around February or March, I start dreading checking the mail. I dread it because itâ€™s that special time of the year. Itâ€™s the time you have to gather all those illegible slips you received from your employer and enter them in to some half baked software online. As you go through the process, the dollar amount you owe/receive will swing wildly making you break into a sweaty mess. All of this is coupled with a stack of indecipherable rules handed down to you from some government entity responsible for the tax collection.

The entire mess with all the pre-tax and post-tax deductions, itemization, credits, and exemptions makes it incomprehensible if all you want to do is â€œpay your fair shareâ€. Additionally, once a tax break is given, itâ€™s very hard to take it back. Thus; we end up with 80,000 pages of IRS lawyerÂ talk.

Wouldnâ€™t it be great if at least you could take advantage of all theseÂ rules?

Thatâ€™s why, Iâ€™m going to explore here the following question: What is the maximum amount you can earn without paying any federalÂ tax?

To keep this manageable, I will make a few assumptions. First, youâ€™re filing as a married couple. This is purely out of convenience for me since thatâ€™s how I file. If you are filing as a single person, most of the time you can just divide the number in half. Additionally, there is a pile of rules Iâ€™ll ignore for convenience. They either donâ€™t apply to the vast majority of people or are insignificant for the bottom line. Also, I will ignore Medicaid and Social security taxes. Finally, I will ignore any possible employer contributions or matches into your retirement accounts.

Letâ€™s start by defining a fewÂ terms.

Pre-tax (or traditional)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA type of deduction for which you donâ€™t have to pay taxÂ upfront.

Post-tax (or roth)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA type of deduction for which you do pay taxÂ upfront.

401(k)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA retirement plan sponsored by yourÂ employer

IRAâ€Šâ€”â€ŠA retirement plan that you pay for yourself.

Standard deductionâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAn amount every tax filer gets to deduct from their income to find their taxableÂ income.

Capital gainsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe tax applied on an investment

Everything beyond will assume a pre-tax or traditional deduction. Roth deductions are for suckers. We will explore thatÂ next.

Now that we got the jargon out of the way, letâ€™s see how we can apply it. We can start with the easiest. The standard deduction. It is $24,000 for a couple for the year 2018. If your family unit is bringing $24,000 per year, the standard deduction would bring your taxable income down to $0. In turn, your taxes would be $0. Fantastic.

Next, you can contribute to a traditional IRA. The limits for traditional IRAs is $5500 per person or $11,000 per couple. Remember that a traditional IRA is a pre-tax deduction. Thus; you can earn an additional $11,000 per couple and pay $0 tax. We are now up toÂ $35,000.

Similarly to IRA, you can also contribute to a traditional 401(k) program with your employer (if the employer is offering it). Each person has an IRS mandated limit of $18,500. Since youâ€™re filing as a couple that gives you a total of $37,000 to deduct. Adding it to the above gives us a total of $72,000 tax freeÂ dollars.

Thereâ€™s one more easy pre-tax deduction left. The health savings account (HSA). This is a great choice for individuals with low medical expenses. Some highly respectable online individuals even describe it as the ultimate savings account. For 2018, the limit for a couple is $6,900. Adding that in to our total gives us $78,900 tax freeÂ dollars.

In many cases, 401(k)â€™s and HSAâ€™s come with a few more advantages. First, many employers are willing to match at least a part of your contributions. That usually amounts to a few thousand tax free dollars. Additionally, if you are 50 or older, 401(k)â€™s allow you to sock away another $6000 per individual. Thatâ€™s another potential $12,000 to put away depending on yourÂ age.

Alright, we got all the obvious things out of the way. If you are not maximizing these, what are you waitingÂ for?

Now letâ€™s talk about the more esoteric options. First, thereâ€™s the 457(b). Thatâ€™s a special program for government workers. If you are a teacher or a nurse or some other government worker you can usually participate in this plan. 457(b) plan has an interesting feature. Unlike other employer sponsored retirement plans, this option has a separate limit. That means you can contribute to both 401(k) and 457(b). Both also have the same limits. Therefore; if a couple works for the government, thatâ€™s an additional $37,000 that can be deducted. That would give you $115,900 tax free dollars if my math isÂ correct.

Of course this is not the Soviet Union. We donâ€™t all work for the government. However, there is one other interesting way to reduce your taxes. If you went through my list of terms above, you may remember â€œcapital gainsâ€; the tax applied on investments. The great thing about this tax is that under certain conditions, when your investment â€œqualifiesâ€, this tax can be 0 percent. You heard that right. Youâ€™ll pay nothing. The requirements are also relatively moderate. The main requirement is that your investment must be held for at least aÂ year.

Once your investment is â€œqualifiedâ€, as long as you manage to keep your total taxable income to under $77,200, youâ€™ll actually owe nothing to the government. Taxable is bolded on purpose. Remember that through the power of IRAâ€™s, 401(k)â€™s and HSAâ€™s we were able to earn $78,900 tax free. Thatâ€™s because, for the purpose of taxation, youâ€™ve earned $0. Now, if you were to earn an additional $77,200 from capital gains, that would still be taxed at 0 percent due to capital gains taxes.Â Amazing!

So whatâ€™s the bottomÂ line?

As a couple with a decent job, you can earn $78,900 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

As a couple working for the state or federal government, you can earn $115,900 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

As a couple working for the government and amassing an impressive portfolio, you can earn an astonishing $193,100 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

As a couple above 50, working for the government and amassing an impressive portfolio, you can earn $205,100 and not pay a dime inÂ taxes.

Thereâ€™s a huge array of further deductions and credits you can look into to reduce your taxes further. If you prefer, you can think of it as increasing your taxable income while keeping your tax obligation at zero. For example, the child tax credit can give you up toÂ $2000.

However, most of us are not working for the government and do not have a portfolio that can generate $80,000 in capital gains year after year. Yet we can still reduce are taxable income by almost $79,000. To put that in perspective, the median income of a married household in 2016 was roughly $87,000; a little more then you canÂ deduct.

Iâ€™m a strong proponent of saving hard and saving fast. Thatâ€™s why, I encourage everyone to participate in any government money give away that is available to them within the legal boundaries. Retirement savings programs are â€œuse it or loseâ€ it programs. Make sure you useÂ it.

title: Elaborating more on Bitcoin value
content:encoded:
Friends have been asking me for weeks about what I thought of this promising new investment opportunity. I promised them a blog post was coming and delivered it. Since then, Iâ€™ve done some more reading about the concept and would like to clarify a fewÂ stances.

Before I do any clarification, I just want to say that I think the idea is actually very interesting. It is modeled after gold and assumes certain positions on the economy and prosperity. The libertarian in me definitely likes where this isÂ going.

One error that I made when reading about Bitcoin was the assumption that all transactions are completely anonymous. I was under the impression that you can transfer money between two consenting adults and the government cannot politely place their noses in your business and ask for a cut. However, thatâ€™s not theÂ case.

Either way, the idea of modeling it like gold is very intriguing. Every so often, when a conversation turns to money, someone looking to sound smart will state some sort of an opinion about how todayâ€™s money is â€œfiat currencyâ€ backed by nothing but thin air and promises. In the good old days, we had the gold standard so each dollar was worth something.

As the video above points out around the 50 second mark, the gold standard does not mean that money is backed by anything either. Gold is just a convenient way of figuring out who owns what and who owes who. It is like a ledger where we write down all the transactions.

Gold isnâ€™t valuable because we make jewellery out of it. Itâ€™s the other wayÂ around.

As it turns out, good forms of money (such as gold) have 5 properties.

  1. Scarcityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGold is pretty hard toÂ find
  2. Fungiabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAny gram of gold is equallyÂ valuable
  3. Divisibilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠYou can subdivide gold into smaller pieces to pay for cheaperÂ things.
  4. Durabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGold is a noble metal. Does not react under most extreme weather conditions.
  5. Transferabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠExchanging gold coins is reasonably easy and been done for thousands ofÂ years.

Bitcoin meets all of the criteria above and some would argue exceeds these criteria relatively to gold. Does it mean itâ€™s time to remortgage your house and go all in on Bitcoin mining like your Uber driver told you? Not quite. Thereâ€™s 4 big problems that I see with the current state of crypto-currencies.

Itâ€™s not an investment. The view that Bitcoin is an investment seems to be the most dangerous to me although itâ€™s a widely held belief. To be fair, itâ€™s hard to argue with results. If you held Bitcoin from 2010 to today youâ€™d be a Zillionaire. Naturally, the typical precautions apply. â€œPast performance do not guarantee future resultsâ€.

However, Iâ€™m mostly referring to the word â€œinvestmentâ€. I donâ€™t think it should be used in this case. The reason is that an investment implies some sort of return due to added value. For example, you invest in stocks because you get to own a company that presumably adds value over time. Added value leads to bigger profits. Bigger profits lead to dividends and as a share holder you have a claim on those dividends. Similarly, we invest in real estate because we count on the rental income. We provide the valuable service of shelter and to thank us, the renter hands usÂ dollars.

Where is the value being added when you store your dollars in the form of Bitcoin? Thereâ€™s none actually. Itâ€™s just a commodity like gold. You may argue that itâ€™s a store of value. You can make an argument that itâ€™s a hedge against inflation (assuming it ever stabilizes in price). But thereâ€™s definitely no added value there so itâ€™s not an investment.

And it isnâ€™t just semantics. Something that is not an investment but you still risk money on to make more money sounds a lot like a gamble. I think that if everyone treated it like a gamble, the results wouldnâ€™t be nearly as exciting. The pundits on TV would have to quiet down and the small talk at dinner will have to shift back to real estate (because thatâ€™s what we did before Bitcoin).

Investors have no clue how it works. We were having a social gathering the other day. Once we were done talking about Trump for the night, the conversation obviously shifted to Bitcoin. Two of my friends wanted to know what I thought of the idea and if they should invest in it. We started talking about some fundamentals of money and investing when it dawned on me; I was standing next to two world class software engineers neither of whom understood how crypto-currencies worked. Neither did I. However, they were ready to put down thousands of dollars into this â€œinvestmentâ€.

A week later I am chatting with another friend over coffee when he pulls out his phone to show me his portfolio. He has huge gains. Over 80% in just a month. Turns out he invested in 20 different crypto-currencies. However, when I asked him what percentage of the tech he understood, he admitted that it was roughly 0.5%. I appreciate the honesty but worried of the implications.

To be fair, this is anecdotal but I have a feeling itâ€™s much more wide spread than many realize. Personally, I would never dream of investing in a company without ever knowing at least what they do and looking at some financial ratios. However, in this case, at least in some limited examples, it seems like the default approach is to buy now and figure it outÂ later.

Itâ€™s actually not that useful. This reason is most up for debate but I think itâ€™s also going to be the most influential. For a currency to be of any use, it must be widely accepted. Bitcoin isnâ€™t quite there yet. Some would argue that itâ€™s just a matter of time until itâ€™s adopted. However, Iâ€™m wondering why? Why would anyone actually useÂ it?

I see one use case for me. I would like to be able to transfer money internationally without paying a middle man. Some people may like to buy guns and blow on the black market. Outside of that, Iâ€™m not really sure why it would be adopted. It makes moving money marginally better but adds a lot of barriers that need to be overcome.

What Iâ€™m really saying, is that beyond the hyper paranoid consumer and the mafia Don, thereâ€™s very little added value to Bitcoin as a currency. Therefore; I must wonder why it would gain any traction as a currency versus more established ones like the USD. Iâ€™m thinking about your average consumer. The ones that make up 95% of the population.

It can easily be competed out of business. So thereâ€™s Bitcoin. Thereâ€™s also Litecoin, Ethereum and Ripple. Three weeks ago, I introduced SuckerCoin. In fact, as of this writing, thereâ€™s thousands of different crypto-currencies you can trade. Crypto-currencies are built on public ideas and open source technologies. Thereâ€™s very little competitive advantage any one currency has that another cannot justÂ adopt.

Bitcoin does have the advantage that is the first and best known. However, that could easily be erased over time as others gain (or Bitcoin loses). One option companies use to maintain their competitive advantage is to lobby the government for regulations and licensing to keep competitors out. I have a hard time imagining the Bitcoin lobby passing that through congressÂ though.

The result is that anyone can start their own crypto-currency. Some of them have even real advantages. For example, Bitcoin has a limitation on how many transactions it can process in a 10 minute block. That is addressed in other currencies. Some currencies donâ€™t even bother with that. They just jump on the hype train. After all, a rising tied lifts allÂ boats.

If Bitcoin, or any other crypto-currency has any chance of staying around for the long term, it must be the currency that is accepted everywhere. But with thousands of currencies, how would anyone make the right choice? Of course, you could imagine a world where everyone accepts all crypto-currencies. However, in that case, the whole scarcity idea (property #1) becomesÂ â€¦ questionable.

Conclusion

I think that Bitcoin is a really cool idea. Getting central planning out of our money supply is a goal worth pursuing. Bitcoin should be thought of as version 1.0 of that idea. But just like all good software, we need to keep iterating overÂ it.

Block-chain (the general idea behind all crypto-currencies) is great. Iâ€™m sure it will be widely adopted. Maybe even for our own financial system. Maybe by our governments. Who knows? However, Iâ€™m going to stick to the tried and true. Iâ€™m keeping my money in a well diversified passively managed index fund and I recommend you do the same. More on thatÂ later.

title: What to insure
content:encoded:
This is highly inspired by an article from Mr. Money Mustache titled Insurance: A Tax on the stupid and I found it to be quite influential for my way of thinking about insurance. The premise of the article is simple. Insure only the things you cannot afford to lose. Pay up for the rest because in the long run youâ€™ll saveÂ money.

This makes perfect sense as well. Take any insurance company as an example. It exists for the sole purpose of making money. It does this by paying out less then it brings in. That means, the risk that itâ€™s covering must cost less in the long run then what it charges for it in premiums. I think no one would argue against thisÂ idea.

Humans have two major flaws when it comes to losses. The first is that we seem to feel twice the amount of pain for a loss then an equivalent gain. Putting this in dollars is the easiest way. Youâ€™d feel twice as much pain for losing $100 then the pleasure of gaining $100. This is completely irrational but thatâ€™s just the way the mind works. It is called loss aversion.

The second flaw is that we are really bad at estimating probabilities. Especially when these events are extremely unlikely. Thatâ€™s why we have irrational fears about dying in a plane crash but arenâ€™t worried what so ever about heart disease. Yet the former kills a tiny fraction of theÂ latter.

So given these two flaws of human behaviour, we can now see why insurance becomes a bad deal. An insurance company knows roughly how likely houses are to burn down or your electronics getting damaged. With a large enough pool of people, they can calculate the risk reasonably well and then distribute it over many premium payers. In fact, since we over estimate the likelihood and the pain of loss, they can charge us significantly more forÂ it.

The other issue I have with insurance is that people seem to insure absolutely everything of any moderate value. For example, people buy extended warranty on their TVâ€™s and phones. They buy extended coverage on their cars. They insurance their pets. Etc. So whatâ€™s theÂ problem?

The problem is that itâ€™s generally a big waste ofÂ money.

Not only are you making money for the insurance companies but also itâ€™s extremely silly to insure something you could afford to repurchase without thinking twice about it. If someone dents my car and I felt the need to fix it, I could pretty easily afford to do it and never think about it again. I wouldnâ€™t bother going to the insurance company forÂ it.

So the general rule of thumb is very simple. Buy insurance only if you cannot afford the replacement or the bills to fix it. For example, if my house burned down and I needed to rebuild it, I could not afford it. Thus; I insure my house. On the other hand, my deductible for my insurance is set to the maximum because I can afford to pay for it out ofÂ pocket.

And if you stop to think about the purpose of insurance, youâ€™ll realize that is there to cover you in case of a catastrophic events. It is not there to save you $20. Dropping your flat screen TV on the floor is not a catastrophic event so buying extended insurance is plain dumb. Unless of course it is in which case buying a flat screen TV is plainÂ dumb.

Thereâ€™s one other situation that you can justify buying insurance for. It is very specific and youâ€™re unlikely to run into but I feel I should mention it anyway. It is the time when you have some additional information that the insurance company doesnâ€™t that significantly increases your risk. For example, letâ€™s say youâ€™re extremely shitty driver but youâ€™re getting a great quote from GEICO. If you have a really good reason to believe that the insurance company is underestimating their risk significantly, go ahead and insure. But Thatâ€™s unlikely to be true and the gain is probably not very significant.

title: Escalator clowns
content:encoded:
One of my internet heroes, Mr. Money Mustache, wrote a very popular article back in 2013 titled â€œCuring your clown-like car habitâ€. Itâ€™s a great read and I highly recommend that you open it in a new tab and read it laterÂ :-) Fun fact, it is also the post that got me hooked on hisÂ blog.

Yesterday I think I managed to identify another set of clowns. I call them escalator clowns. Iâ€™m not going to claim that this term is invented by me. I imagine some people on the interwebs have used it before. However, I think we all know who Iâ€™m talkingÂ about.

Iâ€™m not claiming that anyone who ever takes the escalator is an escalator clown. Thereâ€™s plenty of good reasons to take the escalator. You can have bad knees for example. You may have a child with you who loves to ride the escalator. There might not even be an alternative such asÂ stairs.

However, if you eliminate all of the options from above and you still decide to take the escalator, youâ€™re not yet an escalator clown. To turn into an escalator clown, you have to take the escalator and then consciously just stand there. That my friend, makes you aÂ clown.

I just donâ€™t get it. Why would anyone just stand on an escalator? Escalators are slow. People looked bored. Thereâ€™s nothing pleasant about it. The only reason I can fathom is you must be conserving energy (because youâ€™re starving). Why else would you just stand there and wait? Also, you get two clown points if youâ€™re headingÂ down.

I ran into this phenomena on my way home from work. I was walking out of an office building and speeding my way towards the exit door when I walked past a lovely lady on the escalator. She turned her head and looked at me with a surprised look as I kept walking (and she was standing). To be honest, I donâ€™t know what was the cause of the surprise. It might have been my mere presence.

However, I know one thing for near certainty. She was leaving home from her office job. Office jobs tend to be sitting jobs. Her one solid opportunity to stretch those legs just opened up and she decided to squander it anyway. By no means is she the only one. I see this daily. And you probably do too. You canâ€™t tell me all these youngish people have bad knees. So hereâ€™s a life lesson forÂ you:

Donâ€™t be an escalator clown. Donâ€™t stand to the right. JustÂ walk.
