title: Self fulfilling prophecies
content:encoded:
Yesterday I hosted a bunch of my friends at my house and we ended up in a long discussion about having children, age and work. Nothing unusual so far and thatâ€™s more or less what youâ€™d expect people our age to talk about. It was a great night and it was nice to catch up with everyone. While talking specifically about children and inquiring about why anyone wanted them, one thing that was brought up very casually and without much resistance from the rest of the room was the idea that they will be there to teach you things. Sort of the way I do with my mom and you do with your mom andÂ dad.

Now, thereâ€™s absolutely nothing wrong with learning from your kids. If my kid ends up being a surgeon, I would love to get her opinion about all sorts of health related issues. After all, she has medical training and I donâ€™t. But despite their denial, that was not what my friends were trying to say at all. Instead, it was this underlying assumption that once you got old, youâ€™re just not expected to perform well. Both mentally and physically. And itâ€™s normal. If I was to challenge that idea, obviously theyâ€™d deny it but you could tell this was the assumption going into the conversation based on the context and where it wasÂ going.

Iâ€™m not going to pretend that once you hit 30, you are not less likely to make it to the NBA if you havenâ€™t yet. Thereâ€™s definitely diminishing physical abilities after a certain age (with very notable exceptions). But what bothers me is the lack of any sort of attempt to compensate for that. If youâ€™re worried about your physical performance as you hit 50, why not double your gym time instead of just throwing your hands up in the air and say â€œthatâ€™s just the way it isâ€. I guarantee you there are people double my age who can bench press twice my weight. They just have a different attitude.

Similarly, I think that people that expect less mentally from older people, will expect less from themselves when their older. In turn, their abilities to understand and learn will quickly diminish with age. On the other hand, thereâ€™s older people who are still brilliant and who are able to maintain their mental clarity until their last day. What makes them so different? I think to some extent itâ€™s their attitude.

Thatâ€™s exactly the kind of attitude I want to cultivate in myself. I donâ€™t think that when Iâ€™m 50 Iâ€™ll bench press less. I think Iâ€™ll bench press more. When Iâ€™m 50, I wonâ€™t be taking 10 pills a day. Iâ€™ll take none. Iâ€™ll feel great and Iâ€™m sure of it. I just need to make sure that I take care of myself now. This is the kind of attitude I would expect everyone toÂ have.

title: First intermittent fasting experience
content:encoded:
Thatâ€™s really a bit of a stretch and a click bait because this isnâ€™t really my first intermittent fasting (IF) experience. This is however, a description of my first 24 hour IF experience. And it was quite glorious I mustÂ admit.

For those that donâ€™t know, IF is pretty simple. You just donâ€™t eat. You do this on purpose and you do it for a short period of time. Pretty much what it sounds like. IFâ€™s can last from 12 hours to a week. Thereâ€™s no official time limits really. Also, they obviously include things likeÂ water.

Thereâ€™s plenty of evidence that IF is exceptionally healthy for you. For example, it seems to promote autophagy (which in itself sounds like a great thing). It also helps you lose weight. It can help you reverse type II diabetes. Finally, it can reduce inflammation in the body which is responsible for many chronic diseases such are heart disease and Alzheimerâ€™s.

Iâ€™ve read a lot of opinions about IF and many people recommend it as a regular practice. One such notable case is my internet hero, Dr. Jason Fung. However, Iâ€™ve never done a longer fast then 16 hours. The way I would usually do it is have my dinner by 8 pm and then skip breakfast and have lunch the next day at around 12 pm. That makes it exactly 16 hours.That was pretty much my daily routine for the last year orÂ so.

On Monday, Iâ€™ve decided to step it up a notch and see how I would feel if I went a full 24 hours. To do that, I had to skip one additional meal. Dinner had to go. I must admit that I was a little nervous at first. What if I get hungry? My brain would scream at me. I might even pass out from starvation (unlikely).

What really helped was that my wife was on board with this idea. In fact, like many of my great ideas, it was really her idea. And I wasnâ€™t going to let her down. So like the good partner that I am, I had a huge lunch that day and went cold turkey. So far nothing special. There are a few more hours to dinnerÂ time.

Unfortunately, my wife changed her mind and decided that IF on that day was just not for her. So she decided to cook dinner. The sunken cost fallacy really kicked into high gear here and I just couldnâ€™t give up. I went too far and wanted to try this so bad I figured I can manage without dinner. As a side note, I wasnâ€™t even hungry come dinner time. But you know how it is when you see other peopleÂ eat.

This was pretty much the hardest part of my experience. Iâ€™ve managed skip dinner while watching others eat. The rest was a total breeze. In the morning I had a black coffee and by lunch time I still wasnâ€™t hungry. In fact it was amazing. I havenâ€™t had a drop of food for 24 hours but my body wasnâ€™t falling apart. It was a wonderful experience actually.

Now, an entire week has almost passed and Iâ€™m thinking back to Monday, I realize that this could definitely become a new habit of mine. And why not? It seems to be good for you. It makes perfect sense from an evolutionary points of view. My internet heroes are claiming itâ€™s amazing. And itâ€™s damnÂ easy.

title: Worse than a cheat meal
content:encoded:
Something clicked today that I should have realized much earlier. Nothing groundbreaking and earth shattering like my usual rants but still an interesting realization. I was always under the impression that each time I cheated and had an â€œimproperâ€ meal, I was breaking my diet and forcing my body to restart the entire process of fat adaptation.

Subconsciously, each time I had a bowl of rice at a restaurant or some sort of dessert that a friend baked, I thought to myself that it will be another few days to get back on track. On top of it, I fully expected to see it reflected on the scale and by the very scientific pinchÂ test.

Nothing was further from reality. In fact, most of the time, I saw absolutely no change what so ever. Now, in hindsight, it is ridiculous to think that one bad meal or even one bad day could really cause any noticeable weight gain but there is also a slightly deeper insight. Thanks to Amy Berger I realized the difference between being fat adapted and being in ketosis. More importantly, I realized that just because you cheated, does not mean youâ€™re suddenly not fatÂ adapted.

Letâ€™s start with an example. if youâ€™re a typical SAD (standard American diet) consumer, eating tons of refined wheat flour, you are probably well tuned to convert glucose to energy. All the right enzymes are in place. This is your default mode and it seems to work okay for you. If you were to eat a meal high in fat but low in carbs at this point, youâ€™d probably feel pretty cranky. Of course thereâ€™s an exact parallel to being tuned to eating and using fat forÂ energy.

So what happens if you all of a sudden decide to cut the carbs from your high carb diet? Your body cannot get itâ€™s energy nearly as efficiently anymore and it freaks out. It needs time to develop and express the enzymes related to oxidizing fat for energy. That helps explain why some people experience the so called â€œcarb fluâ€ when first switching to a low carbÂ diet.

But my point is that this process is never an overnight event. It takes time to switch an adapt to a new form of energy. You are very likely to still be a fat burning machine the next day. Therefore; thereâ€™s worse things that you can do to your diet then once in a while having a bowl ofÂ rice.

title: Itâ€™s all about the sugar
content:encoded:
I guess I gave away the punch line for this blog post right from the title but the more I learn about this topic, the more I am convinced that all modern chronic disease is rooted in a single problem (generally). Itâ€™s our obsessive over consumption of sugar and refined carbohydrates.

Now, despite some resistance from the dark vegan armies, Iâ€™m pretty sure itâ€™s obvious that diabetes and over consumption of sugar is closely related. In fact, I would go as far as to say that itâ€™s a root cause of our exploding rate of type II diabetes. It makes perfect sense yet still remains controversial and unresolved.

Next we move on to heart disease. The number one killer in the world. That one I admit is a little more complicated but still I would implicate sugar as the cause. Studies in this space tend to be observational so there are no hard proofs but a lot of things seem to be aligning. For example, insulin resistance and heart disease are closelyÂ related.

Now for some stretch goals. First, thereâ€™s cancer. Iâ€™m going based of this video but seems damn convincing toÂ me.

If a cancer cell requires abnormal amounts of glucose and we donâ€™t provide it, it should starve. If we feed it, its growth should be promoted. Makes perfectÂ sense.

And finally thereâ€™s this whole discussion on Alzheimerâ€™s being type 3 diabetes. Which is again just an implication of sugar being the root cause. This is again pretty early on and light on true detailed studies but it makes sense considering you bought theÂ above.

So having said this, what do we have as a treatment option? Easy, stop eating sugar and cut down your carbohydrate consumption.

title: Sad reality of aging or something else?
content:encoded:
My mom has a friend named Kate. She is a wonderful woman in her 60â€™s. Unfortunately, she lost her husband to brain cancer a few years back. Since then sheâ€™s been living alone in a condo close by to my parents. They see each other quite often and have a great relationship.

I saw her the other day and wanted to use the opportunity to ask her some questions regarding diabetes. I wanted to ask her about the medication she takes and the difficulties she faces. To be honest, I also secretly wanted to let her know about Dr. Jason Fung and how he reverses diabetes (Heâ€™s one of my onlineÂ heroes).

To my surprise, when I brought up his treatment program, she cut me off and refused to listen. I was surprised (to put it mildly). â€œWhy would you not want to knowâ€ I asked her? He literally reverses diabetes in his patients. How could anyone refuseÂ that?

Her explanation was quite thought provoking. She told me that in all honesty, she doesnâ€™t know how long she has to live. She doesnâ€™t want to spend her last remaining years fasting, and worrying about everything she eats. She wants to be able to go out and have a good time. If she was 20 years younger and her husband was still around, things would probably be different.

Now, to be clear, I fundamentally disagree with her. I think she has it completely backwards. By taking care of her health, she could live her remaining days well and truly enjoy them. Also, most likely, sheâ€™ll have more of them toÂ enjoy.

But then I started wondering if she was right too. Was I only saying this because I am half her age. Would I be thinking this way when Iâ€™m 60 too? I sure hopeÂ not.

title: What kills
content:encoded:
I thought it was interesting to see what would kill me if I lived an average North American life. Google is my friend in that case so I googled top 10 causes of death in the U.S. My guess is Canada is looking somewhatÂ similar.

Also interesting to note that there are roughly 2.6 million deaths in the U.S. annually. Although an unfortunate number, itâ€™s a great boon for the morgue industry.

Here is what it looksÂ like:

  1. Heart disease: 633,842 ~Â 24%
  2. Cancer: 595,930 ~Â 22%
  3. Chronic lower respiratory diseases: 155,041 ~Â 6%
  4. Accidents: 146,571 ~Â 5%
  5. Stroke: 140,323 ~Â 5%
  6. Alzheimerâ€™s disease: 110,561 ~Â 4%
  7. Diabetes: 79,535 ~Â 3%
  8. Influenza and pneumonia: 57,062 ~Â 2%
  9. Kidney disease: 49,959 ~Â 2%
  10. Suicide: 44,193 ~Â 1.7%

The first thing to point out is of course how much more prevalent heart disease and cancer are. In my mind, since stroke is accumulation of plaque but in a different area, I lump it together with heartÂ disease.

Next, thereâ€™s diabetes and Alzheimerâ€™s which Iâ€™m convinced are rooted in hyperglycemia and insulin resistance. On top of that, a lot of diabetics will die from heart disease complications so I imagine it is already reflected inÂ (1).

I donâ€™t know what to make of respiratory diseases and influenza. I never heard of anyone having it personally and was surprised to find these so high up. I also donâ€™t know much about kidneyÂ disease.

Finally thereâ€™s accidents and suicide. Now accidents are unavoidable by definition but itâ€™s not really something Iâ€™m afraid of. Suicide is a more sensitive topic but suffice to say that it is 100% avoidable if you manage to not go through withÂ it.

And so it seems to me that if you can avoid modern age diseases (CVD, cancer, dementia, diabetes), avoid accidents and avoid committing suicide, you can live to be a nice, healthy old woman or man in 65% of theÂ cases.

title: Mortgage interest deduction lies
content:encoded:
As some of you know, to stimulate home ownership in the United States, the government created a scheme where by you get to deduct the interest portion of your mortgage payments from your income to reduce it for tax purposes. Effectively, this means that the interest is paid using pretax dollars. Great! letâ€™s all go buyÂ houses.

Not so fast. Take anyone with any sort of economic sense and they will tell you there is no free lunch here. Youâ€™re not getting stuff cheaper. By subsidizing the payments, the government simply pushed the prices of housing up for everyone. If you donâ€™t believe me, answer this question: What do you think would happen if this was taken away now? If you said people would freak out and the prices would fall because payments are higher then reverse this argument.

Alright, so we know governments generally canâ€™t get shit right and a lot of policies are misguided. Does that mean this one is also just a big fat waste of money? Thatâ€™s sort of what I thought. At least until yesterday. Yesterday, I watched thisÂ video:

There were a couple of interesting points of conversation there. One in particular that caught my attention though was regarding this exact topic and your level of taxation. You see, since every owner gets to take advantage of this particular piece of policy, they save at the same rate as their marginal tax rate. On the other hand, the amount that this house went up in price due to this particular policy is roughly equal to the overall average marginal tax rate in the UnitedÂ States.

So what does that mean? That means that if you are at a higher margin tax rate then the average population, youâ€™d save money based on this policy. If youâ€™re in a lower tax bracket, you lose. The only additional point Iâ€™d like to make is that it is probably the average margin tax rate of an average house buyer. The poorest citizens probably keepÂ renting.

So this entire policy is not only making housing more expensive for everyone, but it is oddly also a subsidy for the rich by theÂ poor.

Iâ€™m not talking about tax cuts here that are great for everyone but happen to benefit the rich more (due to their larger tax bill in the first place). This is literally a transfer from the poor to theÂ rich.

title: Being priced out
content:encoded:
If you ever lived in an area with a hot housing market, youâ€™ve probably had more dinners that youâ€™d like to admit where the conversation started and ended with how â€œcrazyâ€ it is out there. Anecdotal evidence about multiple bids on some broken down shitty houses with no pictures on RedFin and how many hundreds of thousands over asking the house down the street sold for dominate.

This in turn tends to drive the renters between us to go on a buying frenzy, desperately looking for a house, any house to buy. Because you knowâ€¦ if you donâ€™t buy today, youâ€™ll be priced out forever. I know Iâ€™ve heard that many times; including here inÂ Seattle.

The same people always bring up the same examples. Look at San Francisco they say. Seattle (or insert the city that you live in) is the next San Francisco. â€œIf I bought ten years ago I could have retiredÂ todayâ€.

So hereâ€™s my contrarian theory. Now this probably doesnâ€™t apply in all cases 100% of the time. But, ask yourselfÂ this:

Were you ever priced in to the city in the firstÂ place?

For example, San Francisco has always been more expensive then Seattle by about a factor of two. If you happened to be the age that you are now, working in San Francisco a decade ago, could you afford it then? Keep in mind that itâ€™s very unlikely your salary would be theÂ same.

Iâ€™m not just talking about inflation. Iâ€™m thinking more broadly like what industry youâ€™re in. Are you in tech or nursing? Youâ€™re probably making way more money then you could a decade ago. These jobs are simply in higher demandsÂ now.

So when your Grandpa reminds you how he bought this house for 60k, donâ€™t forget to ask him how much he was earning per hour. It could make a lot of difference. Now, if you couldnâ€™t buy it then and you canâ€™t buy it now does not mean you shouldnâ€™t strive for it. I am just suggesting that we should keep this in mind when complaining about the state of affordability and how Amazon â€œruinedâ€ everything.

title: Big houses
content:encoded:
A friend just revealed that he bought himself a new house. Due to local social norms, I pretended to be ecstatic and requested to see the house. He pulled out his phone and showed me some pictures. To my horror, this is a 4 bedroom 4 bathroom house for him and hisÂ wife.

Now, I know better than to question this decision. Especially after he already bought it. But thankfully he brought it up himself. He told me that the reason he needed such a large house is because occasionally his parents and his wifeâ€™s parents like to visit. Thatâ€™s definitely a nobleÂ reason.

On the other hand, thereâ€™s the other 49 weeks of the year when you live there just you and your wife. Even if you pop out twins in the next 9 months, you still have one extra bedroom. Of course most self respecting North American would then turn that into an â€œOfficeâ€. You know, like that room many households have that no one goesÂ into.

Great! Another wise financial decision. Now what about the maintenance? What about the taxes on the property? What about the bills? What about not being able to find your wife because your house is too big? Why is it such a desirable status ofÂ success?

Not so fast. Take anyone with any sort of economic sense and they will tell you there is no free lunch here. Youâ€™re not getting stuff cheaper. By subsidizing the payments, the government simply pushed the prices of housing up for everyone. If you donâ€™t believe me, answer this question: What do you think would happen if this was taken away now? If you said people would freak out and the prices would fall because payments are higher then reverse this argument.

Alright, so we know governments generally canâ€™t get shit right and a lot of policies are misguided. Does that mean this one is also just a big fat waste of money? Thatâ€™s sort of what I thought. At least until yesterday. Yesterday, I watched thisÂ video:

There were a couple of interesting points of conversation there. One in particular that caught my attention though was regarding this exact topic and your level of taxation. You see, since every owner gets to take advantage of this particular piece of policy, they save at the same rate as their marginal tax rate. On the other hand, the amount that this house went up in price due to this particular policy is roughly equal to the overall average marginal tax rate in the UnitedÂ States.

So what does that mean? That means that if you are at a higher margin tax rate then the average population, youâ€™d save money based on this policy. If youâ€™re in a lower tax bracket, you lose. The only additional point Iâ€™d like to make is that it is probably the average margin tax rate of an average house buyer. The poorest citizens probably keepÂ renting.

So this entire policy is not only making housing more expensive for everyone, but it is oddly also a subsidy for the rich by theÂ poor.

Iâ€™m not talking about tax cuts here that are great for everyone but happen to benefit the rich more (due to their larger tax bill in the first place). This is literally a transfer from the poor to theÂ rich.

title: How flushing the toilet made me appreciate the little things in life
content:encoded:
Important lesson obtained from a surprising place

The Universe has proven once againâ€Šâ€”â€Šthere is no shortage of life lessons in the most unexpected places. For me, it all started a three weeks back. Up until that point, I thought very little about my toilet (as I should). My most memorable recollection was installing a soft close cover on it so it wouldnâ€™t bang when I put the seat down. Otherwise, it was just like every other toiletâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhite, round and a great place to browse yourÂ phone.

So what lessons could I possibly learn from this familiar household item? Allow me to offer the following allegory.

As many of you know, I dabble in a some house hacking. I rent out my basement on Airbnb to random people on the internet. On Sunday I got the following lovely message from my guests: â€œthe toilet isnâ€™t flushingâ€. Thankfully, there was nothing in there I couldnâ€™t handle. I headed downstairs, pulled out the plunger and started plunging vigorously. I plunged for about an hour. I tried all sorts of techniques. I put hot water in there. I put soap in there. I ended up with a bowl full of hot soapy bubbles. Eventually, I had to admit that I needed professional help.

I called the first plumber I could find on Google. He showed up within a few hours looking ready to unclog some pipes. He started with the auger (long wire you stuff in the toilet). He stuck it in there, rotated it a bunch of times but no luck. He removed the toilet off the floor and tried again. Still no luck. All I could think was â€œWhat the hell did those hippies flush down my toilet?â€.

He mentioned weâ€™re going to need some more heavy duty equipment. Keep in mind that I have Airbnb guests in my house with a dysfunctional toilet. They are not going to be very happy. On top of it, I live in an old house. Our pipes areâ€¦ questionable. How much is this going to cost me? I am now quiteÂ nervous.

We brought down a 400 pound roll of metallic tubing. He stuck it in the pipe and started unwinding it in. He kept going all the way to the end. When he pulled it out, we found an extension cord wrapped around the metallicÂ tubing.

As we both stood there scratching our heads wondering how this is even possible, my wife was still thinking straight. She Googled it quickly and identified it as a part of our sewage pump. Turns out if your toilet is below the sewage line, you need a pump to get the waste out (makes sense once you think about it). The plumber must have ripped off the cord while digging forÂ clogs.

He put the toilet back in place; Charged me $350; told me I need to get a qualified professional andÂ bounced.

I started to frantically call anyone who could possibly help. I needed this done ASAP. We have paying customers in the house who need toÂ â€¦ use the facilities. The best I could do is get a guy to show up in two days. The estimate for a replacement wasÂ $1600.

I donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve ever dealt with plumbers, electricians or any general maintenance workers but they arenâ€™t exactly known for being reliable.

That night, I couldnâ€™t sleep. I was worried the plumber wouldnâ€™t show; replacing the pump wouldnâ€™t fix the issue; or that it would escalate to more problems. I woke up the next day with a big headacheâ€Šâ€”â€Šexhausted and stressed.

On a whim, I decided to call the initial company and complain about the plumber; maybe theyâ€™ll offer me a discount. I dialed their number, and politely explained what happened. Instead of a discount, they offered to fix the pump for free. Another plumber showed up later in the day, replaced the pump within an hour and charged me nothing for labour and material.

Once he finished, I rushed downstairs and started flushing that toilet over and over. Flushing never felt so good. The next night, I slept like a baby. I donâ€™t remember the last time I slept that well. I woke up refreshed, feeling great, ready to take on theÂ world.

What really inspired this story is how vividly I remember the difference in those two days. When the toilet was broken and everything seemed like an endless series of disasters, life was hardâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI was stressed and miserable. Dealing with this shit (pun intended) was not fun. Once the toilet service was restored, my life was turned upside down. I felt free. I felt good. I felt like anything was possible. In short life was glorious again. What a difference 24 hours can do for your wellÂ being.

More importantly, I recognized how much we take for granted. As long as this toilet was working, I never paid attention to it. I pulled the lever down. The water flushed away all my troubles. Life went on. However, once this process failed, my outlook changed. All of a sudden my house wasnâ€™t this impenetrable castle but a money pit. And running that Airbnb wasnâ€™t a license to print money but just a bunch ofÂ hassles.

Granted, I did not feel like that for long. Once everything was fixed and settled, I was more than happy to take my guestsâ€™ money for the right to stay in my basement (I did offer a free night for the trouble). Also, I ended up getting a brand new sewage pump installed for a bargainÂ price.

Upon reflection, I had to ask myself the following question:

What can I do to experience life like I did on Monday, everyday?

In other words, how can I wake up feeling refreshed and energized, all worries alleviated and the anxiety extinguished. Turns out my experience that week is a common phenomena encountered regularly. In fact, we even have an aphorism to explain what happened:

â€œYou donâ€™t know what you have until itâ€™sÂ goneâ€

Duh. Everyone knows that. But what can we do aboutÂ it?

One thing I could do is sabotage my plumbing on regular basis and deal with the plumber while my Airbnb guests are watching. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a scalable solution though so I wouldnâ€™t recommend it.

Another option is to practice what is usually referred to as â€œgratitude journalingâ€. Sonja Lyubomirsky talks extensively about this technique in her book, â€œThe how of happinessâ€.

The How of Happiness: A New Approach to Getting the Life You Want

It entails taking two minutes out of your day (or week) to write down 3 things youâ€™re thankful for. It can be anything. It can be as mundane as catching the bus on time or as significant as getting promoted at work or as pivotal as getting engaged. The key to this exercise is to regularly consider all the things youâ€™re thankful for and consciously become a more gratefulÂ person.

Iâ€™ve known about this method for years. Yet somehow, this spiritual, new age approach never resonated with me. I would imagine people sitting in a circle, humming, holding their energy crystals with one hand and writing in their journals made of recycled fabrics with theÂ other.

If the above doesnâ€™t appeal to you, feel free to drop all the spiritual moonshine and concentrate on the psychological benefits. The root act is simple. Think about what youâ€™re thankful for; be grateful, write it down. Repeat tomorrow.

title: If actions reflect values, what do they say about you?
content:encoded:
The mental math that goes into making decisions and how I tilt the odds in myÂ favour

My company just wrapped up a week of festivities. Hashtags were flying around with snazzy slogans celebrating unity and harmony, identity and integrity and all sorts of other hippy war cries. We got to talk about the companyâ€™s future direction and gossip about internal politics.

Once each day came to a close, we headed to the restaurants to eat the finest Pad Thai San Francisco had to offer. We all had a daily allowance and Iâ€™ll be damned if I didnâ€™t use it! On the last day, we had a giant party with unlimited tequila shots and a fish tacoÂ stand.

That night, I downed my fifth fluid ounce of tequila and headed straight for my friend Colin who was in the midst of a deep conversation with Nina and Zack. I donâ€™t know what they were talking about, but I overheard the following phrase

Your actions reflect yourÂ values

Cool, I thought. Heard that one before. Nothing new. Iâ€™ll take that beerÂ now.

Once the party was over, I stumbled my way to the hotel and passedÂ out.

The next day I woke up at 10am with a pounding headache. I was incapacitated to my room for the next 9 hours while my liver was hard at work. The only positive outcome of that experience was the opportunity to reflect on myÂ actions.

I am the guy who preaches the gospel of low sugar diets to anyone who will dare to listen. I spend copious amounts of time roaming the internet for information about insulin, cholesterol, and inflammation. I also managed to poison my own body using exclusively the sheer power of my ownÂ will.

I am the guy who regularly writes about happiness, minimalism and intentional living. I worked hard on my 2017 resolutions to use my time wisely. I found plenty of time to browse nonsense on the internet throughout that week. I did not however find time to call myÂ mother.

If the statement above is trueâ€Šâ€”â€Šif actions dictate your valuesâ€Šâ€”â€Šmy values areâ€¦ off. They are certainly not what I expected them toÂ be.

I am glad Colin brought up that phrase. Thanks to him, I had a mini-epiphany while nursing my hangover.

Up to last week, my values dictated my actionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šup to a point. Occasionally, I would give myself a break from being goodÂ â€¦ and be bad. I would drink a little too much. I would browse YouTube a little too long. I would get into an argument on Twitter a little tooÂ fast.

The new me prefaces these â€œundesirableâ€ behaviours with the following question:

Does this action reflect myÂ values?

Does drinking a pint of beer reflect my values? Nope. Maybe Iâ€™ll think again before ordering a second round. Better yet, I can go for a tall glass of kombuchaÂ instead.

This approach can work for anyone. TryÂ this:

Next time youâ€™re about to open Netflix, play another round of Candy Crush or skip the gym because you are sore from the brisk walk yesterday, ask yourself this: does this action reflect myÂ values?

title: Proposal: dropping in on people is not the worst thing ever
content:encoded:
The forgotten ancient art of keeping friendships flourishing

Whenever one of our friends is hosting a gathering or a party in their house, I am always amazed by how organized and clean their house is. Everything is attentively dusted and meticulously arranged. The sink is empty of all dishes. The oven is pre-heating that delicious pot roast. And of course, thereâ€™s figs and pistachios neatly laid out in beautiful bowls on the dining table to tie us over until dinner isÂ served.

In turn, when we invite those friends over, thereâ€™s a certain level of underlying obligation to live up to those expectations. If our friends had figs and pistachios, we must have cranberries and walnuts ready for them. If they had a perfectly arranged kitchen cabinet, we must do the same. We certainly cannot afford to wear our comfortable home clothesâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe must dressÂ up.

Of course, this friendly race to outdo each other does not come for free. It actually takes a heavy toll on us. We cannot simply allow to have people over. We must clear up our entire day to do all the cleaning and cooking and shopping and planning. Itâ€™s exhausting. Hosting people turned from being a pleasurable bonding activity to a major inconvenience. We end up thinking twice before invitingÂ anyone.

Hereâ€™s what I propose (technically itâ€™s my wifeâ€™s idea. Giving credit where itâ€™s due): I propose that we stop putting up these facades to hide behind. We all know that everyoneâ€™s houses are a mess when no one is looking. We all know that your fridge isnâ€™t always stocked full of goodies just ready to eat. And you know what? Thatâ€™sÂ okay.

This idea makes most millennial aged individuals very nervous for twoÂ reasons.

  1. It will expose things that no one knows about them expect their spouse. However, we donâ€™t have to make it extreme. Take for example the 30 minute warning approach: If youâ€™ll be in the neighborhood, call your potential host 30 minutes ahead of your arrival. That gives them just enough time to pick up their socks off the floor and close the bedroomÂ door.
  2. As a guest, you also tend to feel awkward about dropping in suddenly. What if they are busy? What if they donâ€™t want to see me? What ifÂ â€¦.? I think this reluctance stems from years of being accustomed to all these obligations when you are hosting. In turn, when other people are hosting, you donâ€™t want to impose. These feelings are perfectly reasonable but we must break out of the cycle ofÂ doubt.

Implementing this approach in our day to day lives is easy. All we have to do is tell each other that itâ€™s okay. Itâ€™s okay to just dropÂ by.

Naturally, when adopting this, there are three caveats I mustÂ mention:

  • Make sure your host is homeÂ (duh).
  • Make sure your host is free. If they are busy, donâ€™t assume itâ€™s an attack on your character. They just have things toÂ do.
  • Know your limits. The idea is not to spend your entire Saturday at someoneâ€™s house.

The idea is inspired by observing my own parents and their huge circle of friends. They constantly seem to have people over but they are never particularly stressed out about it. Itâ€™s not uncommon to have 3 different sets of people show up throughout the day. They are usually served a cup of tea and whatever they can find available in theÂ fridge.

This is sort of how I imagine people living in those small European towns in Greece where everyone is old and happy and all they do is socialize. I want to be old and happyÂ too!

title: How I build the right set of habits
content:encoded:
In my first post, I wrote about the two parts of happiness: fulfillment and achievement. It is clear that earning fulfillment along the way is as important as reaching to the end goal. A friend asked me a very important question: how do we enjoy every moment while still having a sense of a future goal? I think of it thisÂ way:

Completion of a big goal = SUM(small dailyÂ action)

For example, my goal to write a book is far-fetch and has always been postponed. Writing one page every week (for 3 years) actually seems more achievable! The only way to get myself to write repeatedly is to build the habit aroundÂ it.

Deliberately buildingÂ habits

My favorite book Power of Habit suggests that any habit consists of 3Â parts.

First, there is a cue, a trigger that tells your brain to go into automatic mode and which habit to use. Then there is the routine, which can be physical or mental or emotional. Finally, there is a reward, which helps your brain figure out if this particular loop is worth remembering for the future. Over time, this loopâ€¦ becomes more and more automatic.

Defining the cue is crucial. What worked best for me is to select a specific time, location, and vibe all together as a cue. I pick my favorite instrumental music, and sit on the couch on Sunday morning to get my brain engaged. I do my writing routine. Then I publish it to get the readersâ€™ feedback as a reward. It gets easier over time as the habit isÂ formed.

Majority of the time, I forget about the overarching goal and mostly enjoy doing my routine. The right set of habits can maximize your sense of fulfillment while still keeping you on track for the long term achievement.

Replacing badÂ habits

Now that we know what is the good habits to keep or create, itâ€™s time to get rid of the not-so-good habits. The best way is to replace theÂ routine.

Keeping the same cue and reward; substituting theÂ routine.

Say I want to stop checking social media first thing in the morning. First, I must identify the cue and the reward. I know the cue is the sound of the alarm clock, and the reward is the feeling of being awake afterwards. I choose to replace social media with reading (since it contributes to my long term goal). I delete the social media apps and replace them with reading apps. It feel a bit different at first, but overtime, the brain gets the same reward and it adjusts to the change. This strategy works all the time as long as you understand your cue andÂ reward.

Identifying a good habit and deliberately replacing the bad ones is a continuous process. Overtime, I come to a set of habits that I doÂ daily.

Realize enemy ofÂ habits

Life canâ€™t be all planned. Many times, the unplanned events must override the schedule and break your flow. It can even break the yearly habit in a day. Spontaneous habit changes must happen to match the circumstances. This is perhaps the most difficult part about operating life on a set ofÂ habits.

The best way to cope with change is to be self-aware, constantly reflecting upon the self and understanding our ownÂ desire.

Being self-aware also helps with reinforcing the habit consciously when the cues or rewards are missing. Itâ€™s a fallback mechanism to maintain a long lastingÂ habit.

Super Habit

Like any other goal, self-awareness can be practiced and strengthened. I found the habit of meditation to contribute highly to self-awareness. The mind is just like the body. It needs to be well-maintained and exercised.

Meditation gives the mind a chance to reorganize all the information. It is also a practice to de-focus on the past and future, and re-focus on what happens in the present. With higher consciousness, the mind is sharpened to understand and deal with uncertainty in lifeÂ better.

I would denote meditation as my super habit because it keeps all other habits together. (I will write more about thisÂ later!)

Summary

I believe that the better the plan, the easier the execution. The journey to complete your big goal must be thought through. Building good set of habits and maintain them is the fastest way to getÂ there.

title: Surprising unintended consequences of Airbnb hosting
content:encoded:
Weâ€™ve been hosting on Airbnb for a full week now. However, my perfectionist wife has been setting up the room for a month prior to that. The possibility of someone giving us a three star rating is just too much to bear. Thankfully, weâ€™ve been getting only five star ratings soÂ far.

To ensure the five star rating keeps coming, weâ€™ve had to go through each corner of the basement and clear it out, rearrange the furniture and fix any outstanding nagging maintenance issues. As a result, weâ€™ve taken several trunk-loads of stuff straight to Goodwillâ€Šâ€”â€Šmostly random junk that was packed away in the basement, forgotten about and collecting dust.

The basement was also the place where our TV lived. We do not have another one upstairs. It is also the place where I kept my clothes. My wife graciously allowed me to keep my stuff in the basement while she took over the bedroom closet. It incorporated my own private bathroom as well. Weâ€™ve never had to worry where to keep my shaving paraphernalia versus her hair products.

Since weâ€™ve started renting the basement, things had to change. Weâ€™ve shifted from having 1600 square feet to 900. My clothes moved upstairs. Weâ€™ve had to isolate a small corner in the closet for me. The bathrooms were unified (it is going through a clean up process as I am writing this). Thereâ€™s also no more television.

Essentially, weâ€™ve forced ourselves into adopting a certain level of minimalism.

Minimalism was never the intention when considering Airbnb. Instead, I was always thinking about our TTF (time to financial independence). Thatâ€™s because Airbnb is the classic example of passivish income (I made that up). Your existing asset (the house) is doing most of the heavy lifting. You just need to remember to pay the bills. The more you automate, the more passive itÂ becomes.

One glance around here and youâ€™ll know right away that I am a huge fan of minimalism and intentional living. Thatâ€™s why it came to me as a very unexpected yet pleasant surprise when I realized I am forced to downsize substantially.

Before you jump to conclusions, this is not some personality disorder or twisted reasoning. I am not actively trying to induce self-harm. This is a very conscious decision. Ponder this idea of happiness through subtraction for example to see where Iâ€™m coming from. If youâ€™re still not convinced, thatâ€™s fine. Iâ€™ll have a lot more to say about minimalism in theÂ future.

In the mean time, for anyone thinking about their TTF, you should know there are some unintended consequences to Airbnb that go well beyond the money; intentional minimalism happens to be one ofÂ them.

title: My state of the art system to goal setting
content:encoded:
I have yet to meet a person who was perfectly content with exactly who they were. Everyone is always trying to change something about themselves. The typical things includes the food they eat, the amount of exercise they get, how they spend their time and how they prioritize their lives. Turns out, change is harder than reading a blogÂ online.

People are also creatures of habit. We all have our morning routines, our night routines, our commute to work routine and the web sites we visit on our lunch break routine. In fact, when we are put in new environments where executing our routines is hard, we generally tend to skip workouts and eat fried chicken forÂ dinner.

I am going to share with you an approach that I use to form better habits. It is not fool proof. It does require some upfront investment. However, I believe it could work for almost any habit you are trying to form as long as you apply enough creativity. The system is very simple to apply. All you have to do is create a system. Yes, you read that right, the system is to create systems. Let meÂ explain.

When I say â€œsystemâ€, Iâ€™m talking about a set of rules, or guidelines you use to guide your choices. The side effect of those rules should be that you execute your desired habit. Think of these rules as formalizing a contract with yourself. The contract has at least one rule: I can have as much [A] as I want. However, before I get [A], I must do [B]. This is what I call a personal contract.

The inspiration came from Dr. BJ Fogg, a researcher in behaviour design who had a great TED talk a few years back about this exactÂ topic.

If you use an existing behaviour in your life, and you put the new, tiny behaviour after it, you can use the existing behaviour to be theÂ trigger.

Nonetheless, over time, I noticed that simply defining the contract wasnâ€™t always enough. Frequently, I couldnâ€™t uphold the contract for long or I would completely forget about it. In fact, it was really a hit or missâ€Šâ€”â€Šoccasionally it would work really well but periodically it would completely fallÂ apart.

More recently, I took a look at some personal contracts I was able to maintain for a long stretch and tried to boil it down to what made them different. I have identified four hallmarks of a good personal contract.

Automatic. If you can set this up for your desired habit, your job is practically done. For example, before I spend any money, I max out my 401k. I can automate this through my paycheque contributions. Done!

Unfortunately, itâ€™s not easy to automate certain areas of your life. Exercising effectively requires you to be doing exercise. Calling your mom once a week requires you to talk (at least forÂ now).

However, thereâ€™s a clear subset of bad habits that can be automated away. Anything digital will naturally fall here. Do you have bad browsing behaviour? Are you spending too much time on your Twitter/Facebook/YouTubeÂ ? Thereâ€™s an app for that. Are you having trouble saving or budgeting? Thereâ€™s a bank forÂ that.

The advantage of automating bad habits away is you only have that upfront cost once but you reap the dividends indefinitely.

Breaks down barriers. One habit that I recently found to be absolutely effortless is the habit of eating a healthy lunch. In the past, Iâ€™ve tried cooking at home or buying out healthy lunches but inevitably you skip cooking for a few nights and end up ordering a large barbacoa burrito at Chipotle. You do it enough times and getting back to cooking regularly becomes more and more unlikely.

How many barriers can you identify with my past system? First, cooking at home is a pain in the ass. Second, when buying food outside, there are far too many temptations. Third, even if I manage to convince myself to buy a salad, in the back of my mind Iâ€™m always thinking itâ€™s a bad a deal because Iâ€™ll stay hungry after thatÂ salad.

Here is my new approach: my current employer provides catered lunches every day. I made a personal contract with myself to eat a giant bowl of salad from the salad bar first. Once Iâ€™m finished with the bowl, I can have absolutely anything I want. There are no limits. This contract addresses all barriers Iâ€™ve had for eating a healthy lunch. I donâ€™t have to cook anything; I am not tempted by anything else since choices are limited; and I am not getting a bad deal because I can have anything I want afterwards. I just need to get through that bowl of salad first. As an added bonus, thereâ€™s very little I can eat once Iâ€™m done with the salad. I tend to be much more ambitious whenÂ hungry.

In general, try and identify all the little excuses you are giving yourself to stop doing what you really want to be doing. Once identified, try to design your life in a way that will break down those excuses in the most effortless way possible.

Other barriers usually include, distance, accessibility and ease of use. Watch out forÂ these.

Sets the correct incentive. You know how we said before you get [A] you must do [B]? Make sure that whatever [A] is, it is motivating enough to act as a trigger. If you remember reading my commitments for 2018, youâ€™ll recall that one of my commitments was to drink two cups of coffee a day. Unfortunately, Iâ€™ve noticed that as time goes on, I am creeping back to three cups. Each time I have it, I feel a little guilty but I reason that starting tomorrow Iâ€™ll be better. Instead of feeling guilt, I can turn this around and use it to my advantage.

I am a member of a gym located in the same building where I work. I am making the following personal contract: each time I feel like having a third cup of coffee, I must first hit the gym. The barriers to work out are exceedingly low and now I also have a great incentive to do the right thing (the fact that I made it public is aÂ bonus).

You can generalize this approach as well. Essentially, you sacrifice one minor bad habit to enforce and carry out a major good habit by setting up the right incentives for yourself.

Consistent with the individual. Sometimes, despite all the automation, best intentions, lowest barriers, and most enticing incentives, you still fail at your habit building; and thatâ€™sÂ okay.

Coming up with these systems is an iterative process. You will always be tinkering with them. Always trying something new. Always looking for a better way of doing things. Youâ€™ll never get it just right the very firstÂ time.

The key is to keep trying new ways of doing things and experimenting with what works for you. For example, a cup of coffee might be enough to motivate me to go to the gym. You might want a new pair of sneakers instead. If thatâ€™s your barrier, donâ€™t bother with my system. It wonâ€™t work forÂ you.

When I come up with great systems that work for me, I am always very proud and happy to shareâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust wait until I write my post about budgeting.

Let me know if you have a system you are particularly proud of. I am always looking to tweak mine and share withÂ others.

title: This is where I see myself in five years
content:encoded:
Actually, I canâ€™t see thatÂ far.

A couple of weeks ago I was having lunch with my friends Zack and Nina. I canâ€™t remember exactly what we were discussing but it must have been something interesting. It usually is. Suddenly, Zack asks me the following question:

Where do you see yourself in fiveÂ years?

I havenâ€™t been to an interview in a long time so I was caught off guard. I didnâ€™t have a good enough, well rehearsed and politically correct answer to give. Then again, I wasnâ€™t being actually interviewed for a job so I told him the honest truth. The truth is, I think that planning five years ahead is pointless if not counterproductive. I am sure that every lifestyle/productivity guru on the internet is having a meltdown right now. However, let meÂ explain.

Presumably, setting a long term goal means the outcome is important to you. It is probably something that will make you happy and make you feel like a more accomplished person. Or will it? Weâ€™ve talked about this before. What you think will make you happy doesnâ€™t always make you happy. You just may end up on the hamster wheel chasing the nextÂ goal.

More importantly, the goals that you set for yourself today might not even be applicable five years from now. Let me give you a concrete example. Iâ€™ll steal this one from Nina because it works out perfectly. She mentioned that one of her friends has five year goal to open up her own brewery. That sounds really fun right? However, how sure is this friend that brewing beer is what she really wants to do? Five years from now, her priorities could change completely. Has she spent enough time brewing beer for herself? Is she sure that running her own business is something that sheÂ wants?

Another mistake a lot of people make when setting their long term goals is making goals that are outside of their control. For example, you can set a goal for yourself to get married. Is that a good goal? I donâ€™t think so. Yes, one way to hand over more control to yourself is to lower your expectations but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s what you had in mind when committing to this five yearsÂ earlier.

So far Iâ€™ve just been warming up. Sure, all of the above is true, but the real reason five year goals are pointless is much simpler. The unpredictability of life makes it so. For example, five years ago I was happily living in Canada when all of a sudden I got an opportunity to work at a much fancier company for much fancier pay. All my five year plans had to be abandoned (if I had any). Two days ago my wife came back from Portugal and is convinced life is better over there. Whatâ€™s my five year planÂ now?

I can hear all the detractors from my couch grumbling under their breath about how I just donâ€™t understand the goal setting process. It doesnâ€™t have to be this specific or set in stone. Thatâ€™s true! However, how generic are you thinking? The reality is that once you make it somewhat generic, everyone wants roughly the same. Everyone wants to be healthier, stronger, better looking with a devoted spouse and a killer job. So what? How are you getting there? The devil is in theÂ details.

I am not here just to be a complainypants. I also like to propose solutions. So here it goes: Do whatever you do to set your five year goal but set it for only one year ahead. Do this every year. At the end of the year, reevaluate and readjust. A year is generally enough to set substantial but achievable goals. At the same time, when things changeâ€Šâ€”â€Šeither your surrounding or your opinionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou have plenty of opportunity to reevaluate what you value and where youâ€™reÂ heading.

You can experiment with shorter periods of time as well, however, I suspect that if you do this too frequently, you wonâ€™t be giving yourself enough time to complete the goal. At the same time, youâ€™ll be giving yourself a lot of opportunities to quit. One year seems like a good balance between some level of accountability and flexibility.

The key to make this recurring one year goal work is the reevaluation part of the process. Each year, you must check back on the goals you set for yourself in the beginning of year and evaluate your performance. Furthermore, reevaluate if you want to continue with this goal. Finally, and most importantly, step up the difficulty level of theÂ goal.

I think of this as â€œmanaged personal growthâ€. Open source portfolio of 2018 should be better in every way than Open source portfolio of 2017. If not, Open source portfolio wasted 2017. The only way I would know this is if I was accountable to myÂ goals.

Hereâ€™s my self grading forÂ 2017

Hereâ€™s my goals forÂ 2018

A nice and unexpected benefit from this system is that in 2022 Iâ€™ll get to see my 2017 goals and have a good laugh at how little I expected ofÂ myself.

title: Happiness: appealing to the like system
content:encoded:
Happiness: ask, and you shallÂ receive

Actionable items you can do today to engage your likeÂ system

This is part II of my discussion of â€œHappiness: the science behind your smileâ€. If you havenâ€™t read part I, I encourage you to do so here. Everything will make a lot more sense if youÂ do.

For those that have fully embraced the smartphone age and lack patience, hereâ€™s a quickÂ summary:

Turns out what we want is frequently separate from what we like. The things we desire in life do not always bring us happiness. This makes perfect sense from an evolutionary perspective. Evolution does not care about your happiness. Its only objective is to propagate your genes. Therefore; your ancestors were rewarded when competing for status and acquiring resources. However, to be happy, you cannot simply chase your desires. Those desires must also bring you long term contentment. You can do this only if you engage both the â€œwant systemâ€ and the â€œlikeÂ systemâ€.

Now that youâ€™re up to speed, letâ€™s digÂ in.

Shortly after publishing the first article about the two systems, my friend Zack asked me a really interesting question.

Whatâ€™s an actionable item I can do today to determine what will appeal to my â€œwantâ€ and â€œlikeâ€Â system?

Iâ€™ll be honest, I had to think long and hard about this one. My gut reaction was to write a piece bashing materialism and status seeking but I feel like itâ€™s not very satisfying. Itâ€™s hard to convince anyone that driving a brand new Tesla SUV to work on daily basis will not bring them more happiness in life. Also, as my wife frequently reminds me, â€œnot everyone wants to live like aÂ monkâ€.

Consequently, I had to step back and reconsider. What else can you do to engage the â€œlikeÂ systemâ€?

Weâ€™ve already established that people are terrible at predicting how much happiness their desires will bring them. We tend to overestimate the pleasure we will gain from positive experiences. Similarly we tend to overestimate the pain we will experience from negative experiences. However, I am aware of at least one method that seems to be somewhat more reliable than our own intuition. All you have to do is find someone who is at the same position you would like to be and ask them how theyÂ feel.

This might not be the bombshell you were expecting. However, the consequence of this idea is easy to overlook.

Consider for instance what you could do if you were buying a new house. You and your spouse might be looking for a 4 bedroom house at a near by suburb in a brand new development. It must have a 2 car garage and a ton of yard space to play ball with your future child. You will use the extra rooms as an office and an extra bedroom whenever your parents visit from out of town. Sure, it will increase your commute and the mortgage payments are a little high, but itâ€™s worthÂ it!

Sounds familiar? Thatâ€™s because it is exactly what a typical couple doesâ€Šâ€”â€Šat least around this part ofÂ town.

Before signing on the dotted line, and committing to 30 years of debt, you could ask a current home owner, roughly at the same stage of life, roughly with the same house, living in a similar neighborhood, what their day to day looks like. Do they have any regrets? Do they miss renting? How do they feel about Home Depot? What would they change if they could do it overÂ again?

They may tell you that itâ€™s incredible. Itâ€™s everything and more than they hoped for. They love entertaining friends on their brand new deck and all the neighbors are extremely friendly and pleasant. Itâ€™s the best decision they could have everÂ made.

Another possibility is that the commute is tough and stressful and the mortgage payments are stretching their finances further than they are comfortable. Maintaining it is also a dailyÂ grind.

Whatever the outcome, it is valuable information you didnâ€™t have before. According to Dan Gilbert, their response will also be a much better predictor of your future feelings than your own intuition.

Now letâ€™s take it a step further. What if you didnâ€™t just settle for asking people that are a single step ahead of you. What if you also asked people who are multiple steps ahead of you. For example, if your parents own their home, why not ask them? You could even use the same questions.

They may tell you it was a great investment and all their retirement savings are in the house. They were able to raise 2.6 children in that house and send them to the best public schools the department of education had toÂ offer.

Similarly, they could tell you they never once in 20 years walked into that office/bedroom without a feather duster and windex in their hands. They regret not buying a smaller house and using the extra money toÂ travel.

Again, valuable information but this time from a long term perspective.

Finally, you can take this advice to itâ€™s logical conclusion. I hesitate to write this because it is a morbid way to think. However, the insight is absolutely invaluable. I am talking about an article appropriately titled regrets of the dying. It took me a long time to read this partially because I couldnâ€™t get over how morbid it is. However, I highly encourage everyone to give it a chance. Once I got through it, I realized that the fear of regret is a very powerful reason to live right. It was also indirectly responsible for this article (and many others toÂ come).

The regrets are of course very emotional and human. I think that all of us can predict at least half of them if we just sat down and tried to list them. Yet there is something powerfully contemplative even as I re-readÂ them.

One regret I think would resonate with everyone is #4â€Šâ€”â€ŠI wish I had stayed in touch with my friends. This is something that could haunt you your entire life unless you devote a lot of concentrated effort to maintain these relationships. One major reason for this is our endless mobility. It is certainly a great opportunity to meet wonderful people. However, the relationships you form tend to be more shallow. Once â€œbusynessâ€ catches up with you, those are the first toÂ go.

This is a focus area for myself although I will make it more official in my 2019 resolutions.

So what would these people tell you about your house choices if you somehow managed to ask them? I cannot speak for them authoritatively, but my guess is theyâ€™d tell you to live your life and stop wasting your time on this shit because it really doesnâ€™tÂ matter.

title: The real reason economic progress hasnâ€™t lowered work hours more
content:encoded:
Assume for a moment that youâ€™re running a small business manufacturing pins and exporting it to the rest of the world. If you are working the standard North American schedule, it would translate to 40 hours a week or 8 hours a day. Now imagine that through some innovation on your part, you are now able to produce the same number of pins at half the time. To satisfy the same demand you can now work only 4 hours a day and enjoy an additional 4 hours of leisure. Straightforward math soÂ far.

Letâ€™s take this a step further. This time, youâ€™ve automated the process further and you can now produce the same number of pins at a quarter of the previous time. By the same math, now you can work an hour a day and enjoy 7 hours of additional leisure. This is essentially the reality for our productivity curve between 1950â€™s and today. We are far more productive today by every measure. However, the number of hours we work hasnâ€™tÂ budged.

The above was a prediction by a famous economist, John Maynard Keynes, in 1930. The video is a lecture by a professor in Economics trying to answer why this prediction did not materialize. The lecture is very insightful and brings up many interesting statistics about work, prosperity and well being broken down by gender, age and race. However, his main reason as to why the number of hours we work hasnâ€™t decreased despite much progress in productivity is our love for work andÂ money.

Although he presents good evidence to support his case, I believe there are a couple of other reasons we are working the same 40 hour weeks as we did in the 50â€™s that he overlooked. I would also argue that these reasons are equally important if not moreÂ so.

The system isnâ€™t conductive to less hours. Letâ€™s go back to our pin maker from before. If the pin maker decided to lay back and enjoy the additional 7 hours of leisure, what do you think would happen? All of her competitors would eventually figure out the same new, faster method of production and flood the market with pins since they can now produce moreâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach trying to wrestle away market share. In turn, that would push prices down and our (lazy) pin maker would quickly go out of business. This is the basis of capitalism.

We can thank our high standard of living to this phenomena. It brought us many innovations by aligning incentives and pushed billions of people out of poverty all around the world. It does this by rewarding work and innovation but penalizing complacency.

However, there are certainly few employers out there that have toyed with the idea of lowering work hours. For example, back in 2016, Amazon considered introducing a 30 hour work week for some of their employees.

If we have employers that are open to this idea, why donâ€™t the employees rise up and demand lower work hours? Do we love money this much? I think thereâ€™s another more subtle reason that is driving it beyondÂ greed.

Most people havenâ€™t discovered their purpose. If you ever needed to describe your purpose in life, could you? Not the purpose of life, thatâ€™s also beyond the scope of this article. Your purpose in life is what youâ€™d like to achieve or do. If you canâ€™t, thatâ€™s okay. Few peopleÂ can.

Once you free up those 7 hours of leisure time, you must have a way to fill them up with some leisure activities. If you donâ€™t have a purpose, itâ€™s hard to come up with things to do unless traveling the world for 40 years sounds like a good idea to you; and thereâ€™s certainly people who thinkÂ so.

Iâ€™ve encountered this a lot when I talk to people about financial independence (FI or effai ğŸ˜ƒ). The question of what I would do with all that free time immediately comes up. This question sometimes stems from curiosity and other times to ridicule the idea (read this article for my thoughts on this behaviour). Iâ€™ve spoken to countless people about FI but only a handful ever considered what they would do if they had moreÂ time.

Thatâ€™s why a job is usually the de facto source of purpose and the main occupier of time for most people. Once itâ€™s taken away, people may feel lost. Thatâ€™s also why early retirees seem to dieÂ earlier.

Of course, I wouldnâ€™t even be considering FI if I believed dying early was an inevitable fact and no amount of salad eating could save me. Nor would I ever recommend it to anyone else. I believe that anyone who is working towards FI the traditional wayâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat is, by saving hardâ€Šâ€”â€Šmust at some point consider their purpose. Otherwise they could not maintain the motivation to save so much for 15 plus years. Thatâ€™s a tiny minority of peopleÂ though.

Hence the result. Still working 100% of the time while creating 800% the product instead of working 1/8th of the time while producing 100% of theÂ product.

title: How flushing the toilet made me appreciate the little things in life
content:encoded:
Important lesson obtained from a surprising place

The Universe has proven once againâ€Šâ€”â€Šthere is no shortage of life lessons in the most unexpected places. For me, it all started a three weeks back. Up until that point, I thought very little about my toilet (as I should). My most memorable recollection was installing a soft close cover on it so it wouldnâ€™t bang when I put the seat down. Otherwise, it was just like every other toiletâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhite, round and a great place to browse yourÂ phone.

So what lessons could I possibly learn from this familiar household item? Allow me to offer the following allegory.

As many of you know, I dabble in a some house hacking. I rent out my basement on Airbnb to random people on the internet. On Sunday I got the following lovely message from my guests: â€œthe toilet isnâ€™t flushingâ€. Thankfully, there was nothing in there I couldnâ€™t handle. I headed downstairs, pulled out the plunger and started plunging vigorously. I plunged for about an hour. I tried all sorts of techniques. I put hot water in there. I put soap in there. I ended up with a bowl full of hot soapy bubbles. Eventually, I had to admit that I needed professional help.

I called the first plumber I could find on Google. He showed up within a few hours looking ready to unclog some pipes. He started with the auger (long wire you stuff in the toilet). He stuck it in there, rotated it a bunch of times but no luck. He removed the toilet off the floor and tried again. Still no luck. All I could think was â€œWhat the hell did those hippies flush down my toilet?â€.

He mentioned weâ€™re going to need some more heavy duty equipment. Keep in mind that I have Airbnb guests in my house with a dysfunctional toilet. They are not going to be very happy. On top of it, I live in an old house. Our pipes areâ€¦ questionable. How much is this going to cost me? I am now quiteÂ nervous.

We brought down a 400 pound roll of metallic tubing. He stuck it in the pipe and started unwinding it in. He kept going all the way to the end. When he pulled it out, we found an extension cord wrapped around the metallicÂ tubing.

As we both stood there scratching our heads wondering how this is even possible, my wife was still thinking straight. She Googled it quickly and identified it as a part of our sewage pump. Turns out if your toilet is below the sewage line, you need a pump to get the waste out (makes sense once you think about it). The plumber must have ripped off the cord while digging forÂ clogs.

He put the toilet back in place; Charged me $350; told me I need to get a qualified professional andÂ bounced.

I started to frantically call anyone who could possibly help. I needed this done ASAP. We have paying customers in the house who need toÂ â€¦ use the facilities. The best I could do is get a guy to show up in two days. The estimate for a replacement wasÂ $1600.

I donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve ever dealt with plumbers, electricians or any general maintenance workers but they arenâ€™t exactly known for being reliable.

That night, I couldnâ€™t sleep. I was worried the plumber wouldnâ€™t show; replacing the pump wouldnâ€™t fix the issue; or that it would escalate to more problems. I woke up the next day with a big headacheâ€Šâ€”â€Šexhausted and stressed.

On a whim, I decided to call the initial company and complain about the plumber; maybe theyâ€™ll offer me a discount. I dialed their number, and politely explained what happened. Instead of a discount, they offered to fix the pump for free. Another plumber showed up later in the day, replaced the pump within an hour and charged me nothing for labour and material.

Once he finished, I rushed downstairs and started flushing that toilet over and over. Flushing never felt so good. The next night, I slept like a baby. I donâ€™t remember the last time I slept that well. I woke up refreshed, feeling great, ready to take on theÂ world.

What really inspired this story is how vividly I remember the difference in those two days. When the toilet was broken and everything seemed like an endless series of disasters, life was hardâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI was stressed and miserable. Dealing with this shit (pun intended) was not fun. Once the toilet service was restored, my life was turned upside down. I felt free. I felt good. I felt like anything was possible. In short life was glorious again. What a difference 24 hours can do for your wellÂ being.

More importantly, I recognized how much we take for granted. As long as this toilet was working, I never paid attention to it. I pulled the lever down. The water flushed away all my troubles. Life went on. However, once this process failed, my outlook changed. All of a sudden my house wasnâ€™t this impenetrable castle but a money pit. And running that Airbnb wasnâ€™t a license to print money but just a bunch ofÂ hassles.

Granted, I did not feel like that for long. Once everything was fixed and settled, I was more than happy to take my guestsâ€™ money for the right to stay in my basement (I did offer a free night for the trouble). Also, I ended up getting a brand new sewage pump installed for a bargainÂ price.

Upon reflection, I had to ask myself the following question:

What can I do to experience life like I did on Monday, everyday?

In other words, how can I wake up feeling refreshed and energized, all worries alleviated and the anxiety extinguished. Turns out my experience that week is a common phenomena encountered regularly. In fact, we even have an aphorism to explain what happened:

â€œYou donâ€™t know what you have until itâ€™sÂ goneâ€

Duh. Everyone knows that. But what can we do aboutÂ it?

One thing I could do is sabotage my plumbing on regular basis and deal with the plumber while my Airbnb guests are watching. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a scalable solution though so I wouldnâ€™t recommend it.

Another option is to practice what is usually referred to as â€œgratitude journalingâ€. Sonja Lyubomirsky talks extensively about this technique in her book, â€œThe how of happinessâ€.

The How of Happiness: A New Approach to Getting the Life You Want

It entails taking two minutes out of your day (or week) to write down 3 things youâ€™re thankful for. It can be anything. It can be as mundane as catching the bus on time or as significant as getting promoted at work or as pivotal as getting engaged. The key to this exercise is to regularly consider all the things youâ€™re thankful for and consciously become a more gratefulÂ person.

Iâ€™ve known about this method for years. Yet somehow, this spiritual, new age approach never resonated with me. I would imagine people sitting in a circle, humming, holding their energy crystals with one hand and writing in their journals made of recycled fabrics with theÂ other.

If the above doesnâ€™t appeal to you, feel free to drop all the spiritual moonshine and concentrate on the psychological benefits. The root act is simple. Think about what youâ€™re thankful for; be grateful, write it down. Repeat tomorrow.

title: If actions reflect values, what do they say about you?
content:encoded:
The mental math that goes into making decisions and how I tilt the odds in myÂ favour

My company just wrapped up a week of festivities. Hashtags were flying around with snazzy slogans celebrating unity and harmony, identity and integrity and all sorts of other hippy war cries. We got to talk about the companyâ€™s future direction and gossip about internal politics.

Once each day came to a close, we headed to the restaurants to eat the finest Pad Thai San Francisco had to offer. We all had a daily allowance and Iâ€™ll be damned if I didnâ€™t use it! On the last day, we had a giant party with unlimited tequila shots and a fish tacoÂ stand.

That night, I downed my fifth fluid ounce of tequila and headed straight for my friend Colin who was in the midst of a deep conversation with Nina and Zack. I donâ€™t know what they were talking about, but I overheard the following phrase

Your actions reflect yourÂ values

Cool, I thought. Heard that one before. Nothing new. Iâ€™ll take that beerÂ now.

Once the party was over, I stumbled my way to the hotel and passedÂ out.

The next day I woke up at 10am with a pounding headache. I was incapacitated to my room for the next 9 hours while my liver was hard at work. The only positive outcome of that experience was the opportunity to reflect on myÂ actions.

I am the guy who preaches the gospel of low sugar diets to anyone who will dare to listen. I spend copious amounts of time roaming the internet for information about insulin, cholesterol, and inflammation. I also managed to poison my own body using exclusively the sheer power of my ownÂ will.

I am the guy who regularly writes about happiness, minimalism and intentional living. I worked hard on my 2017 resolutions to use my time wisely. I found plenty of time to browse nonsense on the internet throughout that week. I did not however find time to call myÂ mother.

If the statement above is trueâ€Šâ€”â€Šif actions dictate your valuesâ€Šâ€”â€Šmy values areâ€¦ off. They are certainly not what I expected them toÂ be.

I am glad Colin brought up that phrase. Thanks to him, I had a mini-epiphany while nursing my hangover.

Up to last week, my values dictated my actionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šup to a point. Occasionally, I would give myself a break from being goodÂ â€¦ and be bad. I would drink a little too much. I would browse YouTube a little too long. I would get into an argument on Twitter a little tooÂ fast.

The new me prefaces these â€œundesirableâ€ behaviours with the following question:

Does this action reflect myÂ values?

Does drinking a pint of beer reflect my values? Nope. Maybe Iâ€™ll think again before ordering a second round. Better yet, I can go for a tall glass of kombuchaÂ instead.

This approach can work for anyone. TryÂ this:

Next time youâ€™re about to open Netflix, play another round of Candy Crush or skip the gym because you are sore from the brisk walk yesterday, ask yourself this: does this action reflect myÂ values?

  • 2018 resolutions

title: Proposal: dropping in on people is not the worst thing ever
content:encoded:
The forgotten ancient art of keeping friendships flourishing

Whenever one of our friends is hosting a gathering or a party in their house, I am always amazed by how organized and clean their house is. Everything is attentively dusted and meticulously arranged. The sink is empty of all dishes. The oven is pre-heating that delicious pot roast. And of course, thereâ€™s figs and pistachios neatly laid out in beautiful bowls on the dining table to tie us over until dinner isÂ served.

In turn, when we invite those friends over, thereâ€™s a certain level of underlying obligation to live up to those expectations. If our friends had figs and pistachios, we must have cranberries and walnuts ready for them. If they had a perfectly arranged kitchen cabinet, we must do the same. We certainly cannot afford to wear our comfortable home clothesâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe must dressÂ up.

Of course, this friendly race to outdo each other does not come for free. It actually takes a heavy toll on us. We cannot simply allow to have people over. We must clear up our entire day to do all the cleaning and cooking and shopping and planning. Itâ€™s exhausting. Hosting people turned from being a pleasurable bonding activity to a major inconvenience. We end up thinking twice before invitingÂ anyone.

Hereâ€™s what I propose (technically itâ€™s my wifeâ€™s idea. Giving credit where itâ€™s due): I propose that we stop putting up these facades to hide behind. We all know that everyoneâ€™s houses are a mess when no one is looking. We all know that your fridge isnâ€™t always stocked full of goodies just ready to eat. And you know what? Thatâ€™sÂ okay.

This idea makes most millennial aged individuals very nervous for twoÂ reasons.

  1. It will expose things that no one knows about them expect their spouse. However, we donâ€™t have to make it extreme. Take for example the 30 minute warning approach: If youâ€™ll be in the neighborhood, call your potential host 30 minutes ahead of your arrival. That gives them just enough time to pick up their socks off the floor and close the bedroomÂ door.
  2. As a guest, you also tend to feel awkward about dropping in suddenly. What if they are busy? What if they donâ€™t want to see me? What ifÂ â€¦.? I think this reluctance stems from years of being accustomed to all these obligations when you are hosting. In turn, when other people are hosting, you donâ€™t want to impose. These feelings are perfectly reasonable but we must break out of the cycle ofÂ doubt.

Implementing this approach in our day to day lives is easy. All we have to do is tell each other that itâ€™s okay. Itâ€™s okay to just dropÂ by.

Naturally, when adopting this, there are three caveats I mustÂ mention:

  • Make sure your host is homeÂ (duh).
  • Make sure your host is free. If they are busy, donâ€™t assume itâ€™s an attack on your character. They just have things toÂ do.
  • Know your limits. The idea is not to spend your entire Saturday at someoneâ€™s house.

The idea is inspired by observing my own parents and their huge circle of friends. They constantly seem to have people over but they are never particularly stressed out about it. Itâ€™s not uncommon to have 3 different sets of people show up throughout the day. They are usually served a cup of tea and whatever they can find available in theÂ fridge.

This is sort of how I imagine people living in those small European towns in Greece where everyone is old and happy and all they do is socialize. I want to be old and happyÂ too!
