title: Surprising unintended consequences of Airbnb hosting
content:encoded:
Weâ€™ve been hosting on Airbnb for a full week now. However, my perfectionist wife has been setting up the room for a month prior to that. The possibility of someone giving us a three star rating is just too much to bear. Thankfully, weâ€™ve been getting only five star ratings soÂ far.

To ensure the five star rating keeps coming, weâ€™ve had to go through each corner of the basement and clear it out, rearrange the furniture and fix any outstanding nagging maintenance issues. As a result, weâ€™ve taken several trunk-loads of stuff straight to Goodwillâ€Šâ€”â€Šmostly random junk that was packed away in the basement, forgotten about and collecting dust.

The basement was also the place where our TV lived. We do not have another one upstairs. It is also the place where I kept my clothes. My wife graciously allowed me to keep my stuff in the basement while she took over the bedroom closet. It incorporated my own private bathroom as well. Weâ€™ve never had to worry where to keep my shaving paraphernalia versus her hair products.

Since weâ€™ve started renting the basement, things had to change. Weâ€™ve shifted from having 1600 square feet to 900. My clothes moved upstairs. Weâ€™ve had to isolate a small corner in the closet for me. The bathrooms were unified (it is going through a clean up process as I am writing this). Thereâ€™s also no more television.

Essentially, weâ€™ve forced ourselves into adopting a certain level of minimalism.

Minimalism was never the intention when considering Airbnb. Instead, I was always thinking about our TTF (time to financial independence). Thatâ€™s because Airbnb is the classic example of passivish income (I made that up). Your existing asset (the house) is doing most of the heavy lifting. You just need to remember to pay the bills. The more you automate, the more passive itÂ becomes.

One glance around here and youâ€™ll know right away that I am a huge fan of minimalism and intentional living. Thatâ€™s why it came to me as a very unexpected yet pleasant surprise when I realized I am forced to downsize substantially.

Before you jump to conclusions, this is not some personality disorder or twisted reasoning. I am not actively trying to induce self-harm. This is a very conscious decision. Ponder this idea of happiness through subtraction for example to see where Iâ€™m coming from. If youâ€™re still not convinced, thatâ€™s fine. Iâ€™ll have a lot more to say about minimalism in theÂ future.

In the mean time, for anyone thinking about their TTF, you should know there are some unintended consequences to Airbnb that go well beyond the money; intentional minimalism happens to be one ofÂ them.

title: Why reaching goals make me no happier
content:encoded:
Lately, I started to realize that I am not happy. Donâ€™t get me wrong, I am not depressed (all my friends can testify!). In fact, I am happy, just not as much as I think I should be. Nothing is seriously wrong or need to be fixed about my life. I have a great paying job, amazing friends and brilliant co-workers, and I feel strong and healthy. Yet I still want to beÂ happier.

For the past week, I pursued a quest to measure my own happiness. This is surprisingly difficult. The feeling of happiness is not a boolean but a scale. I can roughly estimate an average of 7/10 daily happiness level. I wonder where the missing 3Â went.

Where does 7 came from, you may ask. I imagine my happiness point is derived from some sort of goal or task completion. It could be a small task like doing groceries or a bigger goal like getting a promotion. To explain my thought process better, I made a formula out ofÂ it.

Assume that one atomic unit of happiness is called joy. Each task or goal completion can spark X amount of joy based on level of challenge. My todo list on the weekend looks likeÂ this.

  • Water a plant = 5 joy after completion
  • Clean up my bathroom = 30 joy after completion
  • File taxes = 50 joy after completion
  • Complete my first blog on Medium = 100 joy after completion!

Letâ€™s say my threshold of happiness per day is at 100. If I complete everything in the list (even filing taxes!), I should have a very happy Saturday. Well, the truth is.. notÂ really.

The pure happiness I feel from achieving goals is only temporary. A better goal is contentment or fulfillment.

The formula above fails to capture the sense of fulfillment, which comes from having a purpose and being present in the moment. That is why focusing on goal completion alone is for amateurs. We need to feel consistent fulfillment throughout the journey to theÂ goal.

How should I represent fulfillment in this formula? Since fulfillment is all about enjoying the moment, it should perhaps be represented as joy gain per minute (as long as we feel happy in those minutes). As time progresses, total fulfillment is equal to the joy/min multiplied by the time spend. Letâ€™s try the formulaÂ again.

  • Watch Netflix (1 hour) = 1 joy/min + 0 joy after completion
  • File tax (3 hours) = 0 joy/min + 50 joy after completion
  • Complete my first blog on Medium (~5 hour) = 0.2 joy/min + 40 joy after completion!

You may argue that the fulfillment gain may not always progress linearly with time. For example, if my Medium post took more than 5 hours to write, I would gain no more fulfillment after the 5 hours past. I agree! Well, for the sake of simplicity, letâ€™s ignore that for now and assume only the upper bound of fulfillment that you can reach. Now letâ€™s categorize all tasks into one of the threeÂ buckets.

  • Highly fulfilling activity. The activities such as watching Netflix, or drinking with friends are highly fulfilling but provides zero achievement afterwards.
  • Pure achievement. These activities could be painful to go through but yield accomplishment afterward such as cooking, searching for a bike to buy, or filing tax. I wish I could just finish themÂ quickly.
  • Highly fulfilling with sense of achievement. I have only handful of these in my life such as reading a book, learning to snowboard, or writing this blogÂ post.

This lens is helpful to detach myself from the end-goal ultra focus, and constantly reminding myself to live in the moment. I start thinking of my day as the combination of 30% fulfillment and 70% achievement and started optimizing for the third bucket. Many mundane tasks like folding clothes or biking can also be extremely fulfilling and could be part of the bigger goal achievement (if you think about it hardÂ enough).

Slowly, I feel that completing the goal has become less important, but having the right balance is more crucial to my overall happiness.

Thank you for reading it this far. This post will not come about if I didnâ€™t have a great conversation with my best-friend, â€œMonique.â€ Also, special thanks to @osportfolio for his true inspirational blogs (and the proofreading!).

title: My state of the art system to goal setting
content:encoded:
I have yet to meet a person who was perfectly content with exactly who they were. Everyone is always trying to change something about themselves. The typical things includes the food they eat, the amount of exercise they get, how they spend their time and how they prioritize their lives. Turns out, change is harder than reading a blogÂ online.

People are also creatures of habit. We all have our morning routines, our night routines, our commute to work routine and the web sites we visit on our lunch break routine. In fact, when we are put in new environments where executing our routines is hard, we generally tend to skip workouts and eat fried chicken forÂ dinner.

I am going to share with you an approach that I use to form better habits. It is not fool proof. It does require some upfront investment. However, I believe it could work for almost any habit you are trying to form as long as you apply enough creativity. The system is very simple to apply. All you have to do is create a system. Yes, you read that right, the system is to create systems. Let meÂ explain.

When I say â€œsystemâ€, Iâ€™m talking about a set of rules, or guidelines you use to guide your choices. The side effect of those rules should be that you execute your desired habit. Think of these rules as formalizing a contract with yourself. The contract has at least one rule: I can have as much [A] as I want. However, before I get [A], I must do [B]. This is what I call a personal contract.

The inspiration came from Dr. BJ Fogg, a researcher in behaviour design who had a great TED talk a few years back about this exactÂ topic.

If you use an existing behaviour in your life, and you put the new, tiny behaviour after it, you can use the existing behaviour to be theÂ trigger.

Nonetheless, over time, I noticed that simply defining the contract wasnâ€™t always enough. Frequently, I couldnâ€™t uphold the contract for long or I would completely forget about it. In fact, it was really a hit or missâ€Šâ€”â€Šoccasionally it would work really well but periodically it would completely fallÂ apart.

More recently, I took a look at some personal contracts I was able to maintain for a long stretch and tried to boil it down to what made them different. I have identified four hallmarks of a good personal contract.

Automatic. If you can set this up for your desired habit, your job is practically done. For example, before I spend any money, I max out my 401k. I can automate this through my paycheque contributions. Done!

Unfortunately, itâ€™s not easy to automate certain areas of your life. Exercising effectively requires you to be doing exercise. Calling your mom once a week requires you to talk (at least forÂ now).

However, thereâ€™s a clear subset of bad habits that can be automated away. Anything digital will naturally fall here. Do you have bad browsing behaviour? Are you spending too much time on your Twitter/Facebook/YouTubeÂ ? Thereâ€™s an app for that. Are you having trouble saving or budgeting? Thereâ€™s a bank forÂ that.

The advantage of automating bad habits away is you only have that upfront cost once but you reap the dividends indefinitely.

Breaks down barriers. One habit that I recently found to be absolutely effortless is the habit of eating a healthy lunch. In the past, Iâ€™ve tried cooking at home or buying out healthy lunches but inevitably you skip cooking for a few nights and end up ordering a large barbacoa burrito at Chipotle. You do it enough times and getting back to cooking regularly becomes more and more unlikely.

How many barriers can you identify with my past system? First, cooking at home is a pain in the ass. Second, when buying food outside, there are far too many temptations. Third, even if I manage to convince myself to buy a salad, in the back of my mind Iâ€™m always thinking itâ€™s a bad a deal because Iâ€™ll stay hungry after thatÂ salad.

Here is my new approach: my current employer provides catered lunches every day. I made a personal contract with myself to eat a giant bowl of salad from the salad bar first. Once Iâ€™m finished with the bowl, I can have absolutely anything I want. There are no limits. This contract addresses all barriers Iâ€™ve had for eating a healthy lunch. I donâ€™t have to cook anything; I am not tempted by anything else since choices are limited; and I am not getting a bad deal because I can have anything I want afterwards. I just need to get through that bowl of salad first. As an added bonus, thereâ€™s very little I can eat once Iâ€™m done with the salad. I tend to be much more ambitious whenÂ hungry.

In general, try and identify all the little excuses you are giving yourself to stop doing what you really want to be doing. Once identified, try to design your life in a way that will break down those excuses in the most effortless way possible.

Other barriers usually include, distance, accessibility and ease of use. Watch out forÂ these.

Sets the correct incentive. You know how we said before you get [A] you must do [B]? Make sure that whatever [A] is, it is motivating enough to act as a trigger. If you remember reading my commitments for 2018, youâ€™ll recall that one of my commitments was to drink two cups of coffee a day. Unfortunately, Iâ€™ve noticed that as time goes on, I am creeping back to three cups. Each time I have it, I feel a little guilty but I reason that starting tomorrow Iâ€™ll be better. Instead of feeling guilt, I can turn this around and use it to my advantage.

I am a member of a gym located in the same building where I work. I am making the following personal contract: each time I feel like having a third cup of coffee, I must first hit the gym. The barriers to work out are exceedingly low and now I also have a great incentive to do the right thing (the fact that I made it public is aÂ bonus).

You can generalize this approach as well. Essentially, you sacrifice one minor bad habit to enforce and carry out a major good habit by setting up the right incentives for yourself.

Consistent with the individual. Sometimes, despite all the automation, best intentions, lowest barriers, and most enticing incentives, you still fail at your habit building; and thatâ€™sÂ okay.

Coming up with these systems is an iterative process. You will always be tinkering with them. Always trying something new. Always looking for a better way of doing things. Youâ€™ll never get it just right the very firstÂ time.

The key is to keep trying new ways of doing things and experimenting with what works for you. For example, a cup of coffee might be enough to motivate me to go to the gym. You might want a new pair of sneakers instead. If thatâ€™s your barrier, donâ€™t bother with my system. It wonâ€™t work forÂ you.

When I come up with great systems that work for me, I am always very proud and happy to shareâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust wait until I write my post about budgeting.

Let me know if you have a system you are particularly proud of. I am always looking to tweak mine and share withÂ others.

title: This is where I see myself in five years
content:encoded:
Actually, I canâ€™t see thatÂ far.

A couple of weeks ago I was having lunch with my friends Zack and Nina. I canâ€™t remember exactly what we were discussing but it must have been something interesting. It usually is. Suddenly, Zack asks me the following question:

Where do you see yourself in fiveÂ years?

I havenâ€™t been to an interview in a long time so I was caught off guard. I didnâ€™t have a good enough, well rehearsed and politically correct answer to give. Then again, I wasnâ€™t being actually interviewed for a job so I told him the honest truth. The truth is, I think that planning five years ahead is pointless if not counterproductive. I am sure that every lifestyle/productivity guru on the internet is having a meltdown right now. However, let meÂ explain.

Presumably, setting a long term goal means the outcome is important to you. It is probably something that will make you happy and make you feel like a more accomplished person. Or will it? Weâ€™ve talked about this before. What you think will make you happy doesnâ€™t always make you happy. You just may end up on the hamster wheel chasing the nextÂ goal.

More importantly, the goals that you set for yourself today might not even be applicable five years from now. Let me give you a concrete example. Iâ€™ll steal this one from Nina because it works out perfectly. She mentioned that one of her friends has five year goal to open up her own brewery. That sounds really fun right? However, how sure is this friend that brewing beer is what she really wants to do? Five years from now, her priorities could change completely. Has she spent enough time brewing beer for herself? Is she sure that running her own business is something that sheÂ wants?

Another mistake a lot of people make when setting their long term goals is making goals that are outside of their control. For example, you can set a goal for yourself to get married. Is that a good goal? I donâ€™t think so. Yes, one way to hand over more control to yourself is to lower your expectations but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s what you had in mind when committing to this five yearsÂ earlier.

So far Iâ€™ve just been warming up. Sure, all of the above is true, but the real reason five year goals are pointless is much simpler. The unpredictability of life makes it so. For example, five years ago I was happily living in Canada when all of a sudden I got an opportunity to work at a much fancier company for much fancier pay. All my five year plans had to be abandoned (if I had any). Two days ago my wife came back from Portugal and is convinced life is better over there. Whatâ€™s my five year planÂ now?

I can hear all the detractors from my couch grumbling under their breath about how I just donâ€™t understand the goal setting process. It doesnâ€™t have to be this specific or set in stone. Thatâ€™s true! However, how generic are you thinking? The reality is that once you make it somewhat generic, everyone wants roughly the same. Everyone wants to be healthier, stronger, better looking with a devoted spouse and a killer job. So what? How are you getting there? The devil is in theÂ details.

I am not here just to be a complainypants. I also like to propose solutions. So here it goes: Do whatever you do to set your five year goal but set it for only one year ahead. Do this every year. At the end of the year, reevaluate and readjust. A year is generally enough to set substantial but achievable goals. At the same time, when things changeâ€Šâ€”â€Šeither your surrounding or your opinionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou have plenty of opportunity to reevaluate what you value and where youâ€™reÂ heading.

You can experiment with shorter periods of time as well, however, I suspect that if you do this too frequently, you wonâ€™t be giving yourself enough time to complete the goal. At the same time, youâ€™ll be giving yourself a lot of opportunities to quit. One year seems like a good balance between some level of accountability and flexibility.

The key to make this recurring one year goal work is the reevaluation part of the process. Each year, you must check back on the goals you set for yourself in the beginning of year and evaluate your performance. Furthermore, reevaluate if you want to continue with this goal. Finally, and most importantly, step up the difficulty level of theÂ goal.

I think of this as â€œmanaged personal growthâ€. Open source portfolio of 2018 should be better in every way than Open source portfolio of 2017. If not, Open source portfolio wasted 2017. The only way I would know this is if I was accountable to myÂ goals.

Hereâ€™s my self grading forÂ 2017

Hereâ€™s my goals forÂ 2018

A nice and unexpected benefit from this system is that in 2022 Iâ€™ll get to see my 2017 goals and have a good laugh at how little I expected ofÂ myself.

title: Happiness: appealing to the like system
content:encoded:
Happiness: ask, and you shallÂ receive

Actionable items you can do today to engage your likeÂ system

This is part II of my discussion of â€œHappiness: the science behind your smileâ€. If you havenâ€™t read part I, I encourage you to do so here. Everything will make a lot more sense if youÂ do.

For those that have fully embraced the smartphone age and lack patience, hereâ€™s a quickÂ summary:

Turns out what we want is frequently separate from what we like. The things we desire in life do not always bring us happiness. This makes perfect sense from an evolutionary perspective. Evolution does not care about your happiness. Its only objective is to propagate your genes. Therefore; your ancestors were rewarded when competing for status and acquiring resources. However, to be happy, you cannot simply chase your desires. Those desires must also bring you long term contentment. You can do this only if you engage both the â€œwant systemâ€ and the â€œlikeÂ systemâ€.

Now that youâ€™re up to speed, letâ€™s digÂ in.

Shortly after publishing the first article about the two systems, my friend Zack asked me a really interesting question.

Whatâ€™s an actionable item I can do today to determine what will appeal to my â€œwantâ€ and â€œlikeâ€Â system?

Iâ€™ll be honest, I had to think long and hard about this one. My gut reaction was to write a piece bashing materialism and status seeking but I feel like itâ€™s not very satisfying. Itâ€™s hard to convince anyone that driving a brand new Tesla SUV to work on daily basis will not bring them more happiness in life. Also, as my wife frequently reminds me, â€œnot everyone wants to live like aÂ monkâ€.

Consequently, I had to step back and reconsider. What else can you do to engage the â€œlikeÂ systemâ€?

Weâ€™ve already established that people are terrible at predicting how much happiness their desires will bring them. We tend to overestimate the pleasure we will gain from positive experiences. Similarly we tend to overestimate the pain we will experience from negative experiences. However, I am aware of at least one method that seems to be somewhat more reliable than our own intuition. All you have to do is find someone who is at the same position you would like to be and ask them how theyÂ feel.

This might not be the bombshell you were expecting. However, the consequence of this idea is easy to overlook.

Consider for instance what you could do if you were buying a new house. You and your spouse might be looking for a 4 bedroom house at a near by suburb in a brand new development. It must have a 2 car garage and a ton of yard space to play ball with your future child. You will use the extra rooms as an office and an extra bedroom whenever your parents visit from out of town. Sure, it will increase your commute and the mortgage payments are a little high, but itâ€™s worthÂ it!

Sounds familiar? Thatâ€™s because it is exactly what a typical couple doesâ€Šâ€”â€Šat least around this part ofÂ town.

Before signing on the dotted line, and committing to 30 years of debt, you could ask a current home owner, roughly at the same stage of life, roughly with the same house, living in a similar neighborhood, what their day to day looks like. Do they have any regrets? Do they miss renting? How do they feel about Home Depot? What would they change if they could do it overÂ again?

They may tell you that itâ€™s incredible. Itâ€™s everything and more than they hoped for. They love entertaining friends on their brand new deck and all the neighbors are extremely friendly and pleasant. Itâ€™s the best decision they could have everÂ made.

Another possibility is that the commute is tough and stressful and the mortgage payments are stretching their finances further than they are comfortable. Maintaining it is also a dailyÂ grind.

Whatever the outcome, it is valuable information you didnâ€™t have before. According to Dan Gilbert, their response will also be a much better predictor of your future feelings than your own intuition.

Now letâ€™s take it a step further. What if you didnâ€™t just settle for asking people that are a single step ahead of you. What if you also asked people who are multiple steps ahead of you. For example, if your parents own their home, why not ask them? You could even use the same questions.

They may tell you it was a great investment and all their retirement savings are in the house. They were able to raise 2.6 children in that house and send them to the best public schools the department of education had toÂ offer.

Similarly, they could tell you they never once in 20 years walked into that office/bedroom without a feather duster and windex in their hands. They regret not buying a smaller house and using the extra money toÂ travel.

Again, valuable information but this time from a long term perspective.

Finally, you can take this advice to itâ€™s logical conclusion. I hesitate to write this because it is a morbid way to think. However, the insight is absolutely invaluable. I am talking about an article appropriately titled regrets of the dying. It took me a long time to read this partially because I couldnâ€™t get over how morbid it is. However, I highly encourage everyone to give it a chance. Once I got through it, I realized that the fear of regret is a very powerful reason to live right. It was also indirectly responsible for this article (and many others toÂ come).

The regrets are of course very emotional and human. I think that all of us can predict at least half of them if we just sat down and tried to list them. Yet there is something powerfully contemplative even as I re-readÂ them.

One regret I think would resonate with everyone is #4â€Šâ€”â€ŠI wish I had stayed in touch with my friends. This is something that could haunt you your entire life unless you devote a lot of concentrated effort to maintain these relationships. One major reason for this is our endless mobility. It is certainly a great opportunity to meet wonderful people. However, the relationships you form tend to be more shallow. Once â€œbusynessâ€ catches up with you, those are the first toÂ go.

This is a focus area for myself although I will make it more official in my 2019 resolutions.

So what would these people tell you about your house choices if you somehow managed to ask them? I cannot speak for them authoritatively, but my guess is theyâ€™d tell you to live your life and stop wasting your time on this shit because it really doesnâ€™tÂ matter.

title: The real reason economic progress hasnâ€™t lowered work hours more
content:encoded:
Assume for a moment that youâ€™re running a small business manufacturing pins and exporting it to the rest of the world. If you are working the standard North American schedule, it would translate to 40 hours a week or 8 hours a day. Now imagine that through some innovation on your part, you are now able to produce the same number of pins at half the time. To satisfy the same demand you can now work only 4 hours a day and enjoy an additional 4 hours of leisure. Straightforward math soÂ far.

Letâ€™s take this a step further. This time, youâ€™ve automated the process further and you can now produce the same number of pins at a quarter of the previous time. By the same math, now you can work an hour a day and enjoy 7 hours of additional leisure. This is essentially the reality for our productivity curve between 1950â€™s and today. We are far more productive today by every measure. However, the number of hours we work hasnâ€™tÂ budged.

The above was a prediction by a famous economist, John Maynard Keynes, in 1930. The video is a lecture by a professor in Economics trying to answer why this prediction did not materialize. The lecture is very insightful and brings up many interesting statistics about work, prosperity and well being broken down by gender, age and race. However, his main reason as to why the number of hours we work hasnâ€™t decreased despite much progress in productivity is our love for work andÂ money.

Although he presents good evidence to support his case, I believe there are a couple of other reasons we are working the same 40 hour weeks as we did in the 50â€™s that he overlooked. I would also argue that these reasons are equally important if not moreÂ so.

The system isnâ€™t conductive to less hours. Letâ€™s go back to our pin maker from before. If the pin maker decided to lay back and enjoy the additional 7 hours of leisure, what do you think would happen? All of her competitors would eventually figure out the same new, faster method of production and flood the market with pins since they can now produce moreâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach trying to wrestle away market share. In turn, that would push prices down and our (lazy) pin maker would quickly go out of business. This is the basis of capitalism.

We can thank our high standard of living to this phenomena. It brought us many innovations by aligning incentives and pushed billions of people out of poverty all around the world. It does this by rewarding work and innovation but penalizing complacency.

However, there are certainly few employers out there that have toyed with the idea of lowering work hours. For example, back in 2016, Amazon considered introducing a 30 hour work week for some of their employees.

If we have employers that are open to this idea, why donâ€™t the employees rise up and demand lower work hours? Do we love money this much? I think thereâ€™s another more subtle reason that is driving it beyondÂ greed.

Most people havenâ€™t discovered their purpose. If you ever needed to describe your purpose in life, could you? Not the purpose of life, thatâ€™s also beyond the scope of this article. Your purpose in life is what youâ€™d like to achieve or do. If you canâ€™t, thatâ€™s okay. Few peopleÂ can.

Once you free up those 7 hours of leisure time, you must have a way to fill them up with some leisure activities. If you donâ€™t have a purpose, itâ€™s hard to come up with things to do unless traveling the world for 40 years sounds like a good idea to you; and thereâ€™s certainly people who thinkÂ so.

Iâ€™ve encountered this a lot when I talk to people about financial independence (FI or effai ğŸ˜ƒ). The question of what I would do with all that free time immediately comes up. This question sometimes stems from curiosity and other times to ridicule the idea (read this article for my thoughts on this behaviour). Iâ€™ve spoken to countless people about FI but only a handful ever considered what they would do if they had moreÂ time.

Thatâ€™s why a job is usually the de facto source of purpose and the main occupier of time for most people. Once itâ€™s taken away, people may feel lost. Thatâ€™s also why early retirees seem to dieÂ earlier.

Of course, I wouldnâ€™t even be considering FI if I believed dying early was an inevitable fact and no amount of salad eating could save me. Nor would I ever recommend it to anyone else. I believe that anyone who is working towards FI the traditional wayâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat is, by saving hardâ€Šâ€”â€Šmust at some point consider their purpose. Otherwise they could not maintain the motivation to save so much for 15 plus years. Thatâ€™s a tiny minority of peopleÂ though.

Hence the result. Still working 100% of the time while creating 800% the product instead of working 1/8th of the time while producing 100% of theÂ product.

title: Hyper-specialization vs. Knowing stuff
content:encoded:
I am half way through Joel Salatinâ€™s â€œFolks, this ainâ€™t normalâ€ and if it continues the way itâ€™s been so far, I might have to add it to my most influential book list. The overall theme discusses how far weâ€™ve disconnected from our food supply and how the current food system has become the newÂ normal.

Folks, This Ain't Normal: A Farmer's Advice for Happier Hens, Healthier People, and a Better World

Speaking of new norms, Joel mentions something called a â€œlarderâ€ which was quite common before refrigeration but fell out of favour in more modern times. To be honest, Iâ€™ve never heard of that term and had to turn to Google to help me decipher it. Clearly, the question of how people kept food before modern refrigerators didnâ€™t come up in my mind very frequently.

If you are comfortable not knowing what a larder is because itâ€™s an obsolete concept since the invention of the refrigerator, try to answer one of the following questions instead:

  1. What is a carburetor in relation to aÂ car?
  2. What is the difference between a seed and aÂ nut?
  3. What would hurt more, 220 watts or 220 volts of electricity?
  4. What is lactose in reference to lactose intolerance? Is it a protein or a carb or something else?
  5. What part of the animal is a tenderloin. Follow up question, what animal isÂ it?

Iâ€™ll be very surprised to find anyone born any time after 1980 who didnâ€™t have to Google at least some of these [every day] concepts.

If you made it this far, youâ€™re probably thinking one of twoÂ things.

The education system is dropping the ball on us. The world is going toÂ shit.
Whatever. Who cares what a carburetor is anyway? I drive aÂ Tesla.

Iâ€™d like to address each of these separately. First, if you agree that this knowledge is good to have, itâ€™s very tempting to find a reason why we are missing it. Blaming it on some sort of institution is the easy way out. Unfortunately, I am not convinced itâ€™s always an education problem.

For example, I didnâ€™t know what a carburetor was because I never owned a car myself. I heard others talk about it because their car broke down and it was identified as a possible cause. However, unless youâ€™re into cars or bikes, or you have some fascination with fixing motors, you probably didnâ€™t know what a carburetor was either. Itâ€™s very possible you never even heard of thisÂ part.

Thereâ€™s a good reason for that. Itâ€™s because of how we address problems. If smoke is coming out of the front hood of my car on the highway, instead of stopping by the side of the road, popping the hood and trying to identify the problem, I am going to pick up my phone and call a tow truck to take it to nearest mechanic. Once the work is complete, Iâ€™ll swipe my plastic and drive home. Transaction complete. Where was my opportunity to learn about the internals of anÂ engine?

From an economic point of view, this is a great story. Imagine if this wasnâ€™t the case. What if you didnâ€™t have access to qualified people in different fields. Instead you had to learn how to do everything yourself. It becomes impossible to be a good mechanic, electrician, plumber, programmer and dietician at the same time. There just isnâ€™t enough time (and skill). Through specialization, you are able to gain access to experts in many fields for an affordable price. The mechanic has mastery in her field so you donâ€™t have to. You are now free to concentrate on enterprises that you are more productive in.

Of course it comes at a price. As our society becomes increasingly specialized, our breadth of knowledge becomes more narrow. This is natural since we are outsourcing so much of the â€œotherâ€ work to experts in their own fields. Thatâ€™s why I donâ€™t know much (anything) about electricity or plumbing but I know a thing or two about web development. You can take this to a not so unimaginable extreme where your average nuclear astrophysicist is unable to make herself breakfast because she doesnâ€™t know how to boil anÂ egg.

A second position one could take is that this information is useless anyway. A larder is useless because you have a fridge. A carburetor is useless because you have an electric car. Seeds and nuts are useless because you can always get your fruits from Costco and so on. This is also a flawed argument for a very similarÂ reason.

It is unlikely that knowing the answer to any of the 5 questions posed earlier would directly impact your life in any way. It could, but itâ€™s very unlikely. However, thereâ€™s a certain knowledge base that is significantly common within regular life. Things that come up frequently. This is a sign that you should be familiar with them. For example, it is likely that you were familiar with most, if not all the terms in the questions even if you were unable to answer them without Googling. Thatâ€™s because volts and lactose are quite common in everydayÂ life.

Once you spend enough time learning about the basics, life becomes easier. Changing a light switch in the house isnâ€™t a big deal anymore. If the toilet isnâ€™t flushing the way youâ€™d like, no need to call a plumber. If youâ€™re told you are eating a tenderloin, you donâ€™t need to wonder if itâ€™s white meat or dark meat. All sorts of options open up forÂ you.

Another advantage to knowing your basics well is that others canâ€™t feed you lies, or if they are trying, you have a good radar calibrated to detect just that. In a world where flexible truth prances around masquerading as facts on every corner, this is an incredibly helpful skill to have. For example, it would be much harder for a mechanic to over charge you if you had at least a basic understanding of what could beÂ wrong.

By hyper-specializing in a certain space you are potentially robbing yourself of these opportunities. Why shouldnâ€™t a web a developer know how to garden? For that matter, why shouldnâ€™t a gardener know how a website works. This isnâ€™t proprietary information and the lessons could be invaluable for all. I would personally love to pick my own tomatoes while Iâ€™m sure my gardener would love to update the pricing on his website without my involvement.

title: Why you should read daily
content:encoded:
A book is the words, the ideas, mindset, advice and experience of another person wrapped into a convenient, portable, always available collection ofÂ papers.

This is one of my favourite videos on YouTube and I donâ€™t think I could have expressed the idea any better myself. I highly recommend that you take those three and a half minutes of your hectic and extremely busy life to watch it. Of course, the quote above gives you a reasonable summary asÂ well.

As an employee in most corporations, youâ€™ve likely run into the idea of having a mentor at work. Someone who is senior to you, frequently older or more experienced. They are expected to share their knowledge with you to help you progress in your career. This is a wonderful system (at least in theory) since we can learn from past mistakes and seek advice from more accomplished colleagues.

It sounds great for those 40 hours a week you spend at work. What about the other 72 awake hours you have? How come we donâ€™t seek out mentors for that larger portion of our lives? Of course, if you do, more power to you. I personally donâ€™t know anyone who has successfully maintained such a relationship.

This brings me back to the video above. Since about the age of 20, Iâ€™ve been reading all sorts of non-fiction. I never had a good reason to. I just knew that I enjoyed it. Since watching the video, The idea of mentorship opened my eyes to much deeper reasoning. Here isÂ why.

Each time you read a book, you get to pick a topic, any topic and learn from a world class expert in the field about all the lessons and mistakes theyâ€™ve encountered, in a concise and rigorous way. The book can usually be consumed in about 7â€“30 days. Rinse andÂ repeat.

Books are the ideal kind of mentorship. Through the filter of time and amazon reviews, all the garbage will die out and youâ€™ll be left with the gems. The topic is up to you. The depth of the topic is up to you. The quantity is also up to you. Finally, the schedule is up to you. No single human mentor can live up toÂ that.

Feel free to follow me on GoodReads

title: If actions reflect values, what do they say about you?
content:encoded:
The mental math that goes into making decisions and how I tilt the odds in myÂ favour

My company just wrapped up a week of festivities. Hashtags were flying around with snazzy slogans celebrating unity and harmony, identity and integrity and all sorts of other hippy war cries. We got to talk about the companyâ€™s future direction and gossip about internal politics.

Once each day came to a close, we headed to the restaurants to eat the finest Pad Thai San Francisco had to offer. We all had a daily allowance and Iâ€™ll be damned if I didnâ€™t use it! On the last day, we had a giant party with unlimited tequila shots and a fish tacoÂ stand.

That night, I downed my fifth fluid ounce of tequila and headed straight for my friend Colin who was in the midst of a deep conversation with Nina and Zack. I donâ€™t know what they were talking about, but I overheard the following phrase

Your actions reflect yourÂ values

Cool, I thought. Heard that one before. Nothing new. Iâ€™ll take that beerÂ now.

Once the party was over, I stumbled my way to the hotel and passedÂ out.

The next day I woke up at 10am with a pounding headache. I was incapacitated to my room for the next 9 hours while my liver was hard at work. The only positive outcome of that experience was the opportunity to reflect on myÂ actions.

I am the guy who preaches the gospel of low sugar diets to anyone who will dare to listen. I spend copious amounts of time roaming the internet for information about insulin, cholesterol, and inflammation. I also managed to poison my own body using exclusively the sheer power of my ownÂ will.

I am the guy who regularly writes about happiness, minimalism and intentional living. I worked hard on my 2017 resolutions to use my time wisely. I found plenty of time to browse nonsense on the internet throughout that week. I did not however find time to call myÂ mother.

If the statement above is trueâ€Šâ€”â€Šif actions dictate your valuesâ€Šâ€”â€Šmy values areâ€¦ off. They are certainly not what I expected them toÂ be.

I am glad Colin brought up that phrase. Thanks to him, I had a mini-epiphany while nursing my hangover.

Up to last week, my values dictated my actionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šup to a point. Occasionally, I would give myself a break from being goodÂ â€¦ and be bad. I would drink a little too much. I would browse YouTube a little too long. I would get into an argument on Twitter a little tooÂ fast.

The new me prefaces these â€œundesirableâ€ behaviours with the following question:

Does this action reflect myÂ values?

Does drinking a pint of beer reflect my values? Nope. Maybe Iâ€™ll think again before ordering a second round. Better yet, I can go for a tall glass of kombuchaÂ instead.

This approach can work for anyone. TryÂ this:

Next time youâ€™re about to open Netflix, play another round of Candy Crush or skip the gym because you are sore from the brisk walk yesterday, ask yourself this: does this action reflect myÂ values?

title: My Secret to Productivity
content:encoded:
Everyone has a secret move or a special technique they use to keep themselves pumped up to complete a task. Amidst all the distraction from the likes of Youtube, Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, one may ask how is it possible to stay productive atÂ all?

In my mind, there are many things that need to be my attention. However, I usually have a tendency to delay things as long as possible. People call it many things, but I call it laziness. ğŸ˜–

It could be writing a Medium article, finishing up a chunk of code, reviewing a technical document, or just replying to an email. When Iâ€™m left to my own devices, I would basically imagine all these things in my head and feel the insurmountable amount of work that needsÂ doneâ€¦

When that grim mood sets in, my hand would instinctively reach into my pocket and pull out myÂ phone.

This had happened to me multiple times in the past, and it still does from time toÂ time.

But something changed. Once I discovered the secret cure to counter this terrible disease, Iâ€™ve been able to be 10x more productive than before, and as a direct result, bring much more joy into my life. My steps have springs in them, and my every waking day I feel a sense of mission and accomplishment.

Now, let me share with you my personal secret weapon to increase productivity.

MOMENTUM

Thatâ€™s it, I said it. Momentum. Itâ€™s a simple word, but a powerfulÂ force.

Momentum is what picks you up when youâ€™re down, keeps you going when youâ€™re overwhelmed, and maintains your focus when you sense distraction.
Momentum gets rid of triviality, and drivesÂ action.
Momentum is the power toÂ produce.

When I sense that my energy level is low, and yet there are heaps of stuff left to be done, I give myself a mental pat on the back and start with one simple goal: do one thing at aÂ time.

Let me give you an example. I started writing this article on a Tuesday evening at 10.10pm after work. I had just worked out, cleaned up the place and felt reallyÂ tired.

Yet, I promised my editor (Open source portfolio) that Iâ€™ll write at least an article this week to demonstrate mindful living in my ownÂ life.

After I sat down on my bed, my first thought was, â€œHmm, there are other, better things I can do with my time. Letâ€™s see whatâ€™s on Facebook before I get startedâ€¦â€

One thing led to another, and 10 minutes later I was still on Facebook. How often has this happened toÂ you?

Thatâ€™s when I told myself, â€œOK, letâ€™s try just one paragraph. Letâ€™s see what happensâ€¦â€

Thatâ€™s the magic phrase, letâ€™s see whatÂ happens.

Once you start doing something, the powerful magic of momentum will carry you forward without you knowingÂ it.

Fast-forward 20 minutes later, and Iâ€™ve already written close to 500 words. Much of it will probably be edited out in post-processing, but thatâ€™s OK. I have outdone myself, and wrote more than what I set out toÂ do.

In my opinion, the most important thing is to realize that productivity doesnâ€™t mean getting things done to perfection. Productivity, to me, means to execute and follow-through. Getting something out there is much better than nothing atÂ all.

Once you have momentum behind you, it is much easier to follow that flow and drive things to completion.

Tips & Tricks for BuildingÂ Momentum

Here is a list of tips & tricks I use to build momentum in my dailyÂ life:

  • I block out a chunk of time on my calendar every day for my own space. For example, on my work calendar, thereâ€™s a chunk of time from 3â€“5pm that is allocated for coding. I have understanding teammates who donâ€™t book meetings on those power-hours because itâ€™s important for me to keep sanity and have time to myself to do things I need toÂ do.
  • Fill in mundane tasks with something productive. Reading more books is one of my goals for this year. When I feel overwhelmed and need to get away, Iâ€™ll try to pull out a book or listen to an audiobook on Spotify. I have a book in my backpack at all times, and having something to put my mind into is very helpful in those situations. The goal here is to build a productive habit, and you can replace reading with something else like working out or taking out theÂ trash.
  • Set a schedule and stick to it. Working out is something I dread, yet itâ€™s important for my overall health. Earlier this year when I sat down and analyzed why I wasnâ€™t working out more, I realized that having to drive to the gym and mentally set myself in work-out mode was time-consuming and counter-productive. What I did, then, was I built my own little home gym. My small gym only has some free weights and a bench, but the effects are tremendous. Every day, Iâ€™ll spend 30â€“40 minutes in the gym either lifting or doing a quick jog. Again, I build momentum here by just showing up. 80% of the battle is already won when you show up, and thatâ€™s the beauty of momentum.

Those are just some examples of how I use momentum in my daily life to drive productivity. Iâ€™d like to know if you have any productivity tips to share asÂ well!

Credits

Thanks to Open source portfolio for proof-reading and providing valuable feedback!

Zhia Chong is a student of mindful living. While not writing articles like these on Medium, you can find him on Twitter and LinkedIn.

If you liked this, here are some other articles he hasÂ written:

  • How I landed offers from Microsoft, Amazon and Twitter without an Ivy-league degree
  • How to write a great resume for software engineers
  • How I automated my job search by building a webÂ crawler

title: Why meditation doesnâ€™t work
content:encoded:
Many people see no change after their meditation routine. It is expected.

Think about growing plants from seed. You wonâ€™t see a difference until the first leaf breaks through the soil. Planting requires the right temperature, appropriate timing, sufficient lighting, and much more to be successful. Same goes with meditation; posture, frequency, and durationÂ matter.

How long does itÂ take?

It depends on how thick the soil is. In this analogy, itâ€™s how self-aware youÂ are.

For me, it takes 10 minutes a day, 7 days a week, for 4 weeks to see theÂ benefit.

To experience the benefit of meditation, you need to be mindful enough. But, to be more mindful, you need to practice more meditation. Hence, at the beginning, you may not even be aware of the small changes. The progress is still under theÂ soil.

One does not simply count their breaths to unlock the power of meditation.

Get the logisticÂ right

  • I recommend to use guided meditation. Headspace is great for the beginner because it repeatedly walks through the core practices (seeÂ below).
  • Sit up right. Laying down meditation never works (IÂ tried).
  • Meditate for at least 10 minutes. The mind needs enough time to calm down and adjust to the practice.
  • Do it everyday. This is the most important rule. At the beginning, skipping one day felt almost like starting over again. Leverage the power of habits to see progressÂ faster.

Understand the coreÂ concept

We practice mindfulness in one of two ways: focused attention and open monitoring. They are quite different but both are essential.

  • Focused attention exercise can be done by focusing on one object like breathing. Buddhist monk practices mindful walking; paying attention to the feet that touch the ground, and the weight that pulls down due toÂ gravity.
Focused attention exercise is helpful to sharpen the focus and overcome the distraction in day-to-day life.
  • Open monitoring can be done by being aware of any sensation, thought or emotion that emerge without being attached to it. Instead of focusing on a particular object, keep the mind open to any sensations. See it appear and let it goes without processing it.
Open monitoring is helpful to let go of any present emotion, attachment to the past, and expectation of the future, which consumes our energy unnecessarily.

Benefit

I found that practicing mindfulness strengthens the ability to follow my own thought process to a great extent. I can reach to a deeper reasoning and watch closely how ego and emotion influence any action or decision. Mindfulness also gives the clarity to my subconscious thought such as fear, anxiety, and insecurity, which are the root of my reasoning flaw. Taking time to practice mindfulness is not only important but necessary in this chaoticÂ society.

Like physical exercise, meditation is the exercise of the mind. It will takes the regular practice for months to get the six-packÂ mind.

title: Commitments for 2018
content:encoded:
As promised last year Tuesday, I am publishing my resolutions for 2018. It will follow a slightly modified style of my 2017 resolutions but will stick to the same principles as described in my favourite part of new year. One tweak that Iâ€™m attempting is to create a generic topic that I want to concentrate on (but not grade) and grade myself only on the actionÂ items.

Health

Letâ€™s start with the big one. After all, itâ€™s the most important thing youâ€™ve got. This year, itâ€™s also the most loaded category of resolutions.

  • Eat a big bowl of salad forÂ lunch

I donâ€™t expect to have any trouble with the above. I bought myself a nice big bowl of salad and I make sure to fill it up every day. I highly encourage everyone to eat their leafyÂ greens.

  • Zero alcohol atÂ home
  • Two drink limit during social gatherings
  • Intermittent fast 3 times aÂ week

I think the details of how I do intermittent fasting is out of the scope of this article but the basic idea is restricted eating for 8 hours aÂ day.

  • Limit coffee consumption to two cups aÂ day

This makes me a little sad ğŸ˜”. I love my coffee but I noticed that when I donâ€™t have it, I start feeling very tired. I donâ€™t like the idea of being dependent on a substance. Another option is try decaf orÂ tea.

Minimalism

I couldnâ€™t come up with more then one resolution for this category (appropriately). I think that since last yearâ€™s clean up, weâ€™re pretty reasonable with how much things we accumulate. Thereâ€™s certainly rooms that could use some re-evaluation but overall I canâ€™t complain.

  • Stay itemÂ neutral

This one is short and easy. Iâ€™ll expand on item neutrality separately but the basic idea is simple. One item in, one itemÂ out.

Reading

Each book is someoneâ€™s lifetime accumulation of knowledge and experience condensed into a few hours of the most valuable lessons. Itâ€™s a great way to learn from gurus about any topic without ever having to meet them. Unfortunately Iâ€™m a slow a reader. Therefore; my goal isnâ€™t anything super ambitious but definitely respectable.

  • Read 16 books in aÂ year

I track my reading on Goodreads. That way I know exactly how many books Iâ€™ve read. Also, I donâ€™t have to finish the book to count it. Some books are not very good but as long as I got through a significant portion of it Iâ€™ll add it to theÂ count.

  • Replace unproductive activities withÂ reading

Unproductive activities is quite broad but they tend to boil down to some sort of passive consumption of entertainment; things like TV, netflix, news, and tech websites.

Fitness

Unlike prior years, I didnâ€™t wait until January to start going to the gym. Turns out, thereâ€™s a gym right in the building where I work so itâ€™s extremely convenient. Also, I didnâ€™t create any insurmountable goal. I found that consistency seems to be far more useful here than impressive ambitions.

  • Go to the gym twice aÂ week

I have a simple exercise plan but it will probably fluctuate throughout the year. Mainly Iâ€™m focused on showing up at the gym. Once Iâ€™m there, lifting weights is the easyÂ part.

Mindfulness

This is a completely new category for me. I tried a half-ass attempt at mindfulness earlier in 2017 but not ruminating about the past, planning for the future or recreating hypothetical events in your head, is harder to do then it first seems. I was introduced to the concept a while back but what really brought it to my attention is an honest account by Dan Harris on the path he took to start meditating.

Amazon.com: Buying Choices: 10% Happier: How I Tamed the Voice in My Head, Reduced Stress Without Losing My Edge, and Found Self-Help That Actually Works--A True Story

Since this is a new area for me, and I recognize how tough it is, Iâ€™m starting small for thisÂ year.

  • Donâ€™t pull out your phone without aÂ reason

You stand in line at Trader Joeâ€™s and you pull out your iPhone, slide the screens to the right, then to the left, check your email, and then put it back in your pocket. In the meantime achieving nothing. I see this all the time. Checking your phone for the sake of keeping your mind busy. I want to be okay withÂ boredom.

  • Stay present duringÂ walks

I tend to walk a lot. I walk to work and to get groceries. I walk a minimum of 10,000 steps in a day. I donâ€™t need 10,000 different conversations going through my head though. The idea is to try and stay present while outdoors. Itâ€™s somewhat arbitrary but I think it will be useful for two reasons. First, walking is a regular activity. Therefore; Iâ€™ll get a regular reminder to try and stay present. Second, the duration of the walks tends to be a reasonable amount of time for me to practice this newÂ skill.

  • Stop doing two things atÂ once

Mainly, Iâ€™m thinking about eating and browsing at the same time. Although Iâ€™m sure thereâ€™s plenty of other activities that I multi-task on. It seems like a great idea on the surface. You can finish twice as many things in the same time. However, I think itâ€™s just another symptom of restlessness and the fear of boredom that infectsÂ us.

Personal

I generally like myself, but thereâ€™s one thing that really drives me crazy. I hate how Iâ€™m constantly late to meet people. It is so bad that our friends now expect us to show up late. Itâ€™s an inside joke to see if we show up on time or not. So my resolution for the year isÂ simple.

  • Stop beingÂ late

Iâ€™m going to need some flexibility here. First, itâ€™s culturally appropriate to be late. Itâ€™s even termed â€œfashionably lateâ€. If thatâ€™s the expectation, I wouldnâ€™t want to show up on time and surprise the hosts. Second, I cannot always control when we leave the house. If my wife isnâ€™t ready, I donâ€™t think she would appreciate me leaving the house without her. Therefore; as long as I am dressed and ready to go on time, Iâ€™ll consider that a win. Itâ€™s just a good habit toÂ have.

Thatâ€™s all for me for 2018. What do you think of these resolutions? Are they achievable and specific enough? Is there anything that IÂ missed?

title: Slow it down
content:encoded:
About a year and a half ago I discovered the x1.5 speed feature on YouTube and my world has been changed forever. No more would I have to suffer through slow talking TED talks or horribly paced tutorials on trivial matters. Itâ€™s really been a godsend for my learning. In fact, check out my YouTube viewing as a percentage of my overallÂ surfing:

Thatâ€™s almost a quarter of all my surfing!! Second in itâ€™s place is Twitter which Iâ€™m not as proudÂ of.

Now for the longest time I felt reasonably good about this. I always justified this behaviour by saying that this is for learning. I was technically wasting my time because I was constantly learning something new. This is actually true. There was no way I could consume as much content otherwise.

Recently though, my wife brought up the objection that if I keep watching my videos on x1.5 speed, Iâ€™ll rewire my brain to expect everything to be done that way. Iâ€™ll start talking faster; Iâ€™ll expect other to talk faster; and most importantly Iâ€™ll have a lot less patience.

Initially, I tried to tell her that it is fine because I only watch informational videos at x1.5 speed and entertainment is still at regular speed. I was just trying to pick up facts. Therefore; there was no need to slow it down. Additionally, I didnâ€™t feel like I really had a problem and could easily slow it down and just watch lessÂ videos.

So I tried it. Today. I switched back to normal speed and played through some of my regular subscriptions. The first thing I noticed is how slow everyone seemed to talk. In fact, there were some people Iâ€™ve never even heard talking at a normal rateÂ before.

The second thing I noticed was how hard it was sometimes to just keep listening. I had this urge to do something while they were explaining. It felt like they just couldnâ€™t quite get to the point fast enough for my liking. Iâ€™d find myself skipping ahead a few times just to realize I missed some content and then having to backtrack.

Finally, when I got more accustomed to the speed, I realized how calming it is to listen to someone talk at a regular speed. No one was rushing anywhere and the world wasnâ€™t on fire. They were just saying what they wanted to say and I was an observer.

I think I might still reserve the x1.5 speed option for certain things. Maybe Iâ€™ll do it for technical presentations or something that tends to be extra boring. But the general rule for me now is to listen to people talk they way they intended to beÂ heard.

title: Minimalism and deprivation
content:encoded:
Speaking of minimalism! Itâ€™s important to qualify what it means. I think that a lot of people hear about this concept and assume right away that you are depriving yourself of things. Deprivation also takes a lot of will power. So even if someone thinks they can live with the deprivation, they are sure theyâ€™ll fail due to lack of willÂ power.

I want to tell you that itâ€™s completely wrong. There is no need for any will power what so ever (In fact, thatâ€™s a recipe for disaster but I digress. Iâ€™ll leave that for a later post). What it does take is a change in the state of mind. You must understand that having more does not mean being happier. Thatâ€™s something that you must also internalize.

Internalizing this concept is beyond the scope of this article but itâ€™s an absolute must. Once you do, everything else becomes so easy. Itâ€™s just so intuitive and second nature to dump the stuff you donâ€™t use. And as you dump it, you clear the house, you lower your mental maintenance cost and you lower your anxiety level. This becomes a reinforcing loop.

If, on the other hand, you approach this from the view of deprivation, youâ€™ll fail quickly. All youâ€™ll see is all the things youâ€™re missing while glossing over all the freedom you gained and happiness by subtraction.

My articles are rarely some sort of cohesive set of ideas that you can follow along with but I love how all these ideas from the FI community, minimalism, and happiness really overlap and come together so well. It proves to me once again that these are all correct. Itâ€™s sort of like science when you have a hypothesis about something and based on this hypothesis you keep seeing evidence in real life. It just makes your hypothesis that much more likely to beÂ true.

title: Surprising unintended consequences of Airbnb hosting
content:encoded:
Weâ€™ve been hosting on Airbnb for a full week now. However, my perfectionist wife has been setting up the room for a month prior to that. The possibility of someone giving us a three star rating is just too much to bear. Thankfully, weâ€™ve been getting only five star ratings soÂ far.

To ensure the five star rating keeps coming, weâ€™ve had to go through each corner of the basement and clear it out, rearrange the furniture and fix any outstanding nagging maintenance issues. As a result, weâ€™ve taken several trunk-loads of stuff straight to Goodwillâ€Šâ€”â€Šmostly random junk that was packed away in the basement, forgotten about and collecting dust.

The basement was also the place where our TV lived. We do not have another one upstairs. It is also the place where I kept my clothes. My wife graciously allowed me to keep my stuff in the basement while she took over the bedroom closet. It incorporated my own private bathroom as well. Weâ€™ve never had to worry where to keep my shaving paraphernalia versus her hair products.

Since weâ€™ve started renting the basement, things had to change. Weâ€™ve shifted from having 1600 square feet to 900. My clothes moved upstairs. Weâ€™ve had to isolate a small corner in the closet for me. The bathrooms were unified (it is going through a clean up process as I am writing this). Thereâ€™s also no more television.

Essentially, weâ€™ve forced ourselves into adopting a certain level of minimalism.

Minimalism was never the intention when considering Airbnb. Instead, I was always thinking about our TTF (time to financial independence). Thatâ€™s because Airbnb is the classic example of passivish income (I made that up). Your existing asset (the house) is doing most of the heavy lifting. You just need to remember to pay the bills. The more you automate, the more passive itÂ becomes.

One glance around here and youâ€™ll know right away that I am a huge fan of minimalism and intentional living. Thatâ€™s why it came to me as a very unexpected yet pleasant surprise when I realized I am forced to downsize substantially.

Before you jump to conclusions, this is not some personality disorder or twisted reasoning. I am not actively trying to induce self-harm. This is a very conscious decision. Ponder this idea of happiness through subtraction for example to see where Iâ€™m coming from. If youâ€™re still not convinced, thatâ€™s fine. Iâ€™ll have a lot more to say about minimalism in theÂ future.

In the mean time, for anyone thinking about their TTF, you should know there are some unintended consequences to Airbnb that go well beyond the money; intentional minimalism happens to be one ofÂ them.

title: Why would anyone reject a good idea
content:encoded:
Like any good Effai.me article, Iâ€™m going to call out of my friend publicly and then explain why heâ€™s wrong. In this case, this honour falls on my good friend Nick. Nick is a great guy. He is super smart. He is always looking to grow as an individual. Most importantly, he is open minded. We also happen to share a lot of interest in the world of personal finance, minimalism and happiness.

Nick and I decided to grab a bite at a wonderful Mexican establishment in the city. We sat down, ordered our drinks and chatted about what weâ€™ve been up to recently. Turns out, heâ€™s been reading Mr. Money Mustacheâ€™s blog for the last couple of weeks and really likes it. Heâ€™s just got one concern. Apparently, â€œMr. Money Mustache (Pete) is too extremeâ€.

Specifically, he was bothered by the idea that Pete hasnâ€™t spent any money on clothing in an entire year (at least according to his budget). Peteâ€™s choices of clothing revolved around free event t-shirts and some fashion advice from Costco. This did not resonate well with Nick. His look is much more sophisticated. Therefore; that idea of spending less on clothing was outright rejected.

I tried to reason with him. I told him that spending more on clothing wonâ€™t necessarily make him any happier (the happiness argument); that we tend to have piles of clothes we donâ€™t know what to do with (the minimalism argument); that itâ€™s a depreciating good we waste our money on but adds very little value (the money argument) and so on. Nothing worked. I just wasnâ€™t getting through toÂ him.

That left me wondering. How could a perfectly rational person not realize that not spending thousands of dollars a year on clothing is a perfectly legitimate way ofÂ living?

Of course, this article is not about a particular incident but an illustration of a much more common phenomena. Itâ€™s the phenomena of being presented with a perfectly valid argument for a great idea but failing to accept the (implied) conclusion. In other words, a great idea is rejected due to errors in judgment. So, after some deeper contemplation and inner examination I realized there are three distinct reasons someone could reject anÂ idea.

The idea is too novice. You have probably experienced this before. Someone is giving you advice on a topic you are far more familiar with. The idea is rudimentary, which youâ€™ve considered many times before and dismissed for good reasons. For example, if youâ€™ve just learned the difference between a traditional and Roth 401k, donâ€™t bother telling me about all the benefits of Roth. Iâ€™ve already considered them and chose to go with the traditional route.

It is not because your idea is bad or assumptions are wrong. In fact, itâ€™s great that you took the time to learn the difference (most people donâ€™t). Itâ€™s because Iâ€™ve done plenty of research on the topic and Iâ€™m comfortable with the concept. Roth is not a bad option. However, in many cases, the traditional route can be more advantageous. Itâ€™s a conscious decision.

The best part is that you know perfectly well when this is your reason for rejecting someoneâ€™s idea. You know it because you see the conclusion coming from a mile away. This is the best place to be since there is practically no risk that you are making a mistake. It is not a judgmentÂ error.

â€œLimiting beliefsâ€ are stopping me from adopting this idea. Iâ€™ll be honest. I borrowed this phrase from Ramit Sethi but the idea stands! This is actually a very deep concept that requires itâ€™s own article. However, for the sake of clarity I will summarize it asÂ follows:

It is the silent beliefs carried with you that dictate your actions. These beliefs tell you what you canâ€™tÂ do.

Itâ€™s a very powerful concept and I encourage everyone to explore it further (or wait for a follow up article). To further illustrate this, imagine being overweight your entire life. Obtaining a muscular physique is likely out of the realm of possibilities; mostly because you donâ€™t believe you can achieve it. The number of excuses can be endless. You can blame it on your genes; or your parents; or your hungry BFF. The common theme here is that you believe itâ€™s out of your control. Therefore; a limiting belief and an a likely error in judgment.

The idea conflicts with my life choices. When this happens, you must toy with the possibility that there was an error in your perception of the world; possibly your entire adult life; and at the risk of facing some serious cognitive dissonance. A second option is to find any and every possible reason to explain why that particular idea cannot work for you in your particular circumstances. The second option is the road most oftenÂ taken.

For instance, imagine we are talking about transportation and I am trying to convince you that you donâ€™t need a car. Iâ€™ll tell you about all the wonderful environmental benefits of not owning a car; the cash youâ€™ll save; the exercise youâ€™ll get; the longer life youâ€™ll enjoy. Iâ€™ll even present you with alternative modes of transportation you can use such as a bike or bus. Iâ€™ll even throw in the time youâ€™ll free up to read just like you always wanted so you could be the person you always thought you shouldÂ be.

What will your reaction be? If youâ€™re considering this idea, You have two choices. Either you must admit to yourself that maybe youâ€™re not that savvy, discerning, environmentally friendly consumer youâ€™ve always thought you were. You must also admit that since youâ€™ve started working, your commute was irrational. Alternatively, you can come up with every reason why that canâ€™t possibly work for you. The bus is irregular and unreliable. The bike can get a flat and you donâ€™t know how to fix it. You canâ€™t be late to work and your Uber driver can get lost in your neighbourhood. Thus; you justify the status quo instead of facing the hardÂ truth.

Keep in mind that it is distinctly different from a limiting belief. You are not rejecting the idea because of some â€œinvisible scriptâ€ running your life. You are rejecting the idea because its conclusion is too hard toÂ bear.

Whatâ€™s interesting about this error in judgement is how easy it is to identify it. All you have to do is look at your immediate reaction. Are you looking for a list of excuses as to why this wonâ€™t work for you? Is someone challenging your assumption and itâ€™s making you uncomfortable? Welcome my friend. Youâ€™re experiencing cognitive dissonance and you might want to reconsider yourÂ stance.

I have definitely used all three reasons when rejecting great ideas. Now that Iâ€™ve identified them, I hope it will be easier for me (and you) to notice them and make better decisions.

If youâ€™re wondering, I think my friend Nick was experiencing a conflict with his life choices. Iâ€™m sure he knows that spending thousands on clothing is not necessarily in his best interest. He also knows that money would be better spent buying an index fund. However, to admit that, he would also need to admit that he wasted thousands of dollars in the last 10 years. That would contradict his view of himself as a savvy consumer. Hence, itâ€™s easier to argue that refraining from spending thousands on clothes is extreme. Of course, this is assuming that what Mr. Money Mustache does is a goodÂ idea.

title: Second law of minimalism
content:encoded:
Iâ€™ll start off by admitting that it isnâ€™t really a law. Nor is it second since Iâ€™ve never established the first one. Itâ€™s more of an observation that I had recently regarding minimalist living and why itÂ works.

Now, youâ€™re probably vaguely familiar or remember the idea of the second law of thermodynamics. To summarize it in a non-sciencey way, itâ€™s essentially the idea that things tend towards disorder unless outside energy is applied. A good example of this is taking a bath. Initially, it is all nice and hot but after a while you realize the water has cooled down because the heat hasÂ escaped.

So what does that have to do with minimalism? I think you can draw a neat parallel between thermodynamics and ownership of things (or obligations). Itâ€™s also a great way to better understand twoÂ things

  1. Why are you unhappy with everything youÂ have
  2. How can having less possibly make youÂ happier

Letâ€™s imagine yourself owning a very basic set of dishes. You have nothing beyond a single plate, knife, fork and spoon. Also, washing dishes isnâ€™t exactly your favourite activity. Life is pretty tough. What can we do to improveÂ it?

One thing we can do is add a cup. Now youâ€™re able to enjoy water comfortably instead of trying to collect it in your hands. Sounds pretty great no? Your happiness should improve dramatically. I have no doubt that drinking water without a cup is adding a lot of unnecessary inefficiency to your life. This is also the overall thought process that people go through when determining if they need to purchase something orÂ not.

But thereâ€™s one thing weâ€™ve overlooked. We forgot to account for the cost of maintenance for this item. I use maintenance as a general form to refer to actions like storing the item, washing the item and finding the item. All trivial indeed but donâ€™t forget, all we have is one set of everything. In this case, the trivial maintenance cost is just that.Â Trivial.

Maintenance becomes a problem as the number of items that you own increases. Each of them providing a diminishing return for your convenience but increases the maintenance somewhat linearly. For example, getting another cup would mean another person can have a drink with me but all the above maintenance costs justÂ doubled.

This maintenance cost comes to us in two primary forms. The first is at the cost of our time. We have to spend time washing the cup and putting it away. But also, it comes in the form of mental clutter. This will arise when you donâ€™t take care of the maintenance tasks immediately and they start pillingÂ up.

You can extrapolate this further to all the items that you own. And you own A LOT. Like thousands a lot. Each may take 1â€“10 seconds in maintenance on average so together it takes a significant chunk of your day. And before you realize it, you spend a significant portion of your free time just putting things back together, finishing up unfinished projects and just basic cleaning. No wonder you donâ€™t have anyÂ time.

The second law of minimalism isÂ this:

Everything has itâ€™s cost. Make sure you understand itÂ well

title: Dumbphone alternative
content:encoded:
As a follow up to the previous post, one more â€œextremeâ€ thing Iâ€™ve been considering for a while was to switch completely from a smartphone back to an old school dumb phone. I find the idea very attractive. And it seems Iâ€™m not the only one either. It will ensure that my phone usage decreases dramatically while still giving me a way out in case Iâ€™m in trouble or if someone is looking to reachÂ me.

The problem is that dumb phones are missing certain key apps that I rely on heavily. For example, I like having Google maps for orientation. I mentioned this idea to my wife and to my surprise she questioned my basic assumptions. She asked me when was the last time I was suddenly lost. Could I not look up my path prior to going there and print out the directions? You know, like we used toÂ do.

Thatâ€™s a valid point. I think I like the idea of having maps a lot more then I actually need them. Iâ€™m certain thereâ€™s very few instances that I suddenly needed them because of some unforeseen circumstances. So whatâ€™s really holding meÂ back?

About a year and a half ago I discovered the x1.5 speed feature on YouTube and my world has been changed forever. No more would I have to suffer through slow talking TED talks or horribly paced tutorials on trivial matters. Itâ€™s really been a godsend for my learning. In fact, check out my YouTube viewing as a percentage of my overallÂ surfing:

Thatâ€™s almost a quarter of all my surfing!! Second in itâ€™s place is Twitter which Iâ€™m not as proudÂ of.

Now for the longest time I felt reasonably good about this. I always justified this behaviour by saying that this is for learning. I was technically wasting my time because I was constantly learning something new. This is actually true. There was no way I could consume as much content otherwise.

Recently though, my wife brought up the objection that if I keep watching my videos on x1.5 speed, Iâ€™ll rewire my brain to expect everything to be done that way. Iâ€™ll start talking faster; Iâ€™ll expect other to talk faster; and most importantly Iâ€™ll have a lot less patience.

Initially, I tried to tell her that it is fine because I only watch informational videos at x1.5 speed and entertainment is still at regular speed. I was just trying to pick up facts. Therefore; there was no need to slow it down. Additionally, I didnâ€™t feel like I really had a problem and could easily slow it down and just watch lessÂ videos.

So I tried it. Today. I switched back to normal speed and played through some of my regular subscriptions. The first thing I noticed is how slow everyone seemed to talk. In fact, there were some people Iâ€™ve never even heard talking at a normal rateÂ before.

The second thing I noticed was how hard it was sometimes to just keep listening. I had this urge to do something while they were explaining. It felt like they just couldnâ€™t quite get to the point fast enough for my liking. Iâ€™d find myself skipping ahead a few times just to realize I missed some content and then having to backtrack.

Finally, when I got more accustomed to the speed, I realized how calming it is to listen to someone talk at a regular speed. No one was rushing anywhere and the world wasnâ€™t on fire. They were just saying what they wanted to say and I was an observer.

I think I might still reserve the x1.5 speed option for certain things. Maybe Iâ€™ll do it for technical presentations or something that tends to be extra boring. But the general rule for me now is to listen to people talk they way they intended to beÂ heard.

title: Minimalism and deprivation
content:encoded:
Speaking of minimalism! Itâ€™s important to qualify what it means. I think that a lot of people hear about this concept and assume right away that you are depriving yourself of things. Deprivation also takes a lot of will power. So even if someone thinks they can live with the deprivation, they are sure theyâ€™ll fail due to lack of willÂ power.

I want to tell you that itâ€™s completely wrong. There is no need for any will power what so ever (In fact, thatâ€™s a recipe for disaster but I digress. Iâ€™ll leave that for a later post). What it does take is a change in the state of mind. You must understand that having more does not mean being happier. Thatâ€™s something that you must also internalize.

Internalizing this concept is beyond the scope of this article but itâ€™s an absolute must. Once you do, everything else becomes so easy. Itâ€™s just so intuitive and second nature to dump the stuff you donâ€™t use. And as you dump it, you clear the house, you lower your mental maintenance cost and you lower your anxiety level. This becomes a reinforcing loop.

If, on the other hand, you approach this from the view of deprivation, youâ€™ll fail quickly. All youâ€™ll see is all the things youâ€™re missing while glossing over all the freedom you gained and happiness by subtraction.

My articles are rarely some sort of cohesive set of ideas that you can follow along with but I love how all these ideas from the FI community, minimalism, and happiness really overlap and come together so well. It proves to me once again that these are all correct. Itâ€™s sort of like science when you have a hypothesis about something and based on this hypothesis you keep seeing evidence in real life. It just makes your hypothesis that much more likely to beÂ true.
