title: Why reaching goals make me no happier
content:encoded:
Lately, I started to realize that I am not happy. Donâ€™t get me wrong, I am not depressed (all my friends can testify!). In fact, I am happy, just not as much as I think I should be. Nothing is seriously wrong or need to be fixed about my life. I have a great paying job, amazing friends and brilliant co-workers, and I feel strong and healthy. Yet I still want to beÂ happier.

For the past week, I pursued a quest to measure my own happiness. This is surprisingly difficult. The feeling of happiness is not a boolean but a scale. I can roughly estimate an average of 7/10 daily happiness level. I wonder where the missing 3Â went.

Where does 7 came from, you may ask. I imagine my happiness point is derived from some sort of goal or task completion. It could be a small task like doing groceries or a bigger goal like getting a promotion. To explain my thought process better, I made a formula out ofÂ it.

Assume that one atomic unit of happiness is called joy. Each task or goal completion can spark X amount of joy based on level of challenge. My todo list on the weekend looks likeÂ this.

  • Water a plant = 5 joy after completion
  • Clean up my bathroom = 30 joy after completion
  • File taxes = 50 joy after completion
  • Complete my first blog on Medium = 100 joy after completion!

Letâ€™s say my threshold of happiness per day is at 100. If I complete everything in the list (even filing taxes!), I should have a very happy Saturday. Well, the truth is.. notÂ really.

The pure happiness I feel from achieving goals is only temporary. A better goal is contentment or fulfillment.

The formula above fails to capture the sense of fulfillment, which comes from having a purpose and being present in the moment. That is why focusing on goal completion alone is for amateurs. We need to feel consistent fulfillment throughout the journey to theÂ goal.

How should I represent fulfillment in this formula? Since fulfillment is all about enjoying the moment, it should perhaps be represented as joy gain per minute (as long as we feel happy in those minutes). As time progresses, total fulfillment is equal to the joy/min multiplied by the time spend. Letâ€™s try the formulaÂ again.

  • Watch Netflix (1 hour) = 1 joy/min + 0 joy after completion
  • File tax (3 hours) = 0 joy/min + 50 joy after completion
  • Complete my first blog on Medium (~5 hour) = 0.2 joy/min + 40 joy after completion!

You may argue that the fulfillment gain may not always progress linearly with time. For example, if my Medium post took more than 5 hours to write, I would gain no more fulfillment after the 5 hours past. I agree! Well, for the sake of simplicity, letâ€™s ignore that for now and assume only the upper bound of fulfillment that you can reach. Now letâ€™s categorize all tasks into one of the threeÂ buckets.

  • Highly fulfilling activity. The activities such as watching Netflix, or drinking with friends are highly fulfilling but provides zero achievement afterwards.
  • Pure achievement. These activities could be painful to go through but yield accomplishment afterward such as cooking, searching for a bike to buy, or filing tax. I wish I could just finish themÂ quickly.
  • Highly fulfilling with sense of achievement. I have only handful of these in my life such as reading a book, learning to snowboard, or writing this blogÂ post.

This lens is helpful to detach myself from the end-goal ultra focus, and constantly reminding myself to live in the moment. I start thinking of my day as the combination of 30% fulfillment and 70% achievement and started optimizing for the third bucket. Many mundane tasks like folding clothes or biking can also be extremely fulfilling and could be part of the bigger goal achievement (if you think about it hardÂ enough).

Slowly, I feel that completing the goal has become less important, but having the right balance is more crucial to my overall happiness.

Thank you for reading it this far. This post will not come about if I didnâ€™t have a great conversation with my best-friend, â€œMonique.â€ Also, special thanks to @osportfolio for his true inspirational blogs (and the proofreading!).

title: How I tidy my life
content:encoded:
I thoroughly enjoy an environment that is well-organized. One of my favorite spots in my house is the kitchen cabinet, which has dozen of mason jars lined up beautifully. What is invisible to the eyes is the work that has been done to keep them organized. It especially gets harder when I use and move the jars frequently. I have to tidy up faster than the mess isÂ formed.

That said, I can keep up well with the small cabinet, but not the entire house. In the book Life Changing Magic of Tidy Up, Mari-Kondo teached me the invaluable lesson on how to declutter. KonMari method comprises of two simpleÂ steps.

Discard first, thenÂ tidy.

Attempting to tidy everything would not work because within a few days everything will become cluttered again. Mari-Kondo suggests to Tidy in the right order. Always start with discard. Take each item in oneâ€™s hand andÂ ask

Does it sparkÂ joy?

If it does, keep it. If not, dispose of it. The things that spark true joy for you wonâ€™t always be rational. That is ok. If you are like me, you will find that majority of your possessions, unfortunately, donâ€™t spark joy. I ended up donating more than 50% of my clothes, 80% of books and documents, and so much more in the ten full garbage bags. In the process, I discovered which items were truly precious toÂ me.

Many of us keeps an item for fear of the future or to preserve the past. Letting go of things makes room for other things that matter more. Letting go makes tidying up significantly simpler.

The real lesson I learned here is far from where I started: letting go is more important than adding or tidying. One can live without tidying up, but one must learn how to let go. To me, the idea of decluttering a physical space prompts the need to declutter everything else such as my schedule, emotional needs, and mental state. I tried using KonMari approach on the following.

  • Relationship: Does the relationship with person X sparks joy? How do they make you feel? Again, the focus is not to unfriend everyone who doesnâ€™t spark joy, but to re-consider how to treat the most important people in oneâ€™s life who do. The more relationship you keep in the circle, the less time you have for each individual. Discarding a relationship means spending less time with some, but more withÂ others.
  • Activity/Event: Does the activity sparks joy? How do you feel doing such activity or attending such event? How do you like freeing those time to do something else? This question is the best way to respect your own time. When the calendar is clear, it opens a wide range of possibilities. Discarding an activity or event means declining it to enjoy theÂ freedom.
  • Thoughts/feelings: Does the thought sparks joy? This question is the most life-changing to me. It brought strong awareness into the mindset. Do I still want to think of X? Do I want to feel Y? Thoughts and feelings are the hardest to discard among all (it perhaps deserves its own blog post!). Discarding the thoughts and feelings means freeing up your mind for moreÂ clarity.

After decluttering, it is clear why life used to feel overwhelming. Holding on to too many things takes tremendous time and energy. It is intriguing how putting the house in order helps me find other missions that sparkÂ joy.

title: My state of the art system to goal setting
content:encoded:
I have yet to meet a person who was perfectly content with exactly who they were. Everyone is always trying to change something about themselves. The typical things includes the food they eat, the amount of exercise they get, how they spend their time and how they prioritize their lives. Turns out, change is harder than reading a blogÂ online.

People are also creatures of habit. We all have our morning routines, our night routines, our commute to work routine and the web sites we visit on our lunch break routine. In fact, when we are put in new environments where executing our routines is hard, we generally tend to skip workouts and eat fried chicken forÂ dinner.

I am going to share with you an approach that I use to form better habits. It is not fool proof. It does require some upfront investment. However, I believe it could work for almost any habit you are trying to form as long as you apply enough creativity. The system is very simple to apply. All you have to do is create a system. Yes, you read that right, the system is to create systems. Let meÂ explain.

When I say â€œsystemâ€, Iâ€™m talking about a set of rules, or guidelines you use to guide your choices. The side effect of those rules should be that you execute your desired habit. Think of these rules as formalizing a contract with yourself. The contract has at least one rule: I can have as much [A] as I want. However, before I get [A], I must do [B]. This is what I call a personal contract.

The inspiration came from Dr. BJ Fogg, a researcher in behaviour design who had a great TED talk a few years back about this exactÂ topic.

If you use an existing behaviour in your life, and you put the new, tiny behaviour after it, you can use the existing behaviour to be theÂ trigger.

Nonetheless, over time, I noticed that simply defining the contract wasnâ€™t always enough. Frequently, I couldnâ€™t uphold the contract for long or I would completely forget about it. In fact, it was really a hit or missâ€Šâ€”â€Šoccasionally it would work really well but periodically it would completely fallÂ apart.

More recently, I took a look at some personal contracts I was able to maintain for a long stretch and tried to boil it down to what made them different. I have identified four hallmarks of a good personal contract.

Automatic. If you can set this up for your desired habit, your job is practically done. For example, before I spend any money, I max out my 401k. I can automate this through my paycheque contributions. Done!

Unfortunately, itâ€™s not easy to automate certain areas of your life. Exercising effectively requires you to be doing exercise. Calling your mom once a week requires you to talk (at least forÂ now).

However, thereâ€™s a clear subset of bad habits that can be automated away. Anything digital will naturally fall here. Do you have bad browsing behaviour? Are you spending too much time on your Twitter/Facebook/YouTubeÂ ? Thereâ€™s an app for that. Are you having trouble saving or budgeting? Thereâ€™s a bank forÂ that.

The advantage of automating bad habits away is you only have that upfront cost once but you reap the dividends indefinitely.

Breaks down barriers. One habit that I recently found to be absolutely effortless is the habit of eating a healthy lunch. In the past, Iâ€™ve tried cooking at home or buying out healthy lunches but inevitably you skip cooking for a few nights and end up ordering a large barbacoa burrito at Chipotle. You do it enough times and getting back to cooking regularly becomes more and more unlikely.

How many barriers can you identify with my past system? First, cooking at home is a pain in the ass. Second, when buying food outside, there are far too many temptations. Third, even if I manage to convince myself to buy a salad, in the back of my mind Iâ€™m always thinking itâ€™s a bad a deal because Iâ€™ll stay hungry after thatÂ salad.

Here is my new approach: my current employer provides catered lunches every day. I made a personal contract with myself to eat a giant bowl of salad from the salad bar first. Once Iâ€™m finished with the bowl, I can have absolutely anything I want. There are no limits. This contract addresses all barriers Iâ€™ve had for eating a healthy lunch. I donâ€™t have to cook anything; I am not tempted by anything else since choices are limited; and I am not getting a bad deal because I can have anything I want afterwards. I just need to get through that bowl of salad first. As an added bonus, thereâ€™s very little I can eat once Iâ€™m done with the salad. I tend to be much more ambitious whenÂ hungry.

In general, try and identify all the little excuses you are giving yourself to stop doing what you really want to be doing. Once identified, try to design your life in a way that will break down those excuses in the most effortless way possible.

Other barriers usually include, distance, accessibility and ease of use. Watch out forÂ these.

Sets the correct incentive. You know how we said before you get [A] you must do [B]? Make sure that whatever [A] is, it is motivating enough to act as a trigger. If you remember reading my commitments for 2018, youâ€™ll recall that one of my commitments was to drink two cups of coffee a day. Unfortunately, Iâ€™ve noticed that as time goes on, I am creeping back to three cups. Each time I have it, I feel a little guilty but I reason that starting tomorrow Iâ€™ll be better. Instead of feeling guilt, I can turn this around and use it to my advantage.

I am a member of a gym located in the same building where I work. I am making the following personal contract: each time I feel like having a third cup of coffee, I must first hit the gym. The barriers to work out are exceedingly low and now I also have a great incentive to do the right thing (the fact that I made it public is aÂ bonus).

You can generalize this approach as well. Essentially, you sacrifice one minor bad habit to enforce and carry out a major good habit by setting up the right incentives for yourself.

Consistent with the individual. Sometimes, despite all the automation, best intentions, lowest barriers, and most enticing incentives, you still fail at your habit building; and thatâ€™sÂ okay.

Coming up with these systems is an iterative process. You will always be tinkering with them. Always trying something new. Always looking for a better way of doing things. Youâ€™ll never get it just right the very firstÂ time.

The key is to keep trying new ways of doing things and experimenting with what works for you. For example, a cup of coffee might be enough to motivate me to go to the gym. You might want a new pair of sneakers instead. If thatâ€™s your barrier, donâ€™t bother with my system. It wonâ€™t work forÂ you.

When I come up with great systems that work for me, I am always very proud and happy to shareâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust wait until I write my post about budgeting.

Let me know if you have a system you are particularly proud of. I am always looking to tweak mine and share withÂ others.

title: This is where I see myself in five years
content:encoded:
Actually, I canâ€™t see thatÂ far.

A couple of weeks ago I was having lunch with my friends Zack and Nina. I canâ€™t remember exactly what we were discussing but it must have been something interesting. It usually is. Suddenly, Zack asks me the following question:

Where do you see yourself in fiveÂ years?

I havenâ€™t been to an interview in a long time so I was caught off guard. I didnâ€™t have a good enough, well rehearsed and politically correct answer to give. Then again, I wasnâ€™t being actually interviewed for a job so I told him the honest truth. The truth is, I think that planning five years ahead is pointless if not counterproductive. I am sure that every lifestyle/productivity guru on the internet is having a meltdown right now. However, let meÂ explain.

Presumably, setting a long term goal means the outcome is important to you. It is probably something that will make you happy and make you feel like a more accomplished person. Or will it? Weâ€™ve talked about this before. What you think will make you happy doesnâ€™t always make you happy. You just may end up on the hamster wheel chasing the nextÂ goal.

More importantly, the goals that you set for yourself today might not even be applicable five years from now. Let me give you a concrete example. Iâ€™ll steal this one from Nina because it works out perfectly. She mentioned that one of her friends has five year goal to open up her own brewery. That sounds really fun right? However, how sure is this friend that brewing beer is what she really wants to do? Five years from now, her priorities could change completely. Has she spent enough time brewing beer for herself? Is she sure that running her own business is something that sheÂ wants?

Another mistake a lot of people make when setting their long term goals is making goals that are outside of their control. For example, you can set a goal for yourself to get married. Is that a good goal? I donâ€™t think so. Yes, one way to hand over more control to yourself is to lower your expectations but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s what you had in mind when committing to this five yearsÂ earlier.

So far Iâ€™ve just been warming up. Sure, all of the above is true, but the real reason five year goals are pointless is much simpler. The unpredictability of life makes it so. For example, five years ago I was happily living in Canada when all of a sudden I got an opportunity to work at a much fancier company for much fancier pay. All my five year plans had to be abandoned (if I had any). Two days ago my wife came back from Portugal and is convinced life is better over there. Whatâ€™s my five year planÂ now?

I can hear all the detractors from my couch grumbling under their breath about how I just donâ€™t understand the goal setting process. It doesnâ€™t have to be this specific or set in stone. Thatâ€™s true! However, how generic are you thinking? The reality is that once you make it somewhat generic, everyone wants roughly the same. Everyone wants to be healthier, stronger, better looking with a devoted spouse and a killer job. So what? How are you getting there? The devil is in theÂ details.

I am not here just to be a complainypants. I also like to propose solutions. So here it goes: Do whatever you do to set your five year goal but set it for only one year ahead. Do this every year. At the end of the year, reevaluate and readjust. A year is generally enough to set substantial but achievable goals. At the same time, when things changeâ€Šâ€”â€Šeither your surrounding or your opinionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou have plenty of opportunity to reevaluate what you value and where youâ€™reÂ heading.

You can experiment with shorter periods of time as well, however, I suspect that if you do this too frequently, you wonâ€™t be giving yourself enough time to complete the goal. At the same time, youâ€™ll be giving yourself a lot of opportunities to quit. One year seems like a good balance between some level of accountability and flexibility.

The key to make this recurring one year goal work is the reevaluation part of the process. Each year, you must check back on the goals you set for yourself in the beginning of year and evaluate your performance. Furthermore, reevaluate if you want to continue with this goal. Finally, and most importantly, step up the difficulty level of theÂ goal.

I think of this as â€œmanaged personal growthâ€. Open source portfolio of 2018 should be better in every way than Open source portfolio of 2017. If not, Open source portfolio wasted 2017. The only way I would know this is if I was accountable to myÂ goals.

Hereâ€™s my self grading forÂ 2017

Hereâ€™s my goals forÂ 2018

A nice and unexpected benefit from this system is that in 2022 Iâ€™ll get to see my 2017 goals and have a good laugh at how little I expected ofÂ myself.

title: Happiness: appealing to the like system
content:encoded:
Happiness: ask, and you shallÂ receive

Actionable items you can do today to engage your likeÂ system

This is part II of my discussion of â€œHappiness: the science behind your smileâ€. If you havenâ€™t read part I, I encourage you to do so here. Everything will make a lot more sense if youÂ do.

For those that have fully embraced the smartphone age and lack patience, hereâ€™s a quickÂ summary:

Turns out what we want is frequently separate from what we like. The things we desire in life do not always bring us happiness. This makes perfect sense from an evolutionary perspective. Evolution does not care about your happiness. Its only objective is to propagate your genes. Therefore; your ancestors were rewarded when competing for status and acquiring resources. However, to be happy, you cannot simply chase your desires. Those desires must also bring you long term contentment. You can do this only if you engage both the â€œwant systemâ€ and the â€œlikeÂ systemâ€.

Now that youâ€™re up to speed, letâ€™s digÂ in.

Shortly after publishing the first article about the two systems, my friend Zack asked me a really interesting question.

Whatâ€™s an actionable item I can do today to determine what will appeal to my â€œwantâ€ and â€œlikeâ€Â system?

Iâ€™ll be honest, I had to think long and hard about this one. My gut reaction was to write a piece bashing materialism and status seeking but I feel like itâ€™s not very satisfying. Itâ€™s hard to convince anyone that driving a brand new Tesla SUV to work on daily basis will not bring them more happiness in life. Also, as my wife frequently reminds me, â€œnot everyone wants to live like aÂ monkâ€.

Consequently, I had to step back and reconsider. What else can you do to engage the â€œlikeÂ systemâ€?

Weâ€™ve already established that people are terrible at predicting how much happiness their desires will bring them. We tend to overestimate the pleasure we will gain from positive experiences. Similarly we tend to overestimate the pain we will experience from negative experiences. However, I am aware of at least one method that seems to be somewhat more reliable than our own intuition. All you have to do is find someone who is at the same position you would like to be and ask them how theyÂ feel.

This might not be the bombshell you were expecting. However, the consequence of this idea is easy to overlook.

Consider for instance what you could do if you were buying a new house. You and your spouse might be looking for a 4 bedroom house at a near by suburb in a brand new development. It must have a 2 car garage and a ton of yard space to play ball with your future child. You will use the extra rooms as an office and an extra bedroom whenever your parents visit from out of town. Sure, it will increase your commute and the mortgage payments are a little high, but itâ€™s worthÂ it!

Sounds familiar? Thatâ€™s because it is exactly what a typical couple doesâ€Šâ€”â€Šat least around this part ofÂ town.

Before signing on the dotted line, and committing to 30 years of debt, you could ask a current home owner, roughly at the same stage of life, roughly with the same house, living in a similar neighborhood, what their day to day looks like. Do they have any regrets? Do they miss renting? How do they feel about Home Depot? What would they change if they could do it overÂ again?

They may tell you that itâ€™s incredible. Itâ€™s everything and more than they hoped for. They love entertaining friends on their brand new deck and all the neighbors are extremely friendly and pleasant. Itâ€™s the best decision they could have everÂ made.

Another possibility is that the commute is tough and stressful and the mortgage payments are stretching their finances further than they are comfortable. Maintaining it is also a dailyÂ grind.

Whatever the outcome, it is valuable information you didnâ€™t have before. According to Dan Gilbert, their response will also be a much better predictor of your future feelings than your own intuition.

Now letâ€™s take it a step further. What if you didnâ€™t just settle for asking people that are a single step ahead of you. What if you also asked people who are multiple steps ahead of you. For example, if your parents own their home, why not ask them? You could even use the same questions.

They may tell you it was a great investment and all their retirement savings are in the house. They were able to raise 2.6 children in that house and send them to the best public schools the department of education had toÂ offer.

Similarly, they could tell you they never once in 20 years walked into that office/bedroom without a feather duster and windex in their hands. They regret not buying a smaller house and using the extra money toÂ travel.

Again, valuable information but this time from a long term perspective.

Finally, you can take this advice to itâ€™s logical conclusion. I hesitate to write this because it is a morbid way to think. However, the insight is absolutely invaluable. I am talking about an article appropriately titled regrets of the dying. It took me a long time to read this partially because I couldnâ€™t get over how morbid it is. However, I highly encourage everyone to give it a chance. Once I got through it, I realized that the fear of regret is a very powerful reason to live right. It was also indirectly responsible for this article (and many others toÂ come).

The regrets are of course very emotional and human. I think that all of us can predict at least half of them if we just sat down and tried to list them. Yet there is something powerfully contemplative even as I re-readÂ them.

One regret I think would resonate with everyone is #4â€Šâ€”â€ŠI wish I had stayed in touch with my friends. This is something that could haunt you your entire life unless you devote a lot of concentrated effort to maintain these relationships. One major reason for this is our endless mobility. It is certainly a great opportunity to meet wonderful people. However, the relationships you form tend to be more shallow. Once â€œbusynessâ€ catches up with you, those are the first toÂ go.

This is a focus area for myself although I will make it more official in my 2019 resolutions.

So what would these people tell you about your house choices if you somehow managed to ask them? I cannot speak for them authoritatively, but my guess is theyâ€™d tell you to live your life and stop wasting your time on this shit because it really doesnâ€™tÂ matter.

title: Happiness: our want system vs like system
content:encoded:
There is a whole section on Amazonâ€Šâ€”â€Šor if youâ€™re like me, your local book storeâ€Šâ€”â€Šfor â€œself-helpâ€. Thatâ€™s the section I like to visit. There, youâ€™ll find books like â€œYou are a bad assâ€ and â€œThe subtle art of not giving a fuckâ€ trending at the top, telling you how to live a better life. An appealing proposition in my opinion. Moreover, as weâ€™ve discussed before, reading daily is aÂ must.

One of the subjects I like most under â€œself-helpâ€ is the subject of happiness. It always intrigued me. If someone figured out how to eliminate heartache and sadness and live in a constant euphoria, I want to know! Turns out, itâ€™s an active topic of research with lotâ€™s of published data.

Now, Iâ€™ve always felt like I had a good natural intuition for happiness. Somehow, the idea of spending on fancy vacations or luxurious experiences never resonated with me quite the same way. I knew that inherently, spending my way to bliss wasnâ€™t going to work; or at the very least, it was going to be very expensive. You can imagine how happy I was when science seemed to agree withÂ me.

Happiness

I just finished reading â€œHappiness, the science behind your smileâ€. It is another book reciting more or less what I already knew from other books on the subject. However, It also had a surprising number of insightful observations I never heard before. One of the insights was regarding our â€œwant systemâ€ vs our â€œlikeÂ systemâ€.

What is a â€œwant systemâ€ you ask? Great question. Letâ€™s break itÂ down.

Turns out, things that we want in life, like fancy cars, big houses and so forth, do not always make us happier. If we could somehow measure our present life satisfaction, then go out and buy a new car, several months later, our life satisfaction would be more or less the same. The sciency term for that is hedonic adaptation. In fact, the single best predictor of your life satisfaction a decade from now is not your job, education, house or marital status. It is your life satisfaction today.

In a similar fashion, we have a â€œlike systemâ€. That refers to those things in life that make us happy (things we like). Health, freedom, and respect are all qualities that seem to raise our life satisfaction. Yet, there are plenty of cases when we are working actively against reaching these qualities. For example, everyone knows they should exercise and eat healthy to maintain their health. However, the only time people are motivated enough to eat healthy is a month before a beach vacation.

It follows that these two systemsÂ are

  1. Distinct
  2. Could potentially send opposingÂ signals

A perfect example of this would be volunteering. People that volunteer their time for causes they care about deeply report being happier. Yet there are millions of people everyday who come home and play Xbox (Not sure if Xbox players report being happier).

From an evolutionary perspective, this makes perfect sense. Evolution doesnâ€™t give two hoots about your happiness. Evolution needs you to propagate your genes. Therefore; adapting to your current situation and constantly striving for the next great thing is completely natural. That explains why itâ€™s so hard to be happy with what you have. Youâ€™re simply not designedÂ to.

Thatâ€™s not to say that the two systems will always mislead you and diverge. There are many cases when the two systems align. For example, socializing. Our â€œwant systemâ€ generally agrees with our â€œlike systemâ€. We tend to want to go out and meet our friends and we seem to enjoy our time when weÂ do.

Another example is marriage. Married people report higher life satisfaction than their single counterparts. That makes sense. Who wants to be alone forever? Of course, itâ€™s also possible that happier people tend to get married more frequently simply because they are more pleasant; an attribution biasÂ ğŸ˜•.

So what can you do with this information? I think this can be seen as another framework for making decisions. You evaluate the decision based on what system it appeals to. If it appeals to both, great! Easy win. Continue with what you were doing. If it appeals to one but not the other, maybe itâ€™s a time to step back and re-evaluate. Do you really need to purchase that new iPhone? Should you call your mother or finish reading that article onÂ CNN?

Or you can always donate all your worldly possessions and go live in a forestÂ ğŸŒ².

title: Why would anyone reject a good idea
content:encoded:
Like any good Effai.me article, Iâ€™m going to call out of my friend publicly and then explain why heâ€™s wrong. In this case, this honour falls on my good friend Nick. Nick is a great guy. He is super smart. He is always looking to grow as an individual. Most importantly, he is open minded. We also happen to share a lot of interest in the world of personal finance, minimalism and happiness.

Nick and I decided to grab a bite at a wonderful Mexican establishment in the city. We sat down, ordered our drinks and chatted about what weâ€™ve been up to recently. Turns out, heâ€™s been reading Mr. Money Mustacheâ€™s blog for the last couple of weeks and really likes it. Heâ€™s just got one concern. Apparently, â€œMr. Money Mustache (Pete) is too extremeâ€.

Specifically, he was bothered by the idea that Pete hasnâ€™t spent any money on clothing in an entire year (at least according to his budget). Peteâ€™s choices of clothing revolved around free event t-shirts and some fashion advice from Costco. This did not resonate well with Nick. His look is much more sophisticated. Therefore; that idea of spending less on clothing was outright rejected.

I tried to reason with him. I told him that spending more on clothing wonâ€™t necessarily make him any happier (the happiness argument); that we tend to have piles of clothes we donâ€™t know what to do with (the minimalism argument); that itâ€™s a depreciating good we waste our money on but adds very little value (the money argument) and so on. Nothing worked. I just wasnâ€™t getting through toÂ him.

That left me wondering. How could a perfectly rational person not realize that not spending thousands of dollars a year on clothing is a perfectly legitimate way ofÂ living?

Of course, this article is not about a particular incident but an illustration of a much more common phenomena. Itâ€™s the phenomena of being presented with a perfectly valid argument for a great idea but failing to accept the (implied) conclusion. In other words, a great idea is rejected due to errors in judgment. So, after some deeper contemplation and inner examination I realized there are three distinct reasons someone could reject anÂ idea.

The idea is too novice. You have probably experienced this before. Someone is giving you advice on a topic you are far more familiar with. The idea is rudimentary, which youâ€™ve considered many times before and dismissed for good reasons. For example, if youâ€™ve just learned the difference between a traditional and Roth 401k, donâ€™t bother telling me about all the benefits of Roth. Iâ€™ve already considered them and chose to go with the traditional route.

It is not because your idea is bad or assumptions are wrong. In fact, itâ€™s great that you took the time to learn the difference (most people donâ€™t). Itâ€™s because Iâ€™ve done plenty of research on the topic and Iâ€™m comfortable with the concept. Roth is not a bad option. However, in many cases, the traditional route can be more advantageous. Itâ€™s a conscious decision.

The best part is that you know perfectly well when this is your reason for rejecting someoneâ€™s idea. You know it because you see the conclusion coming from a mile away. This is the best place to be since there is practically no risk that you are making a mistake. It is not a judgmentÂ error.

â€œLimiting beliefsâ€ are stopping me from adopting this idea. Iâ€™ll be honest. I borrowed this phrase from Ramit Sethi but the idea stands! This is actually a very deep concept that requires itâ€™s own article. However, for the sake of clarity I will summarize it asÂ follows:

It is the silent beliefs carried with you that dictate your actions. These beliefs tell you what you canâ€™tÂ do.

Itâ€™s a very powerful concept and I encourage everyone to explore it further (or wait for a follow up article). To further illustrate this, imagine being overweight your entire life. Obtaining a muscular physique is likely out of the realm of possibilities; mostly because you donâ€™t believe you can achieve it. The number of excuses can be endless. You can blame it on your genes; or your parents; or your hungry BFF. The common theme here is that you believe itâ€™s out of your control. Therefore; a limiting belief and an a likely error in judgment.

The idea conflicts with my life choices. When this happens, you must toy with the possibility that there was an error in your perception of the world; possibly your entire adult life; and at the risk of facing some serious cognitive dissonance. A second option is to find any and every possible reason to explain why that particular idea cannot work for you in your particular circumstances. The second option is the road most oftenÂ taken.

For instance, imagine we are talking about transportation and I am trying to convince you that you donâ€™t need a car. Iâ€™ll tell you about all the wonderful environmental benefits of not owning a car; the cash youâ€™ll save; the exercise youâ€™ll get; the longer life youâ€™ll enjoy. Iâ€™ll even present you with alternative modes of transportation you can use such as a bike or bus. Iâ€™ll even throw in the time youâ€™ll free up to read just like you always wanted so you could be the person you always thought you shouldÂ be.

What will your reaction be? If youâ€™re considering this idea, You have two choices. Either you must admit to yourself that maybe youâ€™re not that savvy, discerning, environmentally friendly consumer youâ€™ve always thought you were. You must also admit that since youâ€™ve started working, your commute was irrational. Alternatively, you can come up with every reason why that canâ€™t possibly work for you. The bus is irregular and unreliable. The bike can get a flat and you donâ€™t know how to fix it. You canâ€™t be late to work and your Uber driver can get lost in your neighbourhood. Thus; you justify the status quo instead of facing the hardÂ truth.

Keep in mind that it is distinctly different from a limiting belief. You are not rejecting the idea because of some â€œinvisible scriptâ€ running your life. You are rejecting the idea because its conclusion is too hard toÂ bear.

Whatâ€™s interesting about this error in judgement is how easy it is to identify it. All you have to do is look at your immediate reaction. Are you looking for a list of excuses as to why this wonâ€™t work for you? Is someone challenging your assumption and itâ€™s making you uncomfortable? Welcome my friend. Youâ€™re experiencing cognitive dissonance and you might want to reconsider yourÂ stance.

I have definitely used all three reasons when rejecting great ideas. Now that Iâ€™ve identified them, I hope it will be easier for me (and you) to notice them and make better decisions.

If youâ€™re wondering, I think my friend Nick was experiencing a conflict with his life choices. Iâ€™m sure he knows that spending thousands on clothing is not necessarily in his best interest. He also knows that money would be better spent buying an index fund. However, to admit that, he would also need to admit that he wasted thousands of dollars in the last 10 years. That would contradict his view of himself as a savvy consumer. Hence, itâ€™s easier to argue that refraining from spending thousands on clothes is extreme. Of course, this is assuming that what Mr. Money Mustache does is a goodÂ idea.

title: This is where I see myself in five years
content:encoded:
Actually, I canâ€™t see thatÂ far.

A couple of weeks ago I was having lunch with my friends Zack and Nina. I canâ€™t remember exactly what we were discussing but it must have been something interesting. It usually is. Suddenly, Zack asks me the following question:

Where do you see yourself in fiveÂ years?

I havenâ€™t been to an interview in a long time so I was caught off guard. I didnâ€™t have a good enough, well rehearsed and politically correct answer to give. Then again, I wasnâ€™t being actually interviewed for a job so I told him the honest truth. The truth is, I think that planning five years ahead is pointless if not counterproductive. I am sure that every lifestyle/productivity guru on the internet is having a meltdown right now. However, let meÂ explain.

Presumably, setting a long term goal means the outcome is important to you. It is probably something that will make you happy and make you feel like a more accomplished person. Or will it? Weâ€™ve talked about this before. What you think will make you happy doesnâ€™t always make you happy. You just may end up on the hamster wheel chasing the nextÂ goal.

More importantly, the goals that you set for yourself today might not even be applicable five years from now. Let me give you a concrete example. Iâ€™ll steal this one from Nina because it works out perfectly. She mentioned that one of her friends has five year goal to open up her own brewery. That sounds really fun right? However, how sure is this friend that brewing beer is what she really wants to do? Five years from now, her priorities could change completely. Has she spent enough time brewing beer for herself? Is she sure that running her own business is something that sheÂ wants?

Another mistake a lot of people make when setting their long term goals is making goals that are outside of their control. For example, you can set a goal for yourself to get married. Is that a good goal? I donâ€™t think so. Yes, one way to hand over more control to yourself is to lower your expectations but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s what you had in mind when committing to this five yearsÂ earlier.

So far Iâ€™ve just been warming up. Sure, all of the above is true, but the real reason five year goals are pointless is much simpler. The unpredictability of life makes it so. For example, five years ago I was happily living in Canada when all of a sudden I got an opportunity to work at a much fancier company for much fancier pay. All my five year plans had to be abandoned (if I had any). Two days ago my wife came back from Portugal and is convinced life is better over there. Whatâ€™s my five year planÂ now?

I can hear all the detractors from my couch grumbling under their breath about how I just donâ€™t understand the goal setting process. It doesnâ€™t have to be this specific or set in stone. Thatâ€™s true! However, how generic are you thinking? The reality is that once you make it somewhat generic, everyone wants roughly the same. Everyone wants to be healthier, stronger, better looking with a devoted spouse and a killer job. So what? How are you getting there? The devil is in theÂ details.

I am not here just to be a complainypants. I also like to propose solutions. So here it goes: Do whatever you do to set your five year goal but set it for only one year ahead. Do this every year. At the end of the year, reevaluate and readjust. A year is generally enough to set substantial but achievable goals. At the same time, when things changeâ€Šâ€”â€Šeither your surrounding or your opinionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou have plenty of opportunity to reevaluate what you value and where youâ€™reÂ heading.

You can experiment with shorter periods of time as well, however, I suspect that if you do this too frequently, you wonâ€™t be giving yourself enough time to complete the goal. At the same time, youâ€™ll be giving yourself a lot of opportunities to quit. One year seems like a good balance between some level of accountability and flexibility.

The key to make this recurring one year goal work is the reevaluation part of the process. Each year, you must check back on the goals you set for yourself in the beginning of year and evaluate your performance. Furthermore, reevaluate if you want to continue with this goal. Finally, and most importantly, step up the difficulty level of theÂ goal.

I think of this as â€œmanaged personal growthâ€. Open source portfolio of 2018 should be better in every way than Open source portfolio of 2017. If not, Open source portfolio wasted 2017. The only way I would know this is if I was accountable to myÂ goals.

Hereâ€™s my self grading forÂ 2017

Hereâ€™s my goals forÂ 2018

A nice and unexpected benefit from this system is that in 2022 Iâ€™ll get to see my 2017 goals and have a good laugh at how little I expected ofÂ myself.

title: My favourite part of new year
content:encoded:
2018 is just a few days away. That means my favourite time of year is coming. Itâ€™s that special time when you make new year resolutions which you will break in February. All the good intentions and wishful thinking that comes head to head with the cold hard reality. What a beautiful thing.

Since Iâ€™m painfully aware of how hard it is to stick to new year resolutions, over the years Iâ€™ve come up with a pretty intricate system of rules and reminders to allow me to meet my goals. This is going to be a short summary of how I make my new year resolutions and a plea for all of you dear readers to come up with yourÂ own.

Letâ€™s start with what you shouldnâ€™t do. You should not, by any means, make bullshit new year resolutions. Iâ€™m talking about resolutions such as â€œbe happy with what I haveâ€ or â€œbe kinder to myselfâ€ (You know who Iâ€™m talking about). This sort of resolutions are completely useless for twoÂ reasons.

First, resolutions should not be abstract. It has to be something reasonably concrete. Ideally something that you can point to and say, look I did that. For example, completing a certain long standing project would be a very concrete goal whose success you canÂ measure.

Second, it needs to be something you can break up into smaller steps. That way you can implement it throughout the year. For example, if you want to read 12 books in 2018, each book would be a step that brings you closer to your goal. Being kind to yourself is a failure on both criteria.

But enough with negativity. Letâ€™s talk about what you should do. Since Iâ€™m old, with a vast amount of experience through my years of failure, Iâ€™ve discovered one key attribute that will make meeting your new year resolutions 10 times easier. The key to meetings them is accountability.

Yes I know, itâ€™s a pretty obvious statement but it doesnâ€™t tell much does it? So hereâ€™s the three things that I did in 2017 and found extremely helpful.

Write your goals down. To be honest, Iâ€™ve read more books than I can count that advised me to write something down on a piece of paper. I never did. Itâ€™s a pain in the ass. Not to mention Iâ€™ll probably lose the paper. However, writing down your goals is important because youâ€™re likely going to forget them. Unless of course youâ€™re always wishing to loseÂ weight.

Additionally, writing them down can be really easy in something like Google Sheets. You pop it open, write a few things and itâ€™s saved for eternity. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve done. As a side benefit, if you keep up this habit, you get to see what you were trying to achieve over the years as long as you reuse the same spreadsheet.

Write down the steps for each goal. So remember what not to do #2? Make sure you do the opposite when picking your goals and then in that same spreadsheet, under each goal, write down the practical steps you can do to meet your goal. For example, if your goal is to take better care of your health, you can list things like work out frequency and diet changes that you will be implementing as part of theÂ goal.

Grade yourself regularly. Hereâ€™s how it works. Open up whatever calendar you use and create a recurring event once every two months to remind you to check in on your goals. Each time you check in, give yourself a grade for each step and an overall grade for the goal itself. This works well because you get a regular reminder of what it is that you were trying to do for theÂ year.

The conventional way of declaring a new year resolution on December 31st fizzles out quickly as life piles on with commitments and obligations. I would argue that most people canâ€™t even remember their new year resolution from 2016 and definitely not from 2015. By reminding yourself what you wanted to achieve for the year, each time you veer off course, you get an opportunity toÂ realign.

I have a check in coming up on December 28th for all my resolutions for 2017. Iâ€™ll post them on the blog together with my resolutions for next year. StayÂ tuned.

title: Self fulfilling prophecies
content:encoded:
Yesterday I hosted a bunch of my friends at my house and we ended up in a long discussion about having children, age and work. Nothing unusual so far and thatâ€™s more or less what youâ€™d expect people our age to talk about. It was a great night and it was nice to catch up with everyone. While talking specifically about children and inquiring about why anyone wanted them, one thing that was brought up very casually and without much resistance from the rest of the room was the idea that they will be there to teach you things. Sort of the way I do with my mom and you do with your mom andÂ dad.

Now, thereâ€™s absolutely nothing wrong with learning from your kids. If my kid ends up being a surgeon, I would love to get her opinion about all sorts of health related issues. After all, she has medical training and I donâ€™t. But despite their denial, that was not what my friends were trying to say at all. Instead, it was this underlying assumption that once you got old, youâ€™re just not expected to perform well. Both mentally and physically. And itâ€™s normal. If I was to challenge that idea, obviously theyâ€™d deny it but you could tell this was the assumption going into the conversation based on the context and where it wasÂ going.

Iâ€™m not going to pretend that once you hit 30, you are not less likely to make it to the NBA if you havenâ€™t yet. Thereâ€™s definitely diminishing physical abilities after a certain age (with very notable exceptions). But what bothers me is the lack of any sort of attempt to compensate for that. If youâ€™re worried about your physical performance as you hit 50, why not double your gym time instead of just throwing your hands up in the air and say â€œthatâ€™s just the way it isâ€. I guarantee you there are people double my age who can bench press twice my weight. They just have a different attitude.

Similarly, I think that people that expect less mentally from older people, will expect less from themselves when their older. In turn, their abilities to understand and learn will quickly diminish with age. On the other hand, thereâ€™s older people who are still brilliant and who are able to maintain their mental clarity until their last day. What makes them so different? I think to some extent itâ€™s their attitude.

Thatâ€™s exactly the kind of attitude I want to cultivate in myself. I donâ€™t think that when Iâ€™m 50 Iâ€™ll bench press less. I think Iâ€™ll bench press more. When Iâ€™m 50, I wonâ€™t be taking 10 pills a day. Iâ€™ll take none. Iâ€™ll feel great and Iâ€™m sure of it. I just need to make sure that I take care of myself now. This is the kind of attitude I would expect everyone toÂ have.

title: How to stop corporate bailouts forever
content:encoded:
And how can you do it without government intervention

I joined the workforce around July 2008. I was looking forward to earning money. My pay was going to be in the thousands. I was excited to wear dress shirts and pants and walk around downtown looking important. It was a big change from my university days. Then the recession happened.

I wasnâ€™t knowledgeable enough to understand it at the time. I know some people struggled to find work. My dad lost his job. It would take him another 8 months to find another. I, on the other hand, being a phenomenal performer, was spared (thankfully).

I do remember the protests on wall street and all the TV coverage they got. They called themselves the 99%. I must have been one ofÂ them.

We were angry about the bailouts. The bankers were saved from bankruptcy despite being responsible for the crashâ€Šâ€”â€Šand our money was used to saveÂ them!

It certainly seemed unfair toÂ me.

But what could we do? Letting these companies fail would mean the loss of thousands of additional jobs. â€œIt would cripple the economyâ€.

We also set a certain expectation. The corporations now understood: once you got large enough, the tax payer will bail you out. We even coined the term â€œtoo big toÂ failâ€.

Last week, my friend Ivan and I were discussing this exact topic. What could we do about it? And how could we have avoided this? This time however, being more mature and sophisticated, Iâ€™ve had the clarity to voice an alternative opinion. I thought it would be good to share it here with you, dear audience.

Ask yourself, what does GEICO do to insure your claim? They charge a premium of course. You pay a monthly fee for the insurance that someone will cover you in case of a loss. Naturally, you cover for large losses that would hurt you financially.

You might see where Iâ€™m going withÂ this.

We can determine which companies are â€œtoo big to failâ€; we can use an income or employee count threshold or another metric (or a combination). Once a company crosses that income level (or employee count), each additional dollar earned would be subject to double the taxÂ rate.

Before all my libertarian friends lose their shit, let meÂ explain.

You can view the additional tax as a premium paid into a bailout fund. In case of gross mismanagement and undue risk, the responsibility of bailing out these large corporation doesnâ€™t fall on the tax payer but on the companies themselves.

In reality, no prudent corporation would be willing to pay more tax than necessary. Instead, as the corporation approaches this limit, they will likely split into sub-units.

Amazon would become Amazon AWS and Amazon Retail; Microsoft would become Microsoft Office and Microsoft Windows, Walmart would become Walmart East and Walmart West. You get theÂ idea.

Iâ€™d be lying if I told you I came up with this idea myself. This is taken from Nassim Nicholas Taleb and his excellent book â€œThe Black Swanâ€ (no relation to theÂ movie).

The Black Swan

For every great idea, thereâ€™s going to be some detractors.

For Google or Amazon the 'break them up!' argument is even less coherent, since these companies do not have clearly separate divisions with stand-alone viability. Breaking up Amazon is like breaking up Walmart - into what? Fruit in one company and vegetables in another?

 — @benedictevans

I find this tweet ridiculous. You really canâ€™t think of a way to break up Amazon? Amazon does everything.

And Google? It happens to be a great example of this principalâ€Šâ€”â€Šalthough in a much milder form. It has a holding company, Alphabet, and it spins out experimental companies, Waymo, Sidewalk Labs,Â etc.

Also, no company is forced to spin out every single line of business they have. If a business isnâ€™t mature yet to stand on its ownâ€Šâ€”â€Šif itâ€™s a money loser for exampleâ€Šâ€”â€Škeep it. Every decision is completely up to the board and shareholders.

Finally, some people are worried that large companies will lose their competitive advantage; efficiencies of scale or something along those lines. Maybe. But thatâ€™s debatable. It could equally play out in the opposite direction.

Imagine for instance if Amazon decided to spin out its warehousing operations. Wouldnâ€™t other companies benefit from all the efficiencies gained byÂ Amazon?

You might be asking if a company would even bother investing in innovation if theyâ€™ll spin it off. My answer to you is of course! The investment in innovation doesnâ€™t just disappear. It is sold. A shareholder with one share of Amazon, after the split, would end up with one share of Amazonâ€Šâ€”â€Špriced X dollars lowerâ€” and one share of the new companyâ€Šâ€”â€Špriced at X. Thatâ€™s just how spin offsÂ work.

The end result of such policy is no corporate bailouts, no Dodd, no Frank, no endless bickering, no bureaucrats and no government agencies. This is a way to create the right incentives for the companies to behave while making our economy Antifragile (or at leastÂ robust).

Antifragile

title: Who the hell needs 140 billion dollars?
content:encoded:
First, a quick primer: Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, is currently the richest man in the worldâ€Šâ€”â€Šand by a wide margin. As of the latest Google search, his net worth exceeds $140 billion dollars. Thatâ€™s billion with aÂ â€˜Bâ€™.

I was chatting with my neighbour Esther the other day about her upcoming move to Portland. Turns out the hot housing market in Seattle created irresistible conditions for a post-retirement, single woman to move to a cheaper cost of living area. As a side benefit, she will also be much closer to her kids. While Iâ€™m sad to see her go, I canâ€™t help but feel excited about what that means for the value of my own house across the street. That feeling really makes up for herÂ loss.

If you live in Seattle, and youâ€™re not talking about the housing market, the next natural topic to bring up is the homeless situation which we turned to next. We both noticed a significant uptick in homelessness around the neighbourhood. We both agreed that it is being mishandled and something must be done. She even suggested Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, should do something about it. After all, â€œHeâ€™s got $100 billion dollars. Who needs that kind ofÂ money?â€.

Wait a secondÂ â€¦

â€œWho needs that kind ofÂ money?â€

Now I have a problem with that. Donâ€™t get me wrong. I donâ€™t disagree that $100 (now $140) billion dollars is an absurd amount of money to have. I donâ€™t disagree that he is probably financially independent; that he could retire early; that he doesnâ€™t need to worry about skyrocketing health care costs and a single day fluctuation in his net worth is more money than Iâ€™ll see in a lifeÂ time.

What I do disagree with is the following: Since when are we in the business of deciding whoâ€™s hadÂ enough?

There is a multitude of reasons why the statement above is wrongâ€Šâ€”â€Šboth politically, economically and morally. Many of which are out of scope for this article. I do want to focus on one in particular though.

Jeff Bezos started a company. He created a great product. Millions of people are using it everyday. He revolutionized many industries. He created thousands of jobs. The money is his reward. Is the reward large? yes. But so is his impact. We are talking about an $800 billion dollarÂ company.

Was there any coercion? Did anyone force us to hand over our hard earned money to him? Did he do anything illegal? Did you truly love Barnes &Â Noble?

No. In fact, we did it all out of our own freeÂ will.

Would it be great if Jeff decided to shower the city of Seattle with hundred dollar bills until the entire homeless population and all our city representatives are living inÂ luxury?

Yes, that would be great. If so heÂ chooses.

One of the great things about living in a free society is the freedom to choose. Jeff can decide to spend his money any way he wants to. You may have even seen the following tweet:

Request for ideas...

 — @JeffBezos

A path towards a free society must be a path that letâ€™s the individual direct their own destiny. The opposite leads down a very darkÂ road.

title: Mortgage interest deduction lies
content:encoded:
As some of you know, to stimulate home ownership in the United States, the government created a scheme where by you get to deduct the interest portion of your mortgage payments from your income to reduce it for tax purposes. Effectively, this means that the interest is paid using pretax dollars. Great! letâ€™s all go buyÂ houses.

Not so fast. Take anyone with any sort of economic sense and they will tell you there is no free lunch here. Youâ€™re not getting stuff cheaper. By subsidizing the payments, the government simply pushed the prices of housing up for everyone. If you donâ€™t believe me, answer this question: What do you think would happen if this was taken away now? If you said people would freak out and the prices would fall because payments are higher then reverse this argument.

Alright, so we know governments generally canâ€™t get shit right and a lot of policies are misguided. Does that mean this one is also just a big fat waste of money? Thatâ€™s sort of what I thought. At least until yesterday. Yesterday, I watched thisÂ video:

There were a couple of interesting points of conversation there. One in particular that caught my attention though was regarding this exact topic and your level of taxation. You see, since every owner gets to take advantage of this particular piece of policy, they save at the same rate as their marginal tax rate. On the other hand, the amount that this house went up in price due to this particular policy is roughly equal to the overall average marginal tax rate in the UnitedÂ States.

So what does that mean? That means that if you are at a higher margin tax rate then the average population, youâ€™d save money based on this policy. If youâ€™re in a lower tax bracket, you lose. The only additional point Iâ€™d like to make is that it is probably the average margin tax rate of an average house buyer. The poorest citizens probably keepÂ renting.

So this entire policy is not only making housing more expensive for everyone, but it is oddly also a subsidy for the rich by theÂ poor.

Iâ€™m not talking about tax cuts here that are great for everyone but happen to benefit the rich more (due to their larger tax bill in the first place). This is literally a transfer from the poor to theÂ rich.

title: A non boring advice about your employee stock purchase plan
content:encoded:
This is the best thing you can do with yourÂ money

My employer offers many generous perks. One of them is called an ESPP or employee stock purchase plan. It is a scheme by which the employer incentivizes you to purchase its stock using a portion of your salary. The incentive is usually some sort of a discount or topÂ up.

One question that frequently comes up is what to do once the shares are vested into yourÂ account.

You can go down one of two roads. First, you can sell all the shares immediately and purchase something else. Spoiler alert, Iâ€™m in thisÂ camp.

Second, you can keep theÂ shares.

The reasoning for keeping the shares is actually quite solid. If youâ€™ve made money on the stock market and youâ€™ve held the shares for less than a year, you are subject to good old fashion income tax. If, on the other hand, you held it for more than a year, you are subject to shiny new capital gains tax; and you guessed it, the shiny new capital gains taxes are usuallyÂ lower.

This is exactly the argument I was having with my friend Aaron at work yesterday. Our shares from ESPP are set to vest in November and he was inquiring about my plans for the money. I told him I was going to sell everything and purchase a boring and dull index fund. He told me I was crazy for throwing my moneyÂ away.

This discussion went on for longer then I am ready to admit but I thought I can summarize the lessons here. Also, since this is my blog, my opinion isÂ right.

Letâ€™s start with an example: Since Aaron is a well paid executive of a small company, his household income is $300,000. That puts Aaron at the 24% tax bracket. Aaronâ€™s company offers a 15% discount on the share price. Finally, Aaron commits $20,000 to the ESPPÂ plan.

First, itâ€™s important to note that only your gains are taxedâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot your entire investment. In this case, if you were to sell the shares immediately after vesting, your discount would be your only gain. In other words, 15% of $20,000 orÂ $3000.

Second, uncle Sam would come calling for his portion of those $3000 at the end of the year. His share would be 24% of $3000 or $720â€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s what you owe the government.

Third, if you were to keep the shares for a year, you are still not scot-free. The capital gains tax is still 15% of $3000 orÂ $450.

By holding on to the shares for an entire year, youâ€™ve saved yourself less than $270 ($720 minus $450) or roughly 1% of the entire sum. To put that into perspective, my companyâ€™s stock went down 4% yesterday (and up 17%Â today).

I donâ€™t know about you but that does not seem like a good deal to me. Putting money in a single company is notoriously volatile. Doing it with the company you work for is a potential disaster.

Of course, this is a somewhat contrived example. There are many other things to take intoÂ account

  1. If youâ€™re filing individually and earning above $200,000, the gap between the income tax and capital gains tax is 20% instead of 9%. If youâ€™re earning $38,000, the gap is actually negative (the income tax is lower). You can find the latest ratesÂ here.
  2. If you contribute significantly more than $20,000 into the ESPP program your tax loss might be greater. Of course, that also means you must keep more money in a singleÂ stock.
  3. If the incentive from your employer is larger, your tax could be greater. For example, when purchasing ESPP shares, my employer uses either the price today or the one from 6 months agoâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhichever one is lower. As of this writing, the stock is up 10% from 6 months ago. My taxable gain is nowÂ higher.

It is worth evaluating your exact situation to determine how much money you are actuallyÂ saving.

Also, I donâ€™t want to imply that saving a couple of hundred bucks isnâ€™t worth the timeâ€Šâ€”â€Šit certainly is. I will gladly give my insurance company a call if it saves me money. That lizard has been good toÂ me.

However, these savings donâ€™t come for free. You are leaving a significant amount of money in a stock that you may or may not want toÂ own.

Therefore; my advice to you is this. Sell the damn shares. Put them in betterment. You can thank meÂ later.

I was at a friends house the other day. We sat down for a chat about life and work when his grandmother decided to walk into the room. She joined us at the table and then looked at me with excitement. â€œHave you heard of BitCoin?â€ she asked. She then followed that with â€œI heard itâ€™s an opportunity of a lifetime. You can be rich.Â Quick!â€.

Now this story is totally made up but the lesson here is not to be missed. As a rule of thumb, if everyone is talking about some amazing investment opportunity, itâ€™s probably already too late to make real money. This includes houses, gold, stocks or whatever fad comes next. This isnâ€™t to say that you can never make money. You definitely could! But you have to be aware that at that point it is just aÂ gamble.

The reasons for this argument are a bit complex but are discussed at length in the book â€œIrrational Exuberanceâ€ By Robert J. Shiller. He has a Noble prize so heâ€™s got to be on to something. The gist of it though is that humans are very much like cattle. We learn from each other and we follow each other. Weâ€™re also very prone to create market bubbles and over evaluate assets due to that herd mentality.

One other reason that I think people end up with bubbles thatâ€™s not as frequently discussed is that itâ€™s plain exciting. People love winning. I have a few colleagues who have made several thousand dollars off trading crypto-currencies. They love talking about them and which one is growing at what rate or what high it hit. However, since pretty much all the major crypto-currencies are up, itâ€™s hard to not make money over the last few years. You donâ€™t need any special skills. Although thatâ€™s probably missed byÂ them.

Also, I canâ€™t help myself but see the parallels between this and every single other asset bubble in history. Iâ€™m talking about gold a few years ago, housing before that, and tech before that (and probably now). Every single time it ends in tears and the witch hunt starts for who mislead theÂ public.

This article is going out on the interwebs for my millions of readers to see. That means that a few years from now someone could be reading this as they are paying their rent with some tiny fraction of BitCoin and laughing at my conclusions. I am well aware of it. This could be an absolute revolution in our financial system. And thatâ€™s great. Until then, Iâ€™m keeping my money in a well diversified indexÂ fund.

title: Mortgage interest deduction lies
content:encoded:
As some of you know, to stimulate home ownership in the United States, the government created a scheme where by you get to deduct the interest portion of your mortgage payments from your income to reduce it for tax purposes. Effectively, this means that the interest is paid using pretax dollars. Great! letâ€™s all go buyÂ houses.

Not so fast. Take anyone with any sort of economic sense and they will tell you there is no free lunch here. Youâ€™re not getting stuff cheaper. By subsidizing the payments, the government simply pushed the prices of housing up for everyone. If you donâ€™t believe me, answer this question: What do you think would happen if this was taken away now? If you said people would freak out and the prices would fall because payments are higher then reverse this argument.

Alright, so we know governments generally canâ€™t get shit right and a lot of policies are misguided. Does that mean this one is also just a big fat waste of money? Thatâ€™s sort of what I thought. At least until yesterday. Yesterday, I watched thisÂ video:

There were a couple of interesting points of conversation there. One in particular that caught my attention though was regarding this exact topic and your level of taxation. You see, since every owner gets to take advantage of this particular piece of policy, they save at the same rate as their marginal tax rate. On the other hand, the amount that this house went up in price due to this particular policy is roughly equal to the overall average marginal tax rate in the UnitedÂ States.

So what does that mean? That means that if you are at a higher margin tax rate then the average population, youâ€™d save money based on this policy. If youâ€™re in a lower tax bracket, you lose. The only additional point Iâ€™d like to make is that it is probably the average margin tax rate of an average house buyer. The poorest citizens probably keepÂ renting.

So this entire policy is not only making housing more expensive for everyone, but it is oddly also a subsidy for the rich by theÂ poor.

Iâ€™m not talking about tax cuts here that are great for everyone but happen to benefit the rich more (due to their larger tax bill in the first place). This is literally a transfer from the poor to theÂ rich.

title: Being priced out
content:encoded:
If you ever lived in an area with a hot housing market, youâ€™ve probably had more dinners that youâ€™d like to admit where the conversation started and ended with how â€œcrazyâ€ it is out there. Anecdotal evidence about multiple bids on some broken down shitty houses with no pictures on RedFin and how many hundreds of thousands over asking the house down the street sold for dominate.

This in turn tends to drive the renters between us to go on a buying frenzy, desperately looking for a house, any house to buy. Because you knowâ€¦ if you donâ€™t buy today, youâ€™ll be priced out forever. I know Iâ€™ve heard that many times; including here inÂ Seattle.

The same people always bring up the same examples. Look at San Francisco they say. Seattle (or insert the city that you live in) is the next San Francisco. â€œIf I bought ten years ago I could have retiredÂ todayâ€.

So hereâ€™s my contrarian theory. Now this probably doesnâ€™t apply in all cases 100% of the time. But, ask yourselfÂ this:

Were you ever priced in to the city in the firstÂ place?

For example, San Francisco has always been more expensive then Seattle by about a factor of two. If you happened to be the age that you are now, working in San Francisco a decade ago, could you afford it then? Keep in mind that itâ€™s very unlikely your salary would be theÂ same.

Iâ€™m not just talking about inflation. Iâ€™m thinking more broadly like what industry youâ€™re in. Are you in tech or nursing? Youâ€™re probably making way more money then you could a decade ago. These jobs are simply in higher demandsÂ now.

So when your Grandpa reminds you how he bought this house for 60k, donâ€™t forget to ask him how much he was earning per hour. It could make a lot of difference. Now, if you couldnâ€™t buy it then and you canâ€™t buy it now does not mean you shouldnâ€™t strive for it. I am just suggesting that we should keep this in mind when complaining about the state of affordability and how Amazon â€œruinedâ€ everything.

title: The true price of weddings
content:encoded:
This isnâ€™t really about weddings in particular but they are a good example of a phenomena I just picked up on. Itâ€™s the phenomena I would describe as irrational under-appreciation of money. I would love Dan Arielyâ€™s opinion aboutÂ this.

Hereâ€™s a scenerio: Youâ€™re planning your wedding. Your partner is going through all the little things that need to be done. You, as the financially savvy â€œfinance guyâ€ add up all the costs and realize this wedding is going to cost you roughlyÂ $15,000.

Now, we all know that money is time so a better question is, how much time is it going to cost you. You do the math and after the costs of working, commute, unwinding and the additional wardrobe you maintain, you take home roughly $10 an hour in savings so about 1500 hours of work. You bury your face in your hands and startÂ crying.

This analysis is probably more then what 99% of people do when they make buying decisions. This is probably too much to really expect from most anyway. Plus I donâ€™t think anyone would really want to do such an analysis each time they are about to buyÂ coffee.

So how about a much simpler analysis. Take a purchase in your life that you think was a great decision. For example, I recently bought a roundtrip ticket to Ghana for roughly $1200 and figure out how many times you could do the same trip using the money youâ€™re about to spend. This way, youâ€™re not dealing with abstract figures but actual valuable human experiences (orÂ things).

In this particular example, you could probably visit Ghana 14 times instead of having this extravagant wedding. So ask yourself this question, is this wedding worth 14 trips to Ghana. Of course, for that amount, you could probably visit all ofÂ Africa.

The idea is to equate it to something a little more concrete then just dollars so you grasp the value that youâ€™re dealing with. I find that otherwise, the numbers are too abstract and throwing around $5000 is just as easy as $10,000 without realizing that you just doubled yourÂ cost.

title: Chasing money
content:encoded:
My wife keeps insisting that knowing other peopleâ€™s salaries is a bad idea. You just set yourself up for misery. Her reasoning is that someone will always make more and youâ€™ll always feel like you need to make more too to match up and youâ€™ll never be happy with what youÂ have.

She is absolutely right (generally speaking). This is exactly how someone is bound to feel when finding out colleagues are making more while doing the same job. This is also completely independent of how you felt prior about your salary; An unfortunate humanÂ quirk.

However, once youâ€™re aware of this quirk, I feel like you can take advantage of it. Instead of sulking in your misery, you can do much better. You can make the following realization step byÂ step.

  1. Nothing has changed in your conditions.
  2. If you were happy with your salary before you should be happyÂ now.
  3. There is potential to make even more money so you should be evenÂ happier.

Most are perfectly content with how much they earn but why not earn more for the same work if they can? AfterÂ all,

Money isÂ time

title: My Secret to Productivity
content:encoded:
Everyone has a secret move or a special technique they use to keep themselves pumped up to complete a task. Amidst all the distraction from the likes of Youtube, Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, one may ask how is it possible to stay productive atÂ all?

In my mind, there are many things that need to be my attention. However, I usually have a tendency to delay things as long as possible. People call it many things, but I call it laziness. ğŸ˜–

It could be writing a Medium article, finishing up a chunk of code, reviewing a technical document, or just replying to an email. When Iâ€™m left to my own devices, I would basically imagine all these things in my head and feel the insurmountable amount of work that needsÂ doneâ€¦

When that grim mood sets in, my hand would instinctively reach into my pocket and pull out myÂ phone.

This had happened to me multiple times in the past, and it still does from time toÂ time.

But something changed. Once I discovered the secret cure to counter this terrible disease, Iâ€™ve been able to be 10x more productive than before, and as a direct result, bring much more joy into my life. My steps have springs in them, and my every waking day I feel a sense of mission and accomplishment.

Now, let me share with you my personal secret weapon to increase productivity.

MOMENTUM

Thatâ€™s it, I said it. Momentum. Itâ€™s a simple word, but a powerfulÂ force.

Momentum is what picks you up when youâ€™re down, keeps you going when youâ€™re overwhelmed, and maintains your focus when you sense distraction.
Momentum gets rid of triviality, and drivesÂ action.
Momentum is the power toÂ produce.

When I sense that my energy level is low, and yet there are heaps of stuff left to be done, I give myself a mental pat on the back and start with one simple goal: do one thing at aÂ time.

Let me give you an example. I started writing this article on a Tuesday evening at 10.10pm after work. I had just worked out, cleaned up the place and felt reallyÂ tired.

Yet, I promised my editor (Open source portfolio) that Iâ€™ll write at least an article this week to demonstrate mindful living in my ownÂ life.

After I sat down on my bed, my first thought was, â€œHmm, there are other, better things I can do with my time. Letâ€™s see whatâ€™s on Facebook before I get startedâ€¦â€

One thing led to another, and 10 minutes later I was still on Facebook. How often has this happened toÂ you?

Thatâ€™s when I told myself, â€œOK, letâ€™s try just one paragraph. Letâ€™s see what happensâ€¦â€

Thatâ€™s the magic phrase, letâ€™s see whatÂ happens.

Once you start doing something, the powerful magic of momentum will carry you forward without you knowingÂ it.

Fast-forward 20 minutes later, and Iâ€™ve already written close to 500 words. Much of it will probably be edited out in post-processing, but thatâ€™s OK. I have outdone myself, and wrote more than what I set out toÂ do.

In my opinion, the most important thing is to realize that productivity doesnâ€™t mean getting things done to perfection. Productivity, to me, means to execute and follow-through. Getting something out there is much better than nothing atÂ all.

Once you have momentum behind you, it is much easier to follow that flow and drive things to completion.

Tips & Tricks for BuildingÂ Momentum

Here is a list of tips & tricks I use to build momentum in my dailyÂ life:

  • I block out a chunk of time on my calendar every day for my own space. For example, on my work calendar, thereâ€™s a chunk of time from 3â€“5pm that is allocated for coding. I have understanding teammates who donâ€™t book meetings on those power-hours because itâ€™s important for me to keep sanity and have time to myself to do things I need toÂ do.
  • Fill in mundane tasks with something productive. Reading more books is one of my goals for this year. When I feel overwhelmed and need to get away, Iâ€™ll try to pull out a book or listen to an audiobook on Spotify. I have a book in my backpack at all times, and having something to put my mind into is very helpful in those situations. The goal here is to build a productive habit, and you can replace reading with something else like working out or taking out theÂ trash.
  • Set a schedule and stick to it. Working out is something I dread, yet itâ€™s important for my overall health. Earlier this year when I sat down and analyzed why I wasnâ€™t working out more, I realized that having to drive to the gym and mentally set myself in work-out mode was time-consuming and counter-productive. What I did, then, was I built my own little home gym. My small gym only has some free weights and a bench, but the effects are tremendous. Every day, Iâ€™ll spend 30â€“40 minutes in the gym either lifting or doing a quick jog. Again, I build momentum here by just showing up. 80% of the battle is already won when you show up, and thatâ€™s the beauty of momentum.

Those are just some examples of how I use momentum in my daily life to drive productivity. Iâ€™d like to know if you have any productivity tips to share asÂ well!

Credits

If you liked this, here are some other articles he hasÂ written:

  • How to write a great resume for software engineers
  • How I automated my job search by building a webÂ crawler
